content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												This is a long review, so just read the bottom paragraph for a simple summary of my thoughts.It surprises me that the general consensus for this game is worse than Risen 2: Dark Waters. To be fair, if you hated Risen 2, there likely are not enough redeeming factors about the end of the trilogy to be worth your while. But nevertheless, some substantial improvements to the overall experience have made this a promising step in the right direction for Piranha Bytes as a developer.Risen 2: Dark Waters was ultimately a failure as an open world, engrossing RPG. It was extremely shallow, overall having one of their smallest and most lackluster world designs to date, with most of the islands consisting of winding pathways with few interesting landmarks leading between major locations. These locations were greatly devoid of life, as the characters were as dull and two-dimensional as wooden boards. The combat wasn't the worst I've ever seen in a game, but it took forever to get the necessary skills to stay on top of combat, and by then you just got used to button mashing between prayers. Beyond combat, half the skills in the game were worthless or used in only scripted situations that were easy enough to do without.At first glance, or maybe even for the first couple hours, Risen 3 hardly seems any different. But if you put some effort into it, you'll find much more in store here. The combat system is widely criticized for the wrong reasons. To be fair, the easiest way to fail at Risen 3 was the only way to WIN in Risen 2: button mashing is heavily discouraged in Risen 3, as timing your combos poorly results in substantially slower attacks. Instead, the game encourages you to time your attacks with precision, and focus your efforts between multiple foes instead of trying to spam them to death one at a time. It also has a dodge maneuver, which Risen 2 lacked on release (and when they patched it in, it was hardly any more useful). In fact, the dodge led to quite the opposite criticism: that combat was too easy, since dodging made you invulnerable during the animation. (A patched-in "Ultra" difficulty removes these invincibility frames, if you dare - as well as forcing a cooldown between potion uses.) Beyond that, skills you can learn from instructors give you a parry ability, faster combos, additional combo attacks, and further stat increases to make you unstoppable by the end of the game. It's still not a flawless combat system overall, but this is a world where Skyrim's dreadful DPS-focused combat dodges any ounce of criticism while a game like this is torn to pieces over a moderately tactical system.The magic system is a bit unique, and certainly much more appealing than the lame voodoo system of Risen 2. Combat magic is available to all three factions, but much more varied to the Guardian faction. Some spells are equipped as a primary weapon and used in place of a sword - these spells can be used as a moderately-ranged attack in melee, or aimed as a projectile. Support magic can be placed in your quickbar for a single rapid cast, after which it requires a cooldown. Each faction has their unique spells which can only be acquired through the faction, but single-use versions (scrolls, voodoo dolls, runestones) can be found and used by any class as a disposable magical support with no cooldown.The only thing that truly disappointed me about the magic was that there was hardly any difference between the different types of offensive magic. Fire and Ice did the same amount of damage, for example, and had no unique effects, such as freezing enemies or igniting them. You only switched between them if you found an enemy who was immune to one and not the other.The world design is notably improved. The game does re-use two islands from Risen 2, and scales them down considerably, but the new locations are significantly larger, have more to explore, and have areas of the map that open up as you complete more of the story. The maps themselves are a bit more open, but still tend toward a frustratingly path-focused design that makes most of the locations seem more linear than they really are. Thankfully, they've expanded the game in a vertical direction, allowing you a BIT more freedom in climbing. It's still obvious where you can and cannot climb, for the most part, but ambitious explorers may find rewards hidden in unexpected places if you can find a way. A large assortment of books can be found throughout, attempting to expand the game's lore or close some of the plotholes left between the previous titles.I can't say the characters have improved significantly - there are plenty of fodder characters who just seem cut and paste from the previous game, and are often indistinguishable from others, but they've greatly increased in number, and the dialog has vastly increased as well. Many of the characters are still cringe-worthy or dull as dishwater, but a few still made a note with me as I played, such as the woeful Mortimer on Fog Island, the quiet yet stoic demon hunter Kane, and the misforunate Burke, many of whom have interesting quests or even just stories to tell.You know what to expect with the questing - most RPG's these days have the same number of fetch or exterminate quests, but even in this regard, I'd say Risen 3 at least makes some of them more interesting. If you're feeling adventurous, make sure you disable quest markers - otherwise, if you're getting bored, use them to wrap up sidequests quickly. At least Risen 3's questgivers will tell you what to do and where to go, so you don't HAVE to depend on floating arrows to guide you if you don't want them.The number of items in the game has increased, with more variety to melee weapons, magic, and firearms. Some of the weapons are mechanically indistinguisable from each other (crossbows vs. pistols, for example) yet require different skills to use. The "legendary items" quests from Risen 2 make a return, and number slightly higher, providing potent stat increases. Unique weapons can be found in two pieces, to be reforged at a smithy - but with no clues on how to find these weapons, it's quite possible you'll have better ones by the time you find both pieces.Unfortunately, the game again shipped with day-one DLC, with two story DLC's and one item-only one. Needless to say, developing gameplay content prior to release and charging separately for it is not a practice that consumers should ever endorse, but at least each DLC is slightly larger than Risen 2's, with a smaller price tag.Final consensus: this game does not do enough to change the most vitriolic opinions about Risen 2. Nevertheless, Piranha Bytes appears to have taken some of the largest points of contention into consideration with Risen 3. Not everything got done that fans wanted, but in the shorter development time, dealing with internal restructuring and losing major designers, I think Piranha Bytes was able to focus on their most egregious sins and provide a substantial package that I don't regret paying for.

												I recommend this game for those who enjoy a challenge.  NOT for players seeking the details.  READ the CONS, if these truly matter to you, DO NOT BUY. If you can live without those for a challenge, then this is a game for you.I do NOT feel this game is worth the $50.00, so if you feel this is for you, be sure to follow it and wait for a sale.The only problems I've had, none game breaking thus far, are1. Purchase points: a. I chose this game after reading the reviews of those who had 50+ game hours, ensuring that I was getting information and recommendations from payers who not only take time to truly evaluate a game, but also enjoy the same challenge that I do and really try to learn.   b.  I also choose it after viewing the acheivments and seeing the acheivements 'Perfectionist: complete 300 quests", and kill ### so and so monster or animal. Many of the other acheivments are to complete specific quests, or that is how it appeared to me, So this part made my decision a touch more difficult.The Purchase point that disappointed me most was B.  I have yet to join a faction, I only have mages up to the joining ceremony and yet it shows I have completed 146 quests.  I've completed almost half of the game before I even join a faction??? By the time I do join a faction I will have completed over half of the entire game.  ( Unless I am understanding the acheivment incorrectly, and 'Perfectionist" does NOT mean that you complete all quests in the game. )  Mind you, There are EXTREMELY important ..... abilities / items not obtainable until you do join a faction.And the reason I have completed so many quests is where they placed Quests.  What I mean by this is what actions or goals are considered quests.  An example is when you begin the game, you start on a ship, your woken up and told to come top side to join your 'mate' ( I will do my best to give away the absolute least regarding story or spoilers. ) and literally you only need exit the room to complete your first quest,  " Find so and so island"  When did I 'FIND' it?  In truth someone else found it.  I only woke up and moved my♥♥♥♥♥♥    2.  The combat:  a. CON:  Combat is difficult, so far every monster I have met is able to attack without so much as a wind up or a way to tell they are about to strike, thus not giving you a chance to dodge or block, my attacks are however all wind ups, meaning all monster seem to break my attacks over and over. If I am attacked by 2 or 3 monsters I have had to run because one will complete attacking and as I wind up my attack the next one interupts me, and another attacks after that. Basically meaning I can't get a single hit in on them as they pummel me.  Also they get 2 to 3 consecutive attacks without my being able to interupt with my own attacks, I am only able to dodge like mad or pray they dont break my block. While every one of my attack is interuptable. b. PRO:  OMG the challenge to perfect this is amazing.  I've never played a game that has started with such a combat system that forces you to learn mechanics so quickly.3.  Dialog: a. CON:  Dialog is a bit lame, when reporting a quest complete, if the quest has more then one objective you have to select each objective as completed, then after you go through the "I finished this part, I finished this part, I finished this part, I finished this part, you have to then click "I did everything you asked me to."  As if clicking 4 times for 4 objectives isn't enough to prove you completed all tasks.    CON:  Some dialog choices are out of order, Your only available selection will be "I'll take you there."  and their responce will be "Ohh thank you."  " I did this, and the monsters are everywhere."  "How will I get home?"  Giving me the 'Will you help me' statement AFTER the 'yea, I'll help ya."  CON:  Voice overs,Just before you leave the first island an important event occurs, and a party member joins you When you speak to this member they have a specific tone, and way of speaking. After speaking with them regarding several different things as you travel, their voice will change, suddenly as if they fired the voice over actor and were to lazy to fix the previous voice over recordings. And what I mean by change isn't simply the tone, it is also the manner in which words are spoken.  b. PRO:  The amount of information provided is very nice, your given much information regarding missions, characters, locations and story content.4. Map:  a. CON:  You are given very little detail on your mini-map and full screen map, making travel difficult, and understanding which way you need to go to enter certain 'interior zones. b. PRO:  This is actually more realistic for the era the game is played in as map makers were not as meticulous as they are now adays, and adds to the challenge of the game.5. Mission Log: a. CON:  Finding specific missions that you are on, in order to mark key points on your map, can be can be very difficult as it is a bit difficult to understand how they catagorized things. b. PRO:  as you move through the missions and add more quests to your log the rhyme and reason become apparent, easier to navagate, but also makes sense.So, although there are many cons, I personally am enjoying the game, because the cons really don't break the game play, and the pro's seem to show me that the developer was looking to increase the overall challenge instead of spending to much time on the little things that can be easily ignored.  I understand that when a company releases a game as completed that it means they have fixed the bugs and CONS I have mentioned above.  This is why I only recommend the game to those who are specifically seeking a challenge, and NOT for players who are simply looking for story and graphics.Well that's my two cents, (Looking back) ok that's more like a buck 50,  I hope this information helps you decide if this is a game for you, and thank you for giving my first review time to read. :)I hope you all enjoy!!

Pros- Incredible visuals. Probably the best fire I've seen in a game.- Goofy as usual. Piranha Bytes hasn't changed a bit, and I like it.- Great open world gameplay. There's a lot to explore and find.- Magic is back, and it's satisfying.Cons- Awkward sword combat--things just don't feel quite right, but with time, you get used to it.- Companions aren't as helpful as they are capable.- Story is decent, but unmemorable.- Astral vision ability could have been a lot cooler if there were puzzles or areas where it was required. I found I never really used it.VerdictIf you're looking for a decent, challenging RPG with a sense of humor, definitely get this game. The whole series is fun. Don't expect a Witcher game, but don't let the Metacritic score scare you off either.(Take the Witcher comment with a grain of salt. If you don't like that series, then <insert favorite RPG here>)

												I normally played turn-based RPG, but decided to try Risen 3 for a change.I totally enjoyed this game. It has a great storyline and is extremely immersive.I spend many hours carefully picking up everything, collecting all Legendary Items, and Reforging the best Weapons in the game.I also spend many hours trying to get all the Steam Achievements and was able to do so in a single playthough as a Demon Hunter. It seems that this is the only faction that you can get all achievements in a single playthrough. The other 2 factions, Guardian and Natives all have missing achievements.The combat sequence was extremely fun too. The only hard part for me was the Sea Battles and the Final Boss Fight, because they both require fast interactive responses which was difficult for me. The mini-game were really fun, although the archery one is quite difficult too. However, getting Legendary Items from instances of certain mini-game were a great idea and an incentive as well.Anyway this is really a fun game and it is wonderful to spend many hours in it.I highly recommend this game.

Posted: September 21, 2016
												Originally known for creating sloppy, difficult RPGs that gave the player full freedom in an open world, then deprived him of anything resembling a functional control scheme to interact with it, Piranha Bytes continues moving away from both the pros and cons of its heritage with Risen 3: Titan Lords. Although it is restrictive, small in size, and has a game world that doesn't change, Risen 3 is also easier, more refined, and more approachable than its predecessors. Risen 3 takes place shortly after Risen 2 without providing any background information on the setting. The male, unnamed protagonist is Patty's brother whose existence wasn't acknowledged in the prior games. Changing the protagonist between games wasn't handled well. Returning characters can't chat with him about past events because he wasn't around, and without establishing the setting, the game expects the player to already know the events of Risen and Risen 2 to fully appreciate characters and factions that were fleshed out in those games but not in Risen 3.While searching an ancient ruin for treasure, the hero stumbles into a massive skull cave spewing a small contingent of shadow warriors. When he gets too close to a crystal gate, a shadow lord pops out and sucks the soul out of his mouth, killing him. A pirate's life is full of tragedy, and after three or four seconds of crying Patty leaves his corpse in the sand and goes back to treasure hunting. For reasons that aren't elaborated upon, a part-time shaman returns him to life and sets him on a quest to reunite with his spirit stuck in the Underworld. The game's subtitle implies there will be titan lords too, but don't hold your breath.The story as a whole is uninspired. Crystal gates to the Underworld start appearing everywhere, unleashing shadow minions upon the Southern Seas. The hero cooperates with human settlements in the area to close the gates, kill the shadow armies, and get his spirit back along the way. There are three joinable factions on separate islands, and membership in one serves as a bottleneck for plot progression rather than a well-planned addition to the story. Regardless of which faction is chosen, they coexist peacefully and the hero ultimately needs to assist and recruit all three of them. This is in stark contrast to past Piranha Bytes games where siding with a faction was serious, world-changing business. Here, it affects the hero's chest armor and which spells are permanently learned, but nothing meaningful related to the story. Although the world is open and the small islands and their "run to every corner of the island and do something" quests can be completed in any sequence, the player only picks the order of events that will all occur by the end.Unfortunately, the characters and dialogue are no better. The writing is dull and repetitive, and when everyone is chatty it makes listening to the voice actors slowly enunciate each line feel like it's taking up too much of the game's total playtime. Inconsistencies in the setting and writing impact all aspects of both. A starving village complaining about the lack of food might have piles of fish lying around. Four NPCs in a row might make a nearly identical gallows humor joke, then no one else in the game does. It's distracting when large chunks of the script read like they were written in the same sitting by the same person due to the repetition therein. Word repetition frequently occurs within an NPC's conversation when dialogue relies on parroting the same exact phrases in statements and interrogatives, back and forth. Dialogue also has issues where the flow is off, with NPCs and the hero having unnatural segues and answering questions with incorrect expressions and sentence structures. The writing has some successful moments and executions, but on the whole it stretches out and hurts an already uninteresting setting.The battle system has its problems too. In the beginning, the hero fights as a pirate using a sword for a melee weapon and pistols or throwing knives for ranged attacks. Melee range in Risen 3 is a long distance. When initiating an attack, friends and enemies leap-teleport across the distance to strike, not unlike Batman in his modern series. Attacks can form a three-hit combo. The first attack is lightning-fast while the final hit takes so long that most enemies in the game recover from being stunned and can land a hit before it comes out. Between defending, teleport-attacking, and charged strikes, combat has a tactical feel to it that's somewhat lost in the speed and chaos. Some enemies are so fast they can instantly launch stun-locking combos at will. Others are so defensive it can take a long time just to land a strike. Companions are bad at drawing aggro and most enemies come in packs of two to four, meaning the player is stuck rolling all over the place, trying to avoid stun-locks from fast foes while getting a few hits in when possible. There's no way to lock onto a single enemy, making it tough to target one and take it out before hitting the others. Combat can be annoying and test one's patience, but due to a large health pool and instant, animation-free healing, death is hardly a serious threat.Combat completely changes later in the game, though. Whether it was to encourage players to try guns and magic when they become available, or pure sadism, the ability to counterattack after a parry is a special talent which must be purchased from a trainer after experience points are spent upgrading the hero's melee attribute. This skill, which should have been available from the start, goes a long way toward fixing melee combat. When guns are equipped in the melee slot, combat becomes even easier. Gunshots can't be blocked and are more powerful than swords. Although they must be manually aimed with a radial sight on the screen, hit detection is generous. Finally, after joining a faction the hero can use magic as a primary attack. Like guns, magic can't be blocked. Like melee, magic auto-aims. Using magic or guns negates everything that was tactical about combat, making it so much faster and easier that only role-players and the masochistic would still be using swords by the endgame. It would have been nice if there were more balance between these mechanics or if swordplay were less frustrating, but it's fun to blast through foes quickly in the last half of the game. The progression system provides more than enough experience points and stat-boosting methods to be a journeyman of everything and a master of whatever playstyles are preferred.Risen 3 fares well overall when it comes to the presentation. The art style is lifelike, but more clean and color-saturated than the real world. Outdoor areas are nice and vivid without looking cartoony. Character models have an unnatural shape that's unfortunate during all the bobbing-head dialogue, and indoor locations can be untextured and bland, but considering this isn't a high budget game nothing is appalling. The music is serviceable, but the sound is pulled down by the rough voice-acting. The hero's voice-acting is great with natural gravel to it. NPCs, though, are awful and made worse by how long-winded every character is. Sometimes words are mispronounced and sentences are emphasized incorrectly, like the actor had one take and didn't know the context of the line.Risen 3 is a decent game. It looks, runs, and plays fine with the main downsides being the story and script and anything related to them. The problem is that everything Risen 3 does decently has already been done better. It's a small in scope, small in size, very generic hodgepodge of the foundations of many action games and RPGs without any of the specializations that made them memorable and superior. Ten years ago Risen 3 would have been ground-breaking, but today it is a fine, unremarkable game I expect to forget about in a few weeks.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												The Risen 'series' isn't really much of a series at all.  Risen 1 was very obviously a rebranded Gothic 4 that followed the events of the 'neutral' path of Gothic 3: Xardas and the Nameless Hero banish the gods.  Given its moderate success, however, Deep Silver dangled a bag of money in front of Piranha Bytes and out pooped Risen 2 -- an abomination of a game that somehow missed all the hallmarks of what made prior PB games great.  Apparently Risen 2 sold well enough to justify a Risen 3.  Unsurprisingly there will be no Risen 4.What did PB do right this time around?  Factions are back after their mysterious absence in Risen 2.  And while they don't quite approach the Gothic 1 and 2 levels of distinction they arguably surpass those in Risen 1 (with a very disappointing shallow difference between Warrior of the Order and Mage).  Moreover, each faction has its unique school of magic where spells have distinctive themes and are fueled by different 'currencies.'The game is less linear with the ability to choose which island you tackle first; or, you can go back and forth and explore as you wish with little in the way of artificial barriers impeding your progress.  Unfortunately this pro feeds into one of the game's biggest cons: about a third or so of the way through no enemy presents a challenge.  Even on the harder difficulties you aren't at risk of dying save for the occasional one shot from certain creatures if your magic resistance is low.  And while there's plenty of content it eventually becomes a tedious slog through the same old monsters.  In one section on Kila in the final third or so of the game I swear I must have hacked my way through at least a hundred spiders.The character system is much the same as it was in Risen 2 but its greatest flaw is that once you decide on the type of combat you want to focus on (melee, firearms, or magic); you can get close to maximizing it fairly early on.  Throw some points in Toughness to take some hits and that's all you need.  Dexterity is needed for lockpicking if you don't go mage (who have spells to handle locks) but the other skills are borderline worthless.  Silver Tongue is useful maybe a half dozen times and there's always an alternative to it.  Pickpocketing merely nets you a few extra items but you'll be swimming in gold soon enough.  Intimidate is equally as useless as Silver Tongue.  After 30+ hours of playing I haven't even touched alchemy or distilling.  Crafting isn't needed unless you're a completionist.  And then there's this 'second sight' ability to let you scout for gold, weapons, monsters, whatever... and I never used it a single time.  If you have a pulse and a few brain cells you will have no problems spotting the loot and the very few levers you need to pull to progress through the game.Melee combat is as unsatisfying as it was in Risen 2.  Most monsters will go into stun-lock charges a la Gothic 3 so your best defense isn't parrying but rolling.  Risen 1 did it better and while shields were overpowered the simple introduction of a stamina mechanic to prevent you from turtling up would have been the more elegant solution.  Fortunately the magic is better so you can nuke your way through the throngs of spiders, skeletons, and hell hounds you'll get sick of by hour fifteen or so.The story is uninteresting and largely unexplained.  Instead of the character from the first and second games you now play as the brother of Patty.  Why?  No reason, really.  Outside of the tutorial section Patty becomes largely irrelevant unless you opt to use her as one of a half dozen or so companions in combat.  You could be random Pirate Joe for all it matters.  I didn't even see a mention of the Titans or the events of the last few games until around halfway through.  All you know is: you died, you need to get your spirit back, evil demon things are attacking, and... you have to assemble a fleet to fight the ghost of a dude who died in the second game.An unfortunate companion to the 'story' is the non-stop 'dream' sequences you have whenver you sleep.  You wake up in the spirit world and wander around until you have a brief conversation with characters from the previous games or some big monster spawns, goes BOO, and you wake up.  Similarly jarring are the awful arcade combat vignettes against sea monsters.  Three or four times as you progress the story you're forced into a ship battle where you tool around and fire at it with ONE canon.  Fun times.Risen 3 is a game that screams 'fulfilling our contractual obligation for X number of sequels.'  And while PB puts in some effort to improve upon the turkey of Risen 2; there are still far too many flaws to justify the series continuance beyond the first game.

												Risen 3 – Titan Lords~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ As I have not played the previous two (2) games, I really had no idea what this game would be like.7 hours down the track, I am absolutely amazed by it. The amount of quests I am getting in one location is just unbelievable; I am literally losing count. This RPG is set in a world of Pirates with absolutely stunning visuals. If you enjoy taking screenshots do not look further, this game will give you plenty of opportunities to snatch great screenshots from sunset to beautiful sceneries.Great open world and apart from quests you have a fair few of other things to do like picking up clams where you can get pearls or gathering food, vegetation for potions/magic, and a must for a good pirate, rum and other distilled substances. They are great sources of health in the game. Argh...hip Argh...hip...burp...Argh!One thing I like so far is you do not have to worry about how many objects your character is carrying, just collect them. Anyway, you will be able to trade your goods with multiple people in each destination. And, you will be able to learn many essential skills like using a monkey! Yes you will!Along the way you meet characters and you can invite them to your party. I already have two at this stage (different skills) and they are very useful especially during combat. However, you have to choose who you want at your side when you arrive at each location. For the combat side of the equation, it could have been smoother but it is fine. I am just being a little bit picky here. A little bit of advice, try to upgrade your character attributes as soon as possible because some foes are quiet challenging and even with a companion at your side you just might die quickly. The audio is good and the story is sound. A good RPG all round.Positives:~~~~~~~ -	Great graphics-	Good story-	Massive number of quests-	In depth character options-	Challenging adversaries-	Good humour-	Achievements-	Trading cardsNegatives:~~~~~~~~ -	Combat system could have been betterA very solid RPG in my opinion. Thumbs up.8/10MORE THE_CPT_FROGGY REVIEWS HEREFOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

												Risen 3 is Finally out and is now being hit by reviews that are up and down. Let me talk about my experience and what this game's strong point and weak points. Read first before you point that dangerous thumb at me.  As a new protaganist to the series, you are the son of steelbeard and brother of Patty who both are on the way to crab island to discover treasure from a map only to run into the army of the underworld and have your soul taken. The only thing you can do is to try to redeem it by battling against the forces of darknessRisen 3 is a good improvement over 2 in many ways, Fans of PB's  original risen will love it, those who hated/loved 2 will also be welcomed back to the pirate theme with new improvements, and those that are new to the series will be a hit or miss. The game isn't like your typical rpg or Skyrim. It is a third person rpg with different style, rules and combat. Don't be mislead though this game isn't about sailing the open oceans or exploring a massive world but instead lets you explore certain lands of reasonable size that is filled with plenty of quests, dangers, and treasures.The combat system itself feels more smooth this time around as as it reverts itself away from risen 2 and taps back to its root like Risen with some added tweaks and with a much more fun magic gameplay. Yes you do start this game off weak, in fact you'll have to depend on your companions which you can choose to bring one at a time during the game to help you. You'll have to count on them because enemies will swipe you, attack you from sides, dodge your attacks and even blind side you when you aren't looking and in groups. In fact hard mode can be quite a challenge during the start  game. As you progress the game leveling the way you want you'll start realizing that your efforts will start paying off. You'll start investing in new skills to aid you in becoming stronger  even experiencing better combat which should feel a bit more fluid and much like original risen. You'll also  be able to switch weapons and spells via the bottom hotbars, while combining the use of  items and scrolls becoming more powerful in fact too powerful to the point where you're completely ridiculously almost overpowered, killing enemies in a few hits..The game offers you a choice to join between 3 factions. Voodoo, Demon hunters, or Guardians and you can only commit to one so choose carefully. Each offering its own unique skills and spells to help you fight. Some though are similar to other faction.The game leveling systems revolves around glory and gold. You earn glory from mostly killing and questing.The quest system in this game is well done in a way so that if you've already encountered the quest you'll be able to turn it in to the npc when it is requested eliminating that need to go back and forth. There are Plenty of quests and things to do in the game to acquire glory and gold. The return of magic this time around is more  fun to play with depending on your faction you've picked.You'll be able to utilize spells from that faction otherwise you'll have to buy runes and scrolls.Spells are also a completely seperate tree  and requires certain gems to purchase. When you attain spells you'll only be limited to casting by a cooldown timers. For every faction is a spell you can use as a melee spell over and over again.,You can even improve the timer and combo off more or cast faster. Yes I became a mage and I kick ♥♥♥ with a epee in my hand raining fireballs upon my enemies and stealing stuff by just reaching out my hands and did fire bending somagic this time around is  more fun.Aside from the gameplay the sound and music is perfectly fine for this game, the graphics though a bit outdated is much better than its previous series for sure and the game feels more optimized (save for the 8 cores + situation). If you are a fan of the series you will see that it is NOT THAT BAD though could be improved much more. The voice acting is decent for  in the game  though  some are  a bit cheesy (such as bone) or bad but can be looked over because the dialogues actually get a bit better later in the game.. Sometimes you can see the devs joking around with the dialogue by adding really funny questions and phrases and isn't meant to be taken too seriously. The quests themselves in this game contain many lore behind the world of risen 3 and will keep you wanting to do the quest. You'll have retrieval quests, kill quests, subquests, and mainquests. Not all quests are grindy at all or without purpose.There are choice dialogues in this game and the choices affects the outcome of what happens. The choice is really up to you on how you want to play the game, maybe you'll steal, maybe you'll use your tongue and intimidate or pick another choice to accomplish your mission. maybe you rather be the bad guy and lose a bit of your humanity or gain humanity. Whatever you  choose to do in the game will either acquire your soul back or help you lose it much quicker.anyways check the game out. This game might not be the cup of tea for everyone.Make your own damn decision on the game. Don't be mislead  by naysayers and research it well.  I beaten the game around 25 hours and thats not doing EVERY quest there is in the game, once I became OP i went straight for the last mission. Reason is because I can save my other quests on the other islands for other playthroughs as different faction. I enjoyed the game quite a bit and hope that in the future they can improve on some of the cons I've written about the game. + Game starts off really slow  and difficult but gets better as you progress+ Tons of quests, plenty of glory and gold to be found+ Ship battle with sea monsters are challenging+ The combat is much better than risen 2 but can feel a bit clunky at first until you progress a bit.+ Quests systems completes if you done it already in the world so you don't have to actually grab it to do it you can turn it in as long as you've done it.+ Magic is fun, try guardians and firebend.+ You can be any class you want to be varying from 3 factions.+ Plenty of gear to play around with and stats you can mix and match to your advantage. Legendary weapons included and upgraded weapons.+- Reused map and game materials from 2 +- Subpar dialogue and lots of comedy and jokes, sometimes funny, sometimes cheesy, sometimes very bad+- Some people will probabaly not like the way the combat is done, you get a certain amount of combo hit and you must dodge or attack your enemy.- Armor feels more asthetic than useful sometimes, I found myself wearing adventurer armor during the entire game and barely changing to the other armors.- weapons animation are all the same, along with fist spells, wish elements played a role against enemies more.- combat can be repetitive after you become OP and autotarget can cause issues if you face an npcs you could accidentally hit them sometimes. - difficulty scaling could have some improvement.t- Voice is decent, main character sounds like Christian Bale's Batman.- Graphics needs updated engine, decent at max- camera can be clunky during dialogue sometimes- The item interface can be reworked much better, hate having to hotbar everything to use it such as self cast spells, also need rework on keybindings.-  The game could interact button instead of the attack button as interact, sometimes you accidently just talk to your companion in the fray of things or clicking to find loot because it is all one button.- Need patch to fix 8 core limitation that is causing a blackscreen- spells are a lackluster- World empty after you kill everything, it doesn't respawn so no more mobs respawn.finished on twitch.tv/kenuty on 8/13/2014Video review -

												Risen 3: Titan Lords is an RPG game developed by Piranha Bytes and published by Deep Silver. It’s the third game in the Risen series. The game was released in August 2014 on PC, Xbox360 and PS3, but the PS4 got a remastered version of the game is August 2015. The game plays almost the same as the first two games in the series. An easy to use combat system which makes you counter and parry enemy sword swings whilst you weave in your own attacks. I found the combat system to be very clunky and not very responsive to your input.  Whilst in combat you are able to use your range weapon too; I found this to be a rather pointless addition as it misses the majority of the time even on much bigger targets.  You are able to freely explore the world and take on plenty of side quests. Each of the quests has different ways to solve them, which is a nice element, depending on how you resolve the quest; you may even get a different outcome.  I liked the fact you can play the game in almost any order you choose, meaning you can mould your character exactly how you want it to be. Graphically, I wasn’t too impressed, for me it looks worse than the previous games. I was playing on 4k and it looked really poor. Texture quality was mediocre at best. The lush scenery when exploring islands does redeem itself a bit, but what’s inside that lushness is some really bad looking modelling. The animation and sound effects are so bad, they are sometimes laughable. I believe all modern games should have voice acting in, and sadly Risen 3 has some absolutely awful voice actors. Every single word that is spoken just feels out of place and does not match up with the game play at all. It almost made the cut scenes unbearable sometimes. During the first fifteen minutes of gameplay, there is almost silence. All you hear is the gun fire, no shouting, sound effects of fights, nothing. It just seems to have very poor production values. The game is pretty easy even when playing on the hard settings. The combat system, when you get a hang of it, is easy to use, meaning you can be taking on larger groups of enemies before too long. A lot of the time throughout the game you will be accompanied by a companion which also makes the combat scenes more easily handled too. I only died a handful of times so there isn’t any major challenge to be found here. Risen 3 does have a very good amount of content to play through. Each chapter of the game has at least 20+ side quests for you to tackle. Whilst the side quests don’t distract you too much from the main plot, they are a good addition to the game, that rewards you with money and much needed experience for completing them. I didn’t find myself wanting to complete a lot of them though; they are all very samey after you complete half a dozen; the side quests in this game are nothing when you compare it to the likes of Witcher. The game took me almost twenty five hours to complete, with a fair few of the side missions completed. For me, since I was struggling to get through the abundance of cut scenes and dialogue, I feel that was almost a bit too much, even now I have plenty of side quests I could complete but I honestly don’t think I can put myself through any more of it. You can probably get about 40 hours of content out of this game, and you may even want to consider a second play through given the amount of choice some of the quests offer. I didn’t have any technical problems whilst playing thankfully. I was able to play at 1440p with all of the graphical settings turned up to max and still have a steady 60 fps. I played the game with keyboard and mouse, as I found that to be best for the previous games in the series, but the game will work perfectly well with a controller since it is in the third person perspective. To sum up, I believe Risen 3 to be the worst of the series so far. The first two games had better animation and voice acting in than this one, and to some extent, they even looked better graphically.  The game is currently retailing for £24, 99, and sadly I don’t think it’s even worth half of that. If you are a fan of RPG games and the Risen series, I would suggest you wait till it drops to the £10 mark, just so you don’t feel too let down by the poor production values on show here. Whilst the game does have a vast open world exploration feel to it, it just didn’t live up to my expectations for the third game in a really good pirate series.  Tom's Score Card1) Stay away2) Not Recommended3) Only recommended when on sale4) Recommended5) Highly recommended6) This is a must playIf you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. 												I finished the game right now and well...I have mixed feelings about it. I give a thumbs up because I loved previous Risen games, and want to support the developer which is a semi indy european company, but I'm not sure if I can recommend this.Ok, the things which Piranha does great in general, does great also in this game: the atmosphere, the exploration, the humor and the side quests. AND Risen 3 does a better job in those things which are generally bad in Piranha games, like it is more polished than previous Risen games, and finally has an approachable fighting system as well, but the story is horrible as usual (even if Risen 2 had a decent story anyway).So what's the problem? The problem is that the game is not new. RIsen 1 was an interesting game, and then Risen 2 came out and was able to bring some freshness, so they were different and innovative experiences on their own. But Risen 3 is not more than Risen 1+2 with an updated Risen 2 graphics. It is disappointing even if the game is very enjoyable.Then for whatewer reason the devs cut the story and the lore of the previous games and introduced a new storyline and arch enemy. It was quiet a WTF?? What made the story more messy is that they made constant references to the happenings of the previous games even if the story line doesn't have any connection with Risen 1+2. Because the story was uninteresting I felt the game a little longer than I wanted. It is a 40+ hour game, bear in mind.So should I recommend this game? Well, if you love Piranha Bytes games and want to get all of them, you will buy it. If you enjoyed the previous games but you are not a hardcore fan don't buy it, becuase previous Risen games are better. If you hated them, you will hate also this one.But for starters maybe this is the most accessable game. It is the most polished out of the 3 ones with the best fighting system, and becuase it has a different story you don't need to play the older games to get into it.I personally enjoyed it, but I feel it completely skippable. Piranha Bytes next time you need to try harder coz ppl won't buy your games!!!

												(Updated my review below)Now let me start off my review by saying that this isn't a game for casual players. If you want to mash some buttons and get through stuff alright you're gonna get frustrated and angry.People who have played Gothic and previous Risen games will feel right at home here though.The game is in many ways an improvement over Risen 2, I'll sum up all the points I think have been improved over compared to the previous game in the franchise.+ Much bigger world+ Tons of quests and things to do+ Combat at sea against sea monsters (ripped from Assassins Creed Black Flag but still nice)+ 3 different factions to join (exactly like in gothic 2, you can pick one and stuff will change according to your choice)+ Magic is back, there are tons of spells and skills for you to learn (Voodoo is back and awesome!)+ Treasure searching from Risen 2 is back in force and theres a lot of stuff for you to find+ Companions have more to say and aren't just there like in Risen 2, the game feels more alive. (They give you advice and sometimes really save your life during fights)+ Less bugs and glitches than in Risen 2 (although there are still a few minor issues)+ Gorgeous evironments! (Seriously, look at some screenshots!)+ Music and sound is perfect!+ Replayablility because of the 3 different factions (You can only join one of them so you can play the game again and experience it in a different way with different skills and everything!)+ Hilarious dialog sometimes+ Feels a lot like gothic! (no, seriously it does. The 3 different factions you can join and the overall feel of the game when you're playing is very similar. You even get good references to gothic sometimes throughout the game. Scavengers are in the game and there's a guy called Moe asking for money in front of the tavern :D and those are just a few of them.)+ Did a quest for a parrot, got 2200 gold and new armor! (10/10)Unfortunately there are a few things that just aren't that good...I love the game but in order to make this an honest game review I gotta put the negatives here too.- Voice acting is a mixed bag (For me it was fine but other players will think it's horrible)- Armor is really scarce throughout the game, you'll get your faction armor when you join one of them but that's about it. (It was pretty much the same in the gothic games though)- The game has frame rate issues- Enemy AI is horrible sometimes- ocasional pop in throughout the entire game- Some graphical glitches here and there- Clothes of npc's don't look that great sometimes (clipping)- Combat is challenging in the gothic kind of way, in the beginning you'll have to run away from enemies sometimes. If you wander off and go to deep in some parts of the islands you'll encounter monsters that are way to strong for you. Levelling is slow at first but once you're strong the game is a lot of fun. Gothic was the same and if someone says it isn't they're lying. I've finished Gothic 1 and 2 for like 3 times so I know how the games are. I don't have a problem with this but others will, thats why I said at the beginning that this isn't for casual players.Overall the game was and still is a lot of fun for me, I'll probably keep playing it for a while like I did with Risen 2. But players that aren't used to this kind of gameplay wont enjoy it as much as I did. I'm sure of that, so my advice to those people would be to play Gothic 2 or try out Risen 2. If you get annoyed as hell and hate the levelling and the overall gameplay of those 2 this isn't the game for you. It doesn't do anything new or inovative, it's made for the fans of those 2 franchises (Gothic & Risen)I give this game an 8/10Update: Just started a new game to see if things are different when you join another faction and they are. I joined the Guardians and I have a different ship and some unique faction quests as well!. I highly recommend players to try the game out a 2nd or even 3rd time to see the changes for themselves. I know I gave this game an 8/10 but there's just so many good things that i'm seeing that I'm very tempted to raise it to 9 :D

												Once again a traditional Piranha Bytes title with all its flaws, rough around the edges, feels unfinished sometimes, very very bad beginning and end, almost only tedious fetch/kill quests, ancient facial animations and many more. I hate almost all new mechanics like the sea fights and especially the whole underworld/ghost parts. Just finished the game in about 40h and already forgot most of the weak story.The different factions you can join almost make no difference as you will travel around a game world that is 90% accessible right after the prologue and you will do almost all quests of all the factions anyway. Balancing is abysmal, I would say even worse than the early Gothic 3. The game starts extremely hard, you will probably die most of your deaths in the forst 5 hours. At some point when you master the combat mechanics, got some decent equipment and learned nice skills, the gameplay is actually pretty good. Sadly, it wears off after only a few hours. Most combats are the same, you will probably take the same companion with you 95% of the time and the only interesting situations will arise from glitches. The second half of the game will be one long grind towards completing most quests, looting and killing everything there is, because skilling and learning the important stuff from trainers gets extremely expensive.You will not see a single new creature/enemy in the second half of the game. But you will have to suffer through the worst boss fights in the history of all PB games, which is ridiculous, because they somehow built up a reputation for having the worst end fights with Risen 1 & 2 already. I could go on ranting about many other things, some of which were certainly designed by the Devs on purpose because they are sadists and we the fans are certainly a bit masochistic in return. Nevertheless, once again it is somehow a good game in many aspects as well. For me mostly because the world that has been created is amongst the most atmospheric and credible game worlds I ever experienced. The factions are interesting, the islands are astonishing, the level design with the incredible attention to detail is still one of a kind. The music is beautiful and the voice actors are solid, with a few brilliant exceptions. While many of the main characters are boring and bland, a few save the day, for me these are the gnomes and bones. I'm happy that I decided to give the game a few second chances when I felt like quitting and after all finished the game.My only regret is that I wasted a lot of time collectiong stuff I never needed. TLDR:If you liked any other Piranha Bytes Game, get Risen 3, it is better than Risen 2 and the most impressive in regards to the game world. If you are new and curious about this rough little gem, get it in a sale and read some beginners guides.

												Many reviewers judged Risen 3 to be generic which I don't feel is quite fair. The fantasy Caribbean setting and use of early firearms are rarely seen in rpgs as are open world games that are free of level scaling. Risen 3 is a game where you can find a difficulty 90 lock early on and a diff 10 in the "late game". Of course early and late game are almost completely dependent on where you choose to go and when.Exploration is a strong point of the game and you're always bound to find something useful or something funny at least, whether it's a new weapon, treasure chest, schematic or just two skeletons with apples on their heads and a bunch of throwing daggers stuck in their rib cages. Unlike in many rpgs gold is useful in Risen 3 and you always need more of it. Even if you accumulate large amounts by the end there's some powerful weapons that you can buy in the end game that will deplete your reserve. Conversations with NPC can sometimes feel long winded and slow but the writing also has a unique kind of derpy charm and the humor can be pretty good if a little awkward. Though the ending did feel very anti-climatic I must say, not that it matters much.English voice acting's pretty good but the main protagonist sounded very cheesy to me. Overall both the protagonist and Patty looked/sounded a lot better in Risen 2 I think. The main character in R3 is simply generic and bland both in terms of his voice and appearance while Patty was made sluttier for no good reason. Patty was already good looking in Risen 2 but she also had more character and sass appearance wise imo. Guns and magic make combat quite easy, healing items are overplentiful imo and some of the skills (like distilling for example) are almost useless but ultimately I found the combat and overall gameplay quite fun and that's what matters in the end. It's a shame that some Risen 2 combat elements were removed. Things like salt/sand, the parrot pet, the kick skill but magic and "power gloves" were added so it's not a net loss.Like all the Risen games Risen 3 is a bit rough around the edges but there's plenty of fun to be had and the 3 factions even give it a decent amount of replayability.

												I'm not new to Gothic/Risen series. It's reception was fairly mixed with a small dedicated fanbase. Most criticism came from  lack of polish, overal clunkines and no clear gameplay guidelines. Risen 3 is no different. Although it's far from original Gothic's awkwardness, the core of the game mechanics is the same. Much of the blame was put on difficulty scaling. You're free to go anywhere you like, be it danger seeping cave that's to be tackled by powerful character or trivial fights with monsters as challanging as shooting shotgun at chickens with nunchucks. Risen 3 hints what needs to be done but it doesn't hold your hand throghuout the game.Risen's 3 contuinues it's precedessor carribean setting which is quite unusual, yet eye-catching. Piratey theme is dominant in this RPG. Being so colorful as Risen 3 is, some RPG gamers may be a bit of put off. What needs to be said, is that plot and characters are less than exciting and unique but not subpar - just the usual fantasy RPG mambo-jumbo plus ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ish protagonist.What shines in third Risen installment are numerous quests, items and skills. The latter, though not balanced perfectly, provide variety in gameplay. Many assignments are clones of each other but somehow it manages to be satysfing. At least for a bit more than half of the playthrough it's challenging and gaining experience either by killing monsters or completing quests is satisfying. By the end I was far too powerful to have any kind of challange but getting there was a pleasure and that's the strong point of this title.In conclusion, Risen 3 is surprisingly a somewhat solid RPG. Lurking in shadows of AAA titles, it's mostly overlooked. That's a shame because even with it's shortcomings I honestly enjoyed Risen 3. If it's on a sale, just try it. Just don't expect much in story compartment.Final score : 7/10The good :- Attractive graphics- Lots of quests, items and skills- Freedom to choose your own path and game styleThe bad :- Pirate setting may be not appealing for many RPG fans- Some of the Gothic's clunkiness is still there- Story and characters are ok. Just ok.

On the down side this is the easiest in the series so far. The strong challenge and lack of world-levelling - where the enemies get more powerful as you progress - was my favorite thing about the earlier games. It makes things VERY satisfying when you get that new spell or item and finally crack a previously almost invincible enemy. I blame those negative reviewers who haven't really understood the earlier Risen games for the dramatic drop in difficulty here..It's very much a marmite game - you will love it or hate it.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Risen 3 is a third person open world action roleplaying game made by Piranha Bytes, the team that gave us the Gothic games and of course the first two Risen games. It's hard to talk about Risen 3 without referring to the previous games, which I'll call 'PB games' for short.To summarize: Risen 3 is definitely a step up from Risen 2 but all in all, it is probably still a game that only fans of PB games will love and a game that only fans of the genre may learn to like.To talk about this game more in-depth, I'll take the list I used for my reviews of 'Risen' and 'Risen 2'.Melee combatThe melee combat in Risen 2 was bad, very bad. The melee combat in Risen 3 is a lot better. It would certainly not win any prizes for the most exciting combat in a RPG ever, but after the fiasco of Risen 2 it feels like a huge improvement. The melee combat in Risen 3 is a lot like it was in the first Witcher game. Your character can perform a combo of moves and all you need to do is click the mouse at the right time to make sure the combo is performed correctly. If you click at the wrong time, the combo will be interrupted by the opponent or you will at least notice a decrease in your effectiveness (lower attack speed and damage dealt).The secondary weapons are back: you can use a pistol, a crossbow or throwing daggers. But since melee combat relies on performing a series of successive attacks (combo), you will hardly ever use a secondary weapon because that interrupts the combo flow. Ranged combatThe ranged combat in Risen 3 is about the same as it was in Risen 2. Muskets and shotguns are back, they work about the same as in Risen 2 and they are about as powerful as they were in Risen 2. But because of the improved melee combat and the return of magic, ranged combat isn't the only viable build anymore like it was in Risen 2.MagicMagic is back after being pretty much absent in Risen 2. Each of the three factions have their own type of magic (rune magic, crystal magic or voodoo magic). I can't really comment further on how a mage build would function in Risen 3 as I went with melee/ranged. Learning curve for your characterLike in all PB games, there isn't just a learning curve for the player but for the character, too. He needs to learn to fight better. As the game progresses and you improve your character's skills, you actually feel your character getting better. This curve is not very steep in Risen 3, making it by far the easiest PB game so far. For the sake of Steam Achievements, I only improved my stats and skills a bit and then started saving 'glory points' (what XP is called in this game) to be able to max out each stat one by one (there is an achievement for getting each stat to 100). This means that I went through the better part of the game with only minimal stats and skills, and the game still felt too easy. You can up the difficulty in the game settings, but that only makes the monsters hit harder, which isn't really an issue when the problem is that most monsters don't hit you at all. You could artificially increase the difficulty in two ways, though: go solo, so don't take an npc companion with you: I should have done this earlier but the first few hours you need a companion so you get used to it. Also, there are companions that are part of the factions that live on the main islands and they have a personal quest there, so you miss out on some stuff if you go solo. But it was only after I started to go questing without a companion that I felt challenged in this game. don't use dodge: dodging is overpowered. It has no cooldown and opponents can't interrupt your dodging, so you're actually invincible while dodging. Combined with a companion who will take aggro while you're dodging, this can make the game way too easy.FactionsFactions are back, after being more or less absent in Risen 2. They aren't as different or game defining as they were in the Gothic games, but at least they feel like real factions and they come with their own armor sets, like in the good old days ;-)TrainersThe character development system is very close to the one Risen 2 had, with some minor but welcome changes. You still increase stats with 'glory' (XP) and you still learn or increase skills by finding and paying a trainer who can teach you. It would go too far to describe all the skills and all the stats and their impact on the skills in this review, but I must say that I found the overall character development system in Risen 3 a bit better than in Risen 2.Great atmosphereThe settings, the NPCs, the towns, the music, the humour, ... everything adds to a distinct atmosphere that only PB can create. Although the 'slightly dumbing down' of Risen 2 & 3 compared to earlier PB games is still noticeable, there is a slight improvement compared to Risen 2. NPCs will react to your actions (e.g. stealing in plain sight) a bit more often and a bit more logically than they did in Risen 2, but it's still far from the first four PB games.Something that reminds me of Gothic 2, is that a part of the world of Risen 3 is 'recycled content' from the previous game. Some people find this incredibly lazy. While I see their point, I personally like the vaguely familiar settings. Those islands look different enough from the previous game to be a largely new experience, but you have a feeling of “Hey, here used to be...” and a curiosity of “I wonder if ... is still there”.There are a ton of references to the Gothic games in Risen 3. For starters, some creatures from the Gothic series are back: scavengers, swamp golems, snappers and dragon snappers. There are also a few encounters and easter eggs referring to earlier PB games. For example, you'll come across an annoying fellow called Mud who follows you around and won't shut up (same as in Gothic 1), you'll meet the nameless hero you played in the first two Risen games and you'll see a lot of dead people again like Steelbeard and inquisitor Mendoza. ElexI'm extatic to read that PB is making a new game and that they know they need to improve on a lot of things in Risen 2 & 3. If you're curious, I suggest you read the Q&A thread on the official Elex forum. The replies from PB there are extremely promising. There is also a Steam placeholder product page to be found here: Some notes about the Steam AchievementsThe achievements aren't bugged like they were for Risen 2. If you want to get all the achievements, you will either need three playthroughs or plan a bit. That means: join each faction (save, join, reload) before joining one for good. if you aren't going to join the Demonhunters faction for good: when you join them briefly to get the achievement for that, also do the quest 'A new rank' for Drake before reloading. This quest is Demonhunters only and as a part of that quest, you need to complete another quest called 'Zak's temptation' on Antigua, which has an achievement of its own. gather enough glory points to max your lowest stat and then max each stat one by one (save, max a stat, reload, max next stat, reload, etc.) before allocating your glory points where you want them for your build. start playing the game as a good guy to get the achievement for getting your soul rating over 90 (I'd save at 80 or so, then give all soul dust to Edward to get soul rating above 90, then reload), then start playing as a complete prick to get soul below 10 for another achievement.

Posted: August 12, 2014
												Full Video Review here - 


YouTube™ Video: Risen 3 Titan Lords Review 

			Views: 11,108		

			Cosmic reviews Risen 3 Titan Lords for PC developed by Piranha bites and published by Deep Silver. Enjoy this Risen 3 review? leave a comment!		

Hello once again I'm Cosmic and welcome to the latest addition to the Risen franchise, Risen 3 Titan Lords. Risen 3 was developed by German developer Piranha bites who are well known for their previous titles including the Gothic franchise as well as the previous two Risen titles. Published by Deep Silver, Risen 3 was touted to be a throwback to the first Risen title by once again boasting more open world and exploration based game play.Risen 3 takes a break from the unnamed hero of the first two games. Instead you start the game as the son of the famous pirate Captain Steelbeard thus being brother to Patty a familiar face from the last two games who also features once again in this instalment. Searching for treasure on the mysterious crab coast you soon come across a skull cave that has 'Risen' from the ground, get it? Within the cave itself a skull lord appears and steals the soul of the pirate who seemingly dies. Upon regaining is life thanks too a strange shaman doctor known as Bones, another typical cheesy risen joke. The pirate begins a quest around the southern isles to reclaim his soul and ultimately stop this new threat.Moving away from the more linear and heavily pirate themed second instalment. Risen 3 has gone back to the multi-factional open world style of the first. In Risen 3 you are able to travel throughout the southern isles to visit and explore islands such as Antigua, Taranis,Calador and other familiar places from the previous games. One thing I do really like so far is that exploration really does reap rewards as you can find loot, quests and secret areas in a variety of ways. One new gameplay feature in particular is the ability to swim, while it sounds a little silly it actually becomes a great exploration tool as you can swim offshore to discover secret islands full of loot.One of the positive traits about Risen 3 in terms of travel is in its free-form design. You can just head off in a direction and explore, with the only thing stopping you in your tracks being enemies that you are not ready for. Once you finish the starting section you can go to any island that is available to you at that time. You don't have to do the islands in a specific sequence which adds replay ability particularly when you take the factions into account. While on an Island you can travel on foot or fast travel to the various portals once activated. One useful mode of transport is a magic spell that transforms you into a flying parrot, while you cant stay in this mode for long its great if you've just travelled up a mountain and want a quick route down. It's especially useful for those of us with kleptomania as the parrot flight allows you to fly into locations otherwise inaccessible by foot.The games combat has always been notoriously difficult throughout the series. One click attacking combined with clunky movement can become very tedious and outright frustrating. The start of the game is particularly tedious as your character has next to know abilities other than basic attacks and basic melee blocking. It can end up meaning that those who like to play on the harder difficulty settings will spend hours upon frustrated hours dying against relatively minor enemies especially in group situations. As you progress in the game, improving your stats and acquiring new abilities from trainers, combat becomes a hell of a lot easier. The combat system overall is massively improved from Risen 2 however it still suffers from fundamental flaws that have plagued the series since conception. Clunky movement, issues with focusing on enemies and of course pistol shots missing from point blank range are all back once again.The major redeeming feature about combat this time round is the return of crystal magic. The developers took out magic in Risen 2 something which was largely complained about upon its release. Thankfully magic is back in force this time and I would argue it is the best way to deal with the majority of enemies as not only does it pack a hell of a punch but its the less frustrating option for group encounters. Luckily which ever faction you decide to join, all offer various forms of magical abilities so no matter how you build your character you will have some form of magic to fall back on.Those familiar with the previous titles won't find much different when it comes to character progression. To improve your characters array of stats you must accumulate glory points. Glory is earned for the completion of quests as well as killing enemies. On top of this to improve particular stats and gain new abilities you must find trainers which are dotted throughout the world. However to learn from trainers costs gold and depending on what you are trying to learn you must be prepared to part with a substantial amount. There are also special items hidden throughout the world which you can recover which add a permanent boost to stats these can be gain via exploration or through reading books to acquire the specific quests.While character progression is solid, I've never liked the way the developers have insisted on putting trainers in the game. The main reason behind this is because you really need the abilities they offer and having to pay gold for them, especially early on when large amounts of gold is not easy to come by is a massive frustration. One thing annoys me even further is particularly when it comes to the sword fighting if your a melee focused character. The ability to riposte is essential against some tougher enemies and a life saver in group encounters. Yet even though your playing as a pirate captain you don't have this ability from the start. You must go to find a trainer and then pay gold to get it which is ridiculous.  As I've mentioned there are factions in the game to which you can join one. The three factions include the mages, demon hunters and a voodoo tribe. Each faction offers an array of faction specific abilities and quests. Once you join a faction your able to then gain better ranks within that faction which unlocks better gear, quests and abilities. However once you join a faction you cannot join another so choose carefully. Thanks to the freedom that the game allows you can travel and complete the majority of quests on each factions island before making your decision of which to join. I ended up join the mages faction known as the guardians, one for the magical abilities and two for the cool eye piece.Graphically the game is good but not great. On the PC specifically I would have liked to see a lot higher texture resolutions as much of it looks very last generation console. The world however does look good and immersive. There are some glitches and bugs to be found throughout but these tend to be minor. Sadly once again Risen 3 follows suit in the terrible lip syncing animations as well as poor facial animations as a whole. Similar to the previous games the voice acting and scripting is full of off colour humour and outright cheese. Some of the voice acting isn't terrible but some is just cringe worthily bad.Overall those familiar with the Risen and Gothic series will be right at home with Risen 3. Any avid RPG player will be able to sink their teeth into Risen 3 and find a good amount of enjoyment from it. However I wonder if many people will not be able to get past the difficulty of the combat at the start, it does require a certain amount of perseverance that I think will send more casual players running for the hills. Risen 3 is certainly a large improvement on the second and there’s a good degree of enjoyable content in the game. At the end of the day, if you enjoy a decent RPG then Risen 3 will be for you however those looking for a more streamlined RPG experience may wish to look to more mainstream titles.

												To start with, I finished "Risen 3" 5 days ago. So with its completion, I have done with the series, at least for now. I think I can say without hesitation that Piranha Bytes did a marvelous job there with Risen series. In regards to Risen 3, I have read a lot of reviews and comments that says the game is just more of the same of its predecessors and I kinda agree on that. However, I think it is a good thing that R3 got the best of these two worlds.As an RPG gamer, what impressed me in R1, is the faction system which utterly failed in R2 because your faction was shaping your play style and it was limiting the player to a certain role. Now these factions in R2 plays a role in R3 but for instance, if you want to be an inquisitor, now you can't but there is a whole bunch of quest for them, too and even if you are submitted to another faction which also can heavily consists of magic usage, you can develop you character in both magic skills and/or other gun/musket skills.  Also faction system makes replayability of the game skyrocket, just like it did in R1 and R2; you can revisit the game and play a different storyline with a different faction.Story-wise, it is on par with 2 previous games; although, for me, first one is still the best. It goes without saying, it was also heart-warming to see the characters from previous games; heck, you can even meet with the antagonist of the second game(playerchar) and clink some booze with him; even though it plays a small role it is very nice addition and I really appreciate the developers for giving us, players, tangible lines to merge previous games to the newest and latest title.As for the map, it shares the same location with 2nd game's. I am not sure but maybe, 1 or 2 island were added. So if you played the 2nd game, it's not a big surprise to say  yourself "I think I know this place but from where?". One can say it is a disadvantage or a proof that developers didn't work as hard as they worked for the 2nd game but I found it really satisfying. Because instead of spending time on recreating a new world, they spend the time on enriching the story and quests, giving us a better game in terms of story content from the other previous titles. The story length is quite satisfying in comparison to today's standard; just to give an example, my play-through took around 45 hours.So what I don't like about R3 is, still the same since the beginning of these series. Item-wise, you are still searching for the strongest weapon in regards to your level, not really thinking of any other option because there is no real option there. Second, Lockpicking and Persuasion skills are all needed but for one tenth of whole cases, really. In nine tenth of cases treasure loots or things we steal are totally garbage. So there is not much negativity for me in this game; even they integrate a teleporter system. In the previous titles, it was becoming tiresome to walk over all the island just for 1 quest item. So I think I can safely recommend Risen 3 to rpg lovers and also, with its friendly UI, even to the newcomers from other genres.
