												This "review" may be very stream of consciousness.See, I don't think I'd call the Risen series a good game series, save maybe the first game. Well, that's probably a bit unfair. They are good in a variety of ways, just not the traditional ways most games are. The combat just kinda stinks in these games. There's no real way around it. Again, Risen had this issue too but was far lighter on combat than either of the sequels, at least for the majority of the game. It's incredibly basic and spammy, and there's far too much of it.So why am I so compelled by this series? I think one of the things Piranha Bytes does well, is exploration. There's always nooks and crannies to explore and side quests to find. These random adventures with the sidequests are among Risen 3's strengths, are often very funny. Risen 3 lets you have almost unfettered access to the game's world once you complete the tutorial area. There's about 20 percent of the game walled off for story purposes, but other than that, you can really just do what you want. You'll have a few major goals, but they are so out of reach that often just following your wandering heart is the best course of action. You'll probably find your way into the main story eventually by sheer accident. There's a spell that turns you into a parrot that you can useThat brings me to the story. In order to account for that free form exploration, it's pretty basic. You are the son of a legendary pirate (and brother to series mainstay Patty) who gets his soul stolen by someone in the underworld, but you've managed to retain your human body. So you'll need to set out and find your soul, and in the course of doing so basically solve everyone's problems along the way. Now, the series has never had a strong story. For some reason you're a new character, despite that this new guy kinda looks like the old guy, and he's sort of a similar character (the previous hero is probably a bit more polite). So it's kinda weird that you're a new guy that's not very different from the old guy. Like you can actually read reviews for the game and people are actually confused about it, thinking it's the same character. Well, anyway, it's even weirder because like, the game is pretty heavily invested in Risen 2's story. You recruit 3 of the party members from the 2nd game. So, anyway, just a bit weird that they made this new character that's barely different and have him interact with everyone anyway. I'd get it if they were like "we don't want to reset the hero again," but they kinda do it to you anyway at the start. Just sort of a strange decision.Speaking of things back from Risen 2, the game heavily reuses some of the areas. Most of them are vastly expanded or changed, but still felt a bit like a retread at times. There are a variety of quality of life improvements, like a fast travel system similar to something in an Ubisoft game. The game has the most ridiculously in depth quest tracking system, so if you're lost you just need to use your log and put "show map marker" so if you're not in the mood to explore, you have that option. Crafting's a bit easier now too. There's more trainers, and most trainers train multiple skills so you likely won't have to worry too much about not having access to someone to train you. Trainers and merchants are all marked on the map after you find them once.The levelling system is largely the same but has been reorganized, and not really for the better. For instance, melee skill increases your skill in all three weapon types, so there's not much specializing. Similarly there's like a Silver Tongue (charm) and Intimidate dialogue option often, and these skills are on the same stat too. Most games would force you to pick, be a charmer or be a brute, perhaps tying them to related stats. So it's a little boring that way.Anyways, game starts off hard, like the others. You'll need to choose a magic faction for story purposes (and also, c'mon, free magic). This magic makes the game substantially easier, at least for the faction I chose, which favors direct damage. To be honest, and I find myself saying this with complete surprise, but I'd advise people to take a melee path. The combat does ever get good but there's some fun to be had once you get the parry ability. The basic magic attacks act sort of like weapon attacks, so you can't really use them with swords. So eventually when I got bored of how easy the magic was making the game I invested in melee and only use the cooldown abilities. Combining sword, a magic attack, and then a pistol shot while dancing around enemies could actually be fun at times. Random gripe but, hey, PB, you're a PC developer. Don't give me 30 moves and make them all need to be on the 10 hotkeys. Give me a scrolling hotkey bar or something. That's something to be said about this game over Risen 2 is that you have a lot more stuff to use, and it gives you it often. Even the magic of the other factions can be used via consumable items, so it really adds to the value of exploring. In R2 it seemed pretty rare to find anything too useful outside of a sword upgrade here and there.The game does a good job of feeling "alive." It has a small cast of characters but this allows them to do NPC scheduling. I liked that as you clear objectives like taking back a mine overrun by undead, the miners that were displaced by the undead will go back to work. That sort of stuff. Small touches a lot of games would ignore.Voice acting is weird. The PC sounds like someone's trying to do a Bale Batman voice via Aaron Paul, and I really hated him at the start. I got used to him though, mainly because his deadpan delivery really works well given the odd stories he gets himself involved in. Most of the party members are good, and I rather love Bones' voice actor. Very strange performance in both games. Graphically it's not going to stun much but most enviroments are well done, and it seems to be far more technically sounds than Risen 2. Fairly certain I had better performance in Risen 3 than R2 on the same hardware.Anyways, I preordered it so, a quick review of the DLC, in case you ever get the game. The Gnomes isle one is kind of bland. About 2 hours. Not much to do there, honestly, and it feels rather disconnected. One of the big appeals of the game to me was sailing into a port, finding treasure maps and quests that take me to a different island, and just bouncing around. The DLC, by nature, can't be involved in this, so it loses that. The second major DLC is the Fog Island one. This one I like better. It's more involved in the main story, and has some decent atmosphere. Also had some good treasure to be found, while the other one didn't. Still suffers from being disconnected. Both are about 2 hours each, which isn't too bad for 5 bucks, but I'd probably wait for at least a small discount.Writing this all out sounds negative, and it kinda is, but as much as I have issues with some of it, I enjoyed my overall time. I think PB are really good at creating areas to explore. The aren't too big, not too small, and there's always something around the corner, and they give you. I just hope, now that they have the rights to Gothic back again, that we see them address the combat in the future. I don't need much when it comes to action RPGs, but something's gotta give. Even something as simple as making combat rarer.Alright, ramble done. I don't think I can recommend it outright. Have a tolerance for Eurojank, and like pirates, humor, and good exploration? Probably worth getting. Liked Risen 2? Get it for sure. Hated Risen 2? Ehh, it's an improvement but not leaps and bounds. Wait for a sale.Final clocked in time is 45 hours, for those that care about game time. Minus the DLC and a few deaths / idle moments I'd say most people will get 35-40 hours out of it.

												The first few hours of Risen 3 feels similar to its predecessor, with slightly dated graphics and a shortage of polish. However, patience is a virtue, and as you progress, a fun and addicting longing for adventure prevails. Piranha Bytes is known for its imagination in the genre of RPGs, and Risen 3 is yet another fine example. This game is full of charms, and will keep you entertained for many hours. The voice acting is good, quests feel authentic and give you a sense of importance, and the overall objectives are virtually always clear. There is room for improvement in graphics and final polishing, but I'd give Risen 3 a solid 8 out of 10. It doesn't quite rival the brilliance of Skyrim, but for RPG fans, it's still a no brainer.

												I think that the decision whether or not to recommend this game was quite a close one for me because while the game does have allot going against it on paper it was still fun to play I just think that it got held back because unfortunately no one area of the game stood out as having been particularly well executed throughout.On the one hand the levels are quite well done and there is allot to do in the game, plus you have a wide variety of choices when deciding on how to build your character so you don’t have to decide what play style you want to employ up front. There are also a wide variety of side quests to pursue which provide quite a few hours of entertainment. The crew of your ship which you will build up over time are interesting as they will make comments as you travel with them, some of which are fairly amusing. Another thing that I liked was the skill system, to many games have long complex skill trees that don’t feel like they contribute to much more than the player stats. In risen 3 you can learn any skill you want and allot of the spells are interesting to play with, from being able to blink around the field to turning yourself into a parrot to more aggressive combat spells there is allot to play and experiment with. While I know that some people have had stability issues I’ve yet to crash once and fps drops are small and few so I personally think that the game is fairly stable. On the other hand this game does disappoint particularly as you progress, this is due to your character becoming overpowered and there being no real counter balance making combat a chore as the enemies don’t become notably stronger or varied also meaning that there is little incentive to mix things up. Another damming issue is that you don’t have to get too far into the game to have seen every enemy except the bosses. Graphics were another issue, while the environment may be appealing the rest is fairly sub-standard and broken graphics and clipping are a common issue. It’s also fairly easy to glitch a quest with issues ranging from broken markers through to the quest being impossible to finish effectively breaking the game forcing you to either load an earlier save or start a new game. while the game does have some replay value from joining different factions and completing different quests it could do with some incentive to start a new game such as unlocking (significantly) harder difficulties or additional content. I think that the straw that broke the horses back though was the highly anti-climactic endgame. The last few quests and the final cut scene were extremely disappointing because allot of what you had done to that point seemed to fizzle out leaving you asking the question “what, is that it! What the (inset preferred term to express outrage)!”pros:.interesting environment.the story was great up until the last chapter.fully voiced (though it’s kind of expected in this sort of game these days).interesting characters not the best ever but still ok.stablecons:.not challenging after a point + various balancing issues.anti-climactic ending and no closer.can bug out on you either quest markers or in a breaking way.poor graphicsIn conclusion I felt that while the game was fun to play it doesn’t feel finished and while I can accept that not all games are going to be polished to a mirror shine they need to pick up the slack in some regard whether that be through the story or the gameplay mechanics and risen 3 ultimately just didn’t do that.

												Firstly, although my game time says 4 hours, my save file says 6. 6 hours of gameplay might not be enough to properly review this game, it seems to be improving, but is all the time I am willing spend here for now. I bought this game based on the various reviews here swearing that the game will get better, but honestly, who wants to go through 5 or 6 hours of gameplay before having fun?The combat is clunky. The attacks are not responsive, the characters go through pirouettes, leaps and lunges to deliver a single blow. At the beginning of the game the delay between the strikes in your 3-hit combo are long enough to allow the enemy to interrupt you every single time. You will be reduced to using the same hit and roll tactic for next 3 hours, whittling away at the enemy's health while your companion does most of the heavy lifting... Unless the companion AI suddenly decides to stop attacking or has gotten stuck somewhere, in that case whittle away. On the other hand, as you progress you acquire new types of weapons and skills that really add up to the combat. It can still be frustrating, but after 5 hours or so (your mileage might vary depending on the places you visit first and how you develop your character) you start to see where the combat is trying to go. I do not if it eventually gets there, I will update this review when I revisit the game.This might be surprising, but the combat isn't what finally pushed me away from the game. It is the conversation that did it for me, and that is quite sad because they went through the effort of voicing pretty much everything. The problem is that the conversations meander so much, there are so many exchanges in one conversation branch that hold no value, they don't develop the characters, they don't introduce lore, nor do they mimic normal conversation. It is really, baffling how much extra effort went where it needed to. I understand that a complaint for the previous game was the lack of voiced acting or how little voice acting there was, I am not too sure about this, but regardless, there is just too much useless and pointless dialogue in this game, but I might have been able to take if it wasn't for the horrible voice acting.  That's right, there is awkward writing being voiced very badly. This is the first time that this has affected my gameplay so much that I have stopped playing. All that said, the game has the potential to improve plenty, perhaps by the 15th hour everything else would be sufficiently enjoyable that you can look past the scrip and voice acting, but if that is the case, it would be better to wait for this game to go on sale, currently it isn't worth the asking price.

Posted: January 8
												I really, REALLY wanted to like this game. Hell, it was a new Piranha Bytes release, and I LOVE these devs. However, I'm not sure what's going on with them after seeing this. Sadly, I would have taken more consideration into pre-ordering it had I known what Risen 2 ended up being, as PB in my opinion has had a relatively solid track record with their games, with titles that were at least good enough for me to pitch in and support them, and that's saying something in most cases.I've been a Piranha Bytes fan to the core when it comes to their RPGs since I had the manual dexterity to use a keyboard, and Gothic was actually my first RPG experience. Even to this day, I have a hard time finding games in the RPG sector that manage to captivate me as much as G1 and G2 did.However, this isn't a Gothic 1 or Gothic 2 review. This is a Risen 3 review, so let's get on with it.What really ruined it for me:The Combat-   -   -   -   -   -This was the first thing I noticed when I began playing the game, and I have to say PB fell flat on their face with this one. First and foremost, the main character has about as much ability in using a sword as a dead cat, and he's about as stalwart as one, too. His attacks have an atrocious wind up that make even the simplest combat situations into an ordeal of timing and hoping the enemies don't hit you first, which brings me to my next subject: Enemies have NO WIND UP to balance this out. Just about everything you encounter and fight in the game will attack you relentlessly and without any kind of delay, meaning that if you go in and swing at the enemy, they can just attack and interrupt you, doing damage and bringing you back to square one. Oh, and that's another thing. EVERYTHING, and I mean EVERYTHING stuns your character. Tiny♥♥♥♥♥beach insect thing? (I still have yet to understand those creatures.) Yeah, their tiny attack will stagger your character the same way you'd expect him to if he got clocked upside the head by Chuck Liddell.     As a whole, this results in an absolutely infuriating combat experience that was one of the main reasons I had to put the game down for good. It's completely unbearable, and frankly I've come to expect far more from these developers.Now, I know, I've seen it everywhere. People could say that Gothic's combat was just as awful, if not worse, but there's a key difference there: Gothic's combat is anything but horrible, for one. If anything, it's about all you should expect from an RPG from around the year 2000; on the other hand, this game from 2015 manages to have combat that, unlike Gothic, doesn't just take a bit of time to get a hang of, but instead is completely impossible to work with and that, in my opinion, makes the experience null and void. I even used cheats to increase my combat skill in hopes of making my character's attacks worthwhile, and even THIS did absolutely nothing whatsoever.In terms of major flaws, this really is the only one, and it manages to be so outstandingly, so GLORIOUSLY bad that the game is completely ruined by it.Now, the game has some things that I like about it, namely the fact that it really does feel like a Piranha Bytes game still. The dialogue, characters, world, and music all still make me feel like I'm playing a good old PB game, but once I get into a fight I simply can't force myself to get through the whole thing.Now, for an open recommendation for the developers and a closing statement:You clever ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s have given me gaming experiences throughout my entire life, and I absolutely adore you all for it. I've often burst out in laughter from the Hero's dialogue options and an NPC's response, as well as the numerous easter eggs and goodies you leave lying around. This, just as often as I've have slammed my fist down on my desk in frustration from the challenging and punishing, yet rewarding combat experience, but this game hardly managed to do any of that for me, as the whole thing was sadly cut short by its one fatal flaw.When I say this next bit, I want you guys to know (and this goes to other readers as well) that I'm not just putting on the nostalgia blinders; I just know a working formula when I see it.      Hypothetically, if you lot made another RPG, regardless of if it's Risen or something new entirely, and you used the same formula for G1 and G2 (here's where you could call me out on nostalgia blindness, if it weren't for the fact that an overwhelming number of your fans will show agreement) and adapted it for a modern market, using a newer engine with better graphics and the like, it would probably end up being another great installment; and, when I say 'formula' I'm talking about everything that made the first two Gothic games what they were, from the controls to the stats. Hell, you could make it on the old G2 engine and it'd probably still be great, but if there's one thing I'll admit, it's that the controls, while not inherently bad and not in need of outright change, could definitely use a tune up to make it feel a bit more fluid and responsive.At this point, I doubt anything in the paragraph above will happen, but I do sincerely believe it'd do the team a lot better than what they're going with as of now. Some things don't need to change, and it really does seem like the games started going downhill once the controls went through the big overhaul they did starting with Gothic 3, which changed the other two games' main control drawback of being somewhat stiff at times and generally feeling rather old-school to making the whole thing just feel outright clumsy. Risen 3 seems to have marked the apex of this clumsiness, and it's so atrocious that I couldn't even recommend this to my worst enemy.Hopefully this review shed some light for players on the fence about getting it and why I sincerely believe they should just go to GOG and buy one of the Gothic games instead. (It's probably obvious which two I recommend.) If you can be a proper human and adapt to the controls that are most definitely different from what most are accustomend to, you'll find what is an experience that is worlds better than what this title provides, and possibly one that you may find unforgettable.

												beautiful. just finished what i'm hoping is not the last pirahna bytes game. and even though i don't really write reviews and am new to steam i figured the newest edition to my favorite series deserves a shout out. i discovered risen 1 a couple years ago in a bargain bin and didnt expect much... just a no name company with what looked like a simplistic, guided rpg.... i was surprised at the little details put into it that i had never seen before and a friend told me about gothic.  my next was gothic 3 which to this day is my favorite game right up there with skyrim, fallout 3, kotor. their games seem to get a lot of flack, and i think that is mostly for the combat system... which i always thought was fine. no this isn't a world where you start off hacking through hoards of enemies seamlessly, if you want an action game... get an action game.if you want a role-playing experience where you are put into the shoes of a character and asked to build them and guide them through a process than all of their games are great(though don't get the steam version of gothic 2 one of the steam patches broke it and it stopped booting in the fifth chapter for me..... all my disc versions have been fine though)first off, all their games are 'deceptively' open world. meaning, you look at a mini map( in the later ones) and see roads and mountains and assume you are supposed to take those roads. one of the things i find so wonderful about their games is: yes, they offer a road.... but if you don't follow it they reward you.risen 3 doesn't have the greatest feeling of accomplishment and i think that may be do to making teleporting easier. teleportation stones used to be a big prize and this feels more similar to arcania.... too many stones means you aren't excited about it any more. though that could just be compared to gothic 3 which had the biggest moment of "score!" of any game i had ever played with finding all 6 druid stones when people online would all swear their were only 5 and the mentioning of the 6th was a bug. finding something that the internet hadn't found for years... that makes a game stick with you.this one didn't have as many of those moments, unlocking unlimited flying and the 'reach far away objects' hand were my biggest. but it still sticks true to its roots and gives a gaming experience that rewards exploration. and player control of the leveling process.this is easier than it's predecessors, but their games are all designed to be hard at the beginning and easy later on and i think that is brilliant. there is nothing more annoying than leveling up only to have enemies take longer to kill.... ok i don't play games for the repetitious hack and slash. i play for the character development and story... i'm one of those weirdos that reads all the game books and listens to what the characters say. i like games that let you ease in, explore cautiously, and then once you have been everywhere don't make you repeat things.i think the biggest annoyance in the game was the knife mini game, sometimes my knives would be sticking out of the board and i get no points -_- that and the one character that i got, started a quest with... then he leaves.other than those things, risen 3 like its predecessors is a game that gives what it gets. if you run through the trails, don't care about dialogue, and are only there to kill things than you will get a shallow action experience. take that extra time to climb that highest peak, to fly in between shadow minions, to read the items in your inventory. and you find a game that people put effort into. which is more than can be said for most of what comes out today.

												Risen 3 promises to bring back the best features from the previous titles in the series as well as features from the Gothic series. In the next installment of the Risen franchise, you are a new hero who must fight the oncoming Titan attack. The world is crumbling, island by island and you must build up a resistance to fight against the horde of Titans. Your soul has also been stolen and you must figure out how to regain it back, claiming it as yours as it once was.Risen 3 is quite an improvement from its predecessor: Risen 2 in all the right places. The animations, skills, exploration, and graphics have all been upgraded. One of the reasons the Risen series is not enjoyable for gamers is due to its frustrating combat. I can attest to being very frustrated with the combat in Risen 2. The combat in Risen 3 has not been improved very dramatically. The combat system is mostly the same except for a few tweaks. You will still get frustrated at one point or another, but continuing through the story definitely has its benefits.The animations during fighting battles have vastly improved, easily having the best animation work out of the Risen series to date. Skills also pour into the combat system more than ever. Yes, you still have to use money to purchase skills. Yes, you still have to use glory to purchase skills. But, the skills you learn in Risen 3 are more beneficial than any other skills in the Risen series. The skills provide players a somewhat easier time in each fight because they are learning extra skills that will help in combat, providing for quicker and more efficient kills.Where Risen 3 really shines is its exploration and its storyline. You are a new hero in the Risen universe who has his soul ripped out from a Titan Lord and must get it back. Simple premise, but its a little more complicated. When you wake up, a war between the Titans and humans is going on and your hero is caught in the middle of it. He is then sent to destroy Titan portals, to keep Titans from entering the world as well as forming an alliance between the remaining island factions to ensure humans are victorious. The storyline provides hundreds of quests that people can give you to do in exchange for money, items, or even glory. The quests can range anywhere from "Kill x Amount of Bloodhounds" to recovering stolen items. Factions and exploration are a few main features of Risen 3. You can join three factions: Demon Hunters, Voodoo Pirates, or the Guardians. Joining one over the other reaps different benefits than another. You may also only be able to learn skills if you are a specific faction, which may be of use to you later in the game. Going back to the islands from Risen 2 was refreshing but also disturbing when you see all the destruction that has been caused to the cities. Exploring the large amounts of caves also gave me a Skyrim feel, which I haven't felt for a while. It seems like every place matters to where its at and every place is different and distinct from another place. There is not a huge difference in graphics, but Piranha Bytes obviously took a lot of feedback from Risen 2 and improved some major bugs within the graphical system. The storyline provides anywhere from 10-50 hours of gameplay; depending on how many hours you spend on exploring and how many hours you spend on doing the wide variety of quests.Something came back to the Risen franchise. Magic. There is still Voodoo magic, but I'm talking about REAL magic. Such as magic from Risen 1. I loved magic in Risen 1 and I was really happy to see them bring it back for Risen 3. In Risen 3 it is done very well and one of my playthroughs I eventually just used magic because of how powerful it was. If you would like to become a wizard, join the Guardians faction, they are the faction that handles magic.Although, the game is better than previous titles in the series, it has its flaws. One, the combat system. It hasn't been revamped and you will still get frustrated from your "lack-of-skill". Although, unlike Risen 2, if you keep leveling up and buying more skills, you will begin to have the upperhand in combat; which was awesome to see and kept me going. Although there is a TON of exploration, you are visiting the same places as in Risen 2. I really would have liked to see another world, instead of the one from the previous title.(This is a shortened review for Steam. The full review will be up on my blog ready for anyone and a link will be provided. Happy gaming!)6.5/10

												I love Risen 3 in its current form. Through the 30 or more hours it’ll take you to complete the game, you’ll encounter so many locations, characters and situations that it takes far too much time to talk about in detail. Little things, like the two loonies with Anatidaephobia, or bouncer at the tavern on Calador who has the same name as the bouncer in Gothic 2. Risen 3 won’t do anything to win you over if you hated the previous instalments of the series. But then again, that really just means this series isn’t for you. Risen 3 is no huge leap forward, but instead focuses on small but considerable improvements and additions to the formula. It’s not perfect, and you might not feel there’s enough new for your liking, but for me it was just enough. I was never bored throughout my adventure, there was always something new to do, someplace new to discover. The seemingly small environments were teeming with enough life that it felt a lot bigger than it might look on a map. It might not be the proper sequel to Gothic 2 we’ve all been waiting for, but it does its job well enough for me to accept it into the collection.4/5Full review:http://www.pixeljudge.com/en/reviews/risen-3-titan-lords/

												I've played and finished Risen and Risen 2, and as a fan, I think that this game is even better then my spectations. In Risen 3 they brought back the elements most missed from the first game, in addition to the things that already had in the second game. 												Alright I do not usually do reviews as you can see, but I thought this game deserved one. First and foremost I am coming to love this game and I hated, absolutely hated the first and second game. I actually just gave both of them to my friend on the day I bought them. I am honestly unsure why I dis-liked the first game, something about it just pushed me away so severely I could not stand it.. That for me at least was fixed in this one.It is fun, I enjoy all the stories and quests and silly little things you can find, despite some bad voice acting at times I do actually like the voice acting and I love the things the main character says. All in all I love this game, but I have one gripe. Honestly the combat is really lacking, even if it is an improvement. No matter how good you seem to get with the combat, you are nearly guaranteed to get hit a couple times fighting a group of two (or three if you have a companion) and if you are fighting a group of three or up you will not avoid damage. That is just how it is. Combat does not allow you to get good enough to really protect yourelf while you deal damage. I found dodging to be more effective than blocking after a bit but still, it was just impossible to really avoid damage... Which really sucks to me because I liked to play games "perfectly" if you will. No mistakes and such. That doesn't matter in this game.But anyway, like I said I love this game, it is great, just don't expect to be to awesome in combat. You will be able to deal pretty heavy damage eventually though. 8/10 for me, only combat holds this game back in my eyes.

												First impressions....objectively balanced!I've only parted five hours of my life, to Risen: Titan Lords. With these three hours, I must confess. I'm sold! However, I will admit faults where they are due. I'll outline the good, the bad and the ugly.The Good1) Shiny enviroments to look at! Crystal clear water, and reflective water bring life to the world. Much improved over number 2 in the series.2) Combat mechanics, the skill system is similiar to Dark Waters. They've improved on the "wheel" so to speak. 3) UI layout, it's simplistic and opitmized. You wont feel, it's a waste of space. Since it barely takes away from the visual sights.4) The music, it's well done.5) Swaggity swag, more swag than you could possibly swag out to. The Bad1) Sounds and atmospheric immersion. Combat sounds are sub-par. The enviroment sounds, just seem off. I know, pervious incarnations have had these issues. Hopefully, patches/mods will fix it.2) LOS on enemies, so far mobs just seem to see you at a ridiculous range. Sneaking, definitely helps trim that. Movement can be awkward and disorienting at first. Just need to adjust.3) Lack of interface options for fullscreen mode. Game started out windowed, I had to ini file, fix it. Not a major deal, but easily fixable via placed in-game options. 4) Character identity confusion? Okay, minor spoiler...you're not the nameless hero from the other games. Yet, you're with Patty and the character is Steelbeards son. However, you're still nameless. I call him "Ted Dos Lagos" we get it Piranha Bytes, you don't name the "heroes". I'm sure, ya'll over there have some inside joke about it. It's from the Gothic days, and eventually the heroes name get's revealed. The Ugly1) Claw monkeys! 2) Facial expressions and animations. They just don't really have a quality feel, it's irky. The combat animations, aren't amazing. Yet, it could've been better. I know, the guys at Piranha Bytes, have it in them. 3) Lesser polished look on model textures and meshes for bodies They took a step backwards, this go around. Dark Waters, had really nice textures and meshes. I will admit, the armor looks pretty dope, which helps overlook the body. 4) Dead Veggies, you'll spot dead vegetation on living healthy plants here and there...it's weird to see. I know it adds immersion, it just looks off. Minor gripe of mine.5) The dialogue, lots of sarcastic remarks. Lots of profanity for profanity sake. Sailors, like doing that. The voice acting is ugly, but it's not terrible. 7.5/10Overall, based on my first impressions. It's solid follow-up to Dark Waters. It needs some patching, needs some shiny boot polish, needs a bath. However, it's Risen the only successor to Gothic. You get, what you pay for. If you're a true zealot of the old Gothic series, whom are rare. Give the Risen franchise some more thought and maybe even you can help improve it. I will say, we'll never have another Gothic II. I'm okay with that too. I genuinely feel, the guys/gals at Piranha Bytes, have the best intentions at heart for their products.Edit: I'm just going to add, if you do still enjoy Gothic II, in all of it's fantastic glory. There are a few mods out there. The community is dim and with little life, I know World of Gothic closed their doors. Folks, are out there though. Just need to try and find them.

												Great game. I Loved Risen and Risen 2 before this. the aliasing was a bit disappointing when first started up, but using Nvidia's 4K DSR makes the graphics very good indeed - and I'm a stickler for good visuals. Risen is a feel good RPG with great (although remade at times from Risen 2) locations, quests and characters along the way, each having a distict personality. The Combat, for me, is great, not clunky at all, very simple but the amount of weapons and options you have for defeating foes is plentiful. Do you really want to have a long, drawn out fight with one of the hundred Scavengers in the game, or just get it out of the way quickly and move around and explore, loot chests and complete quests? For me RPG's like Risen 3 (and the first two) are built for exploring, not getting into 5 minute fights at every turn.The DLCs are worth getting too, adds hours of extra gameplay and great bonus items, more great quest storylines too! Sad to have completed it! Though maybe I'll find the time to get some replay value by playing as another faction... For me, an easy 8/10 all things considered.  Personally, a 9/10 - playing games is about enjoyment, right?

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												(The game took me 35-40 hours to complete, Steam failed to record some of them, so the displayed amount is missing at least 8 hours) If you know Piranha Bytes and their history, you know what you're getting yourself into: A unique and memorable adventure with quirks both major and minor. Virtually everyone would like to see another proper Gothic game, but PB is keeping in mind what the market lacks at any given time and what the publisher may be willing to shell out money for. Back in 2012, it made sense for them to try out a different setting for Risen 2. After all, it had to compete with the likes of Skyrim, and a small studio such as PB has to pick its battles. Risen 2 was a sequel developed from scratch (content-wise) – no easy task, I imagine. They probably could not afford to ditch it all again for Risen 3 and instead opted for a more iterative approach, applying a thin layer of Gothic in the meantime to please the impatient fans. Thus, it feels more like a very large content update to Risen 2 than a true sequel, and PB have not quite delivered on their promise to go back to their roots. I'm not going to talk about story and graphics, as those elements are just solid, do the job and do not stand out to me. What does stand out, is the world.The world: The islands can be visited in any order this time around. They have been lovingly crafted, with many small highlights and cheekily placed treasures waiting to be uncovered. Carefully placed objects tell stories without using words, such as skeletons surrounded by bottles of rum in a secluded spot or a monkey messing around among bananas, voodoo dolls and corpses. There were countless occasions of these enriching little things that never failed to make me smile or ask myself "WTF happened here?". The world is teeming with quests (300+ of them) that mostly revolve around fetching and killing stuff. Their presentation through funny and witty dialogue (which does have its cheesy moments) makes them rewarding to complete beyond the glory and loot you get. Swearing is indeed overused, which is a trademark and a welcome recurring theme in the German version, but probably superfluous in the eyes of the English audience. The world and the characters that populate it can suck you in for countless hours at a time. What bothers me is the use of recycled locations from Risen 2 (such as Antigua and Tacarigua), which, apart from the shadow realm's dark taint, retain their Carribean atmosphere.A thin layer of Gothic, weapons & armor: PB promised to go back to their roots and create a darker atmosphere. There were indeed (very short) moments where I felt like I was playing a Gothic game again, largely due to the new locations, factions and their armor sets. Roaming through the swamplands in a demon hunter's armor that looks like a beautiful cross between a dragon hunter's armor (G2) and an Old Camp one (G1) felt great. However, once I returned to my ship and met a parrot named Polly that told me to shave, nostalgia was quickly smothered. There are a few reincarnated minor NPCs from the old games, such as Mud (G1), an annoying, needy motormouth following you around for a bit, and Moe (G2), a violent bully demanding a toll from everyone trying to enter a tavern. Such small instances of fan service kindle hope for a more substantial return to Gothic in the future.Aside from the faction-specific armor sets, there is still a huge emphasis on pirate's clothing. This results in an muddled mixture of epochs and settings in places. Moreover, it's a shame that some stronger versions of armor pieces are just recolorings of the previous ones (e.g. a third-rank demon hunter helmet is a shade lighter than a second-rank one). Re-using assets from within this game and the previous one and applying a different coat of paint to some may be a necessity because of the development team's small size and budget. However, it seriously hurts immersion and they need to apply more polish and care to their equipment in future games.The types of weapons you'll find are again ripped from different eras and settings. There are Gothicesque axes and maces, there is your typical pirate gear and then there are a few questionable design choices. For example, the strongest musket in the game looks like an overdesigned modern-day (scoped...) air rifle that is made of bright, varnished wood. The fact that it says "way ahead of its time" in the description doesn't help much. By mixing medieval-looking arms, pirate sabers and fancy guns, PB created a rather incoherent set of tools.Combat: Serviceable, but still rather quirky. You'll find that monsters essentially teleport to your location from 10 meters away and repeatedly knock you back in a straight line. This gives a very rigid and stiff feel to the whole affair when it comes to sword fighting. Thankfully, you can dodge and pick up more moves along the way, but most of the time surviving melee combat felt more like exploitation of design flaws than standing up to a challenge to me. Many have said that it gets better later on as you get stronger and master your timing, but I really wasn't enticed to put up with sword fighting for that long. The fact that they re-introduced offensive magic abilities (painfully absent in Risen 2) adds some much needed flow and diversity. Muskets still provide an easy way to avoid finicky sword fighting and just shoot s#it in the face Indiana Jones style. I would not call them overpowered per say, as they behave and do damage as you'd expect, but still quite out of place in a Piranha Bytes RPG.Conclusion:Piranha Bytes took Risen 2 as a foundation, made it less linear, a little bit better and added a few excellent islands and factions. The result is a fun and engaging, though incoherent pirate game with a hint of Gothic/Risen 1 and plenty of the old PB quirks. That's a little less than I was hoping for, but about what I was expecting. Overall, I'm satisfied with Risen 3 and I can't wait for what future games might have in store.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												I loved Gothic 2, but never really ventured out to play any other games by PB. I picked this up on a whim, and I'm completely blown away - in a good way.Yes, the dialogue is cheesy. The script can be bad and jump around. The bugs can be awful, and laughable. You may rage the first time you accidentally back up a palm tree during combat only to fall out and die. You'll get headaches from the twitching textures, and the jittery lighting during cutscenes. You'll think the voice actors are sometimes intentionally trying to be do a bad job. The quality of the character design varies greatly from on to another. But, I still love this game, and for a good many reasons. Combat is excellent. It won't be everyones cup of tea, but its a better twist on difficult than some other games. I hate combat and levelling in Skyrim. I love combat and levelling in this game. It just feels better, and I feel like I'm accomplishing something. Enemy placement is also excellent. The world is dangerous. For example, after returning to the tutorial area after finishing the tutorial. I had killed all the monsters, and was grabbing a shroom from near a pool of water and waterfall. I almost jumped out of my seat when a massive crocodile charged at me. Almost died, but surviving a far stronger enemy after being surprised felt great. I really love the level design. Risen 3 takes relatively small maps, and makes the most of them. I love exploring and trying to find every nook and cranny, because you actually benefit from doing it. Think that ledge over there looks like you can land on it? There's probably some dead dude in a weird position, with some coins and a bottle of rum. Maybe some flowers for some extra stat points. Looks like there is an out of the way beach around a jutting out rock? I bet you'll find some useful loot, and some lore. Found a way onto that roof that makes it seem like you were glitching the game? Nope, devs figured players would do that and planted a few potions/spells. The devs understand me as a player. They know I like to mess with things, and they took it in stride and made their game great. This game won't be everyone's cup of tea, but for me it's up there. I give it an 8/10. Well worth the cost, especially on sale.

												Great game with some minor flaws sums this game up, if you dont buttom mash like a big silly and like rpg's this is a must buy (with my limited cash reserves I would say wait for a sale). I have been stuck to this game for 5 days at the time of writing this and am near the end of my second playthrough, its got to the point where Im dreaming that Im in game...send help.Anyway everyone else has the pros and cons so let me write up a tiny list of hints from my time of playing to help anyone who cares enough to read them.1, watch a youtube video about the combat (not angry joe he's a noob) to get the jist of it and to see if you want to get the game or not...2, dont use ranged combat (rifles or shotguns), stick to melee or magic, some spells are very badass, spells cost no mana and theres even a bunch of spells that improve your melee combat (demon hunter guild best magical swordsman imo)3, pick up as many quests as you can, it may overwhelm you but they are not endless and you'll nail them off fast4, if you like the game pick up the dlc's (dont need adventurers garb though) they extend the game a fair bit and dont impeed on it.5, look out for stat increasing plants and recipes for turning them into stat potions, a huge amount of free character improvement lies in these things.6, choose the right difficulty level, lots of people think this game is too hard and it will be if you put it on hard, put your ego aside for this one and just put it on easy at the start you'll have a lot more fun while still needing to pay attention, as you get better turn it up if you feel the need.7, watch out for margoloth, I wont go into details but it can be a hard boss battle. The best way to combat her imo is wait until shes at 50% health and use about 5 necromancy spell scrolls (get them before the fight). When the time comes...you'll thank me.Thats it for my main tips, I wish I knew that list on my first playthrough, still I managed ok because I put it on easy and had a blast. Controlling the difficulty is essential to not rage quiting like a moronIts a good game, get it

												Risen 3 offers great entertainment value. It was designed to be fun and enjoyable to play for a more casual gamer, or a gamer that enjoys some pleasant and relaxed gameplay once in a while.What sets this game apart from other action-rpgs is the beautiful handcrafted world that is a joy to explore, no other developer can compete with Piranha Bytes in this respect.The game offers a light-hearted story that is well told, and a lot of side quests.You eventually get a good ship and start building your crew of companions, each with their own stories, personalities and side quests. The assortment of skills and spells is very nice and varies somewhat depending on what faction you chose to join.The character progression is fairly fast compared to previous games.The one thing that is most important about the combat is to NOT tap the attack button repeatedly. Tap once, wait for the move to reach its peak then tap again, with a bit of practice you will get the timing which is very forgiving. You can also tap by listening to the sound. The dodge move has 100% invincibility window, making it very efficient when you want to get away from a tough spot.If you are looking for pleasant gameplay and good entertainment this is the best game you can get.

Posted: August 31, 2014
												If you play RPG's for immersion and exploration (ala Skyrim, Fallout 3), you should probably ignore the negative reviews and give Risen 3 a shot. The world is large and incredibly detailed with many sizeable islands each with their own unique look, feel and questlines. The combat is not frustrating like in previous Risen games, its a bit on the easy side but quite enjoyable once you learn some skills and spells. The game looks good and the economy is well balanced so you always have reason to just head off into the wilderness in search of loot to sell or hidden quests. While previous Risen games had slow, difficult starts that confined you to a small area, once you get past the opening sequence which lasts about an hour Risen 3 opens up entirely. The main storyline is not good at all, but there are lots of interesting side quests and colourul characters to talk to. If you have been curious about trying a Pirhana Bytes game but are worried about a slow start or a long learning curve, Risen 3 is a great entry point into one of the most underrated series of the last five or so years.

YouTube™ Video: Risen 3 Titan Lords Review 

			Views: 14,847		

			A Risen 3 review looking at the gameplay and its features on PC. Risen 3 Titan Lords is also available on Xbox 360 and PS3 platforms from August 15th 2014.		

Risen 3 provides an interesting romp  through its fictitious locales with an overflowing amount of things to do , comprehensive character progression, and the chance to do things differently depending on the choices made. Despite a few negatives here and there with things like getting stuck in the scenery, not enough variety with the combat and the view being obscured by foliage when in battle, the game runs smoothly and plays well. Considering its price point, gamers will get their monies worth in terms of hours, and there’s enough intrigue to keep battling on to see what happens next despite some dodgy dialogue and shallow performances.  If you’re a fan of action role playing games, then there’s a lot to like about Risen 3 which offers some pleasant and open ended adventuring.

												For some reason, Piranha Bytes games tend to be underrated. I love the art in this game, the tropical scenery is fantastic to look at. Lots and lots of quests, hidden objects, places to explore. Very good combat, definitely more challenging that what you find in Bethesda games. Three factions to choose from, with different play styles (mages = pure magic, demon hunters = melee with magic buffs, voodoo = melee with curses). Strange design choice for what concerns progression: the game starts pretty brutal, but while enemies always remain the same, you become more and more powerful, until you basically enter god mode.Anyway, having a blast with this game, and will probably play it again on hard after completion, picking a different faction. Comes highly recommended, especially considering the budget price it can be bought for now.

content:
Posted: March 10
												I would definitely recommend this game.The graphics are good, particularly the environment.  There's quite a bit of fun dialog with NPCs and your companions which had me laughing at times, it was entertaining.  There are a lot of side quests which I didn't get to finish all of because I got so focused on completing the main story line.  That's actually a compliment though because I was so focused on the main story because I'd really gotten caught up in it.  Towards the end of the story line I was REALLY wanting to kick the butt of the main bad guy.  In my first play through I focused mainly on melee weapons (swords) and enjoyed the combat.  It wasn't too complicated but at the same time had a nice level of challenge to it that gave you a sense your own skill matttered.  The kill moves were also pretty good (with the possible exception of one where you slit the throat of a skeleton which just seemed silly, but I can live with that when the rest was pretty cool).  There are also a LOT of cut scenes, the developers devoted a lot of time to this and they're generally pretty good.  It gives the game a more cinematic feel which was fun.Okay so that's the good, now for the bad.Not everything is explained very well, so I found myself sometimes just saving, trying things and reloading until I had a sense of what I should do or what was the best decision because the game didn't give me enough info about various skills and so forth to make anything other than a random guess.  Couple of examples.  Spending glory on skills and attributes, I was never entirely sure how important different ones, what the effect of raising one attribute vs another really was or how useful some skills were.  Another example, whether to keep or sell some things I'd gathered.  I gathered a LOT of iron ore, gold ore, etc. but by the end of the game all the gold ore was still sitting in my inventory.  Should I have sold it, was there some crafting I could have done with it but missed, or was it just another form of "wealth", I don't know and the game never explained this.  This was my first Risen game experience so perhaps previous games had explained this but, again I don't know.  But for someone coming to the game franchise for the first time some parts of the game were a bit too puzzling.  Overall though these problems didn't stop me from enjoying the game.  Also the game doesn't prevent you from saving at any time you like and you can have as many saves as you wish so you can always just save, experiment with choices and then reload as necessary.There's a lot of weapon choices but your armor / clothing choices were limited so being able customize your character's appearance was likewise limited more than that I would have liked.  (I guess Skyrim has me really spoiled with all the options I got used to there.)   If you have the Adventurer's Garb, which I did, I wore it for much of the game.One other criticism I would have is that once you finish the main story line the game ends, there's no option to continue in a sandbox mode as you can with other games such as Skyrim.  There is a lot to explore and with such an engaging main story line its easy to miss stuff.  But I don't necessarily want to start a new game or go back to one of my many older save points just to finish exploring a richly detailed game world.  So the lack of a sandbox mode after finishing the main story line would have been a plus in my book.Lastly, if the game developers happen to read this I have a small criticism about the game ending.  I don't want to give away any spoilers here so I'm going to be a bit vague.  But, the end cut scene was abrupt and short.  Your hero emerges you briefly see your friends and then it cuts to you sailing away and rolls credits.  As it cuts from seeing your friends to sailing away, that was very abrupt and for a game that had so many well done cut scenes the ending felt a bit anti-climatic and short.  So just wanted to point that out, it could have done with more of a celebration and renunion with your friends and crew at the end after such a big final battle.Overall though I'd very much recommend the game.  All the important aspects of the game worked, nothing felt broken to me or unfinished.  I had a lot of fun exploring the world the game presents, getting to know the NPCs, forming alliances and making enemies.  Some of the sarcastic dialog was just FUN, it was nice to play a game where you really could tell an NPC, "Hey, you know you're a moron, right?"  LOL

content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												So, here it is. The finale for Risen series. At least I hope it is, although the game explains nothing and again the plot feels like a huge anime show filler the main character slashes unimportant♥♥♥♥♥♥and sub-plot has no real impact on the core story.Incipiam.The Risen 3 once again throws us onto the infamous southern seas full of small islands and boring, uninspired pirates of the caribbean theme. I can rightfuly feel cheated (again) by the developer, who promised to dump the failure Risen 2 was and go back to Risen 1 alike tone and released only selected set of screenshots and information during the development time.You start the game on the Crap Coast, fighting poor♥♥♥♥♥attempt of hitting towards their braindead fanboy scene with scavengers who also loved Risen 2 (because of the stamp PIRANHA BYTES GAME printed on a box - or they genuinely enjoyed it, but this review is not about scat fetish, it's about Risen 3). I mean - oh God, do they really think they managed to create a good pirate theme in Risen 2 and decided to base the whole game around it once more? I'm convinced that the developers live in some kind of green-house, protected from any word of critique, letting themselves to hear only braindead applause Risen 2 received from PB-logo's mental slaves.So, we're now a different person, a brother to Patty. A wierd decision if you ask me, because he doesn't feel different at all from the previous "nameless" hero (whom we actually meet in the game, with levitating rum bottle floating above his hand). All right - I guess, because I could play a rock named Tom and I wouldn't feel any difference and the plot wouldn't suffer at all: the main character just grunts, speaks some kind of broken germenglish and the voice actor seems to be jagged (you can actually hear it!), and he mostly says "everything will be all right", "I will do it", "give me more money". Ok, back to the game. The Crap Coast is a training level, where we die and our soul is stolen. Patty cries, buries us and then Bones from the previous game appears out from nowhere and revives us. After leaving the Coast the game gives us few main goals: you need to reclaim your soul, you need to form an alliance to defeat the deus ex machina which is the ghost of Crow. Why is he back and haunts the seas? Duh - TO HUNT YOU! Why? Ummm, I don't know and it's never explained beyond that. It actually is a contradiction, because later it's explained that everything we do helps Necroloth and was planned by him. Why did he send Crow to hunt us? Ummmm... Talk about Star Wars I-III plot nonsense that tries to look good. The whole plot feels like wrote by an 8 years old fan of PB's games. The Crow subplot would actually make sense if he appeared after the plot twist, but he's actually the second most important cause of our actions to form a fleet. The third one is to join the faction which will help you to reclaim your soul and gives a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of quests. I've to admit that doing quests in the early stage of the game was fun, as most of them were reminiscent to Gothic's stage of choosing your faction. Also because the new game areas, like Calador and Taranis are actually well designed and are open for exploration. You can actually jump on some roofs to discover some powerful stuff early in the game. You're not too limited by the game and you can actually choose what do you want to do now. To level up in the faction, make and alliance, destroy the shadow portals, or just do minor nonsense. It's a huge step forward from Risen 2, but it's not a big achievement (I don't really believe it is possible to make a worse game than Risen 2 was). Unfortunately they reused some islands and they are as bad as they were previously. Antigua is laughable and Tacarigua is a boring set of corridors with some bonus chests you can't miss.Then you perform an unsuccessful ritual in order to reclaim your soul, you defeat Crow and arrive to the SKULL ISLAND. You kill some minor trash mobs, free three main mages and the game ends with one of the most disappointing, rushed, not thought through, cheesy endings I've ever seen, including the shoot-2-bullets-to-win Mara fight. I mean - what the ♥♥♥♥ happened there? The series plot is excactly where it was at the ending of Risen 1! Another titan/titan lord (apparently Necroloth is a Titan Lord AND a Titan at once, which doesn't make sense and contradicts the previous games) is defeated, everyone cheers up and they set sail to the open sea... Watch credits and go ♥♥♥♥ yourself, you just finished a boring filler which is apparently a clue of the whole series. Disappointing, because I really hoped for jumping out from the♥♥♥♥♥♥hole Risen 2 dug plot-wise.Gameplay-wise it's a Risen 2 as it should be in the first place. The combat works, character development doesn't feel like a shoveled down gimmick that does nothing at all but brakes the whole game. The skills are thought through and work, but they're still the same broken fundamentals of Risen 2 gameplay concept which is just not fun and boring. Firstly, the game is incredibely easy. Like - super easy no matter which path you take. Muskets were overpowered in Risen 2 and instead of reworking the whole system, they decided to overpower everything. Melee combat is predictable and it's easy to kite enemies, you can actually defeat EVERY type of monster in the VERY BEGINNING (after the tutorial). Imagine my astonishment when I actually defeated some golems with a basic swords, and then mauled down a shadow guardian (which is a reskinned dead guardian from Risen 2) right in Calador. You will meet only two stronger enemies, some kind of flying lizard and an undead beast, but the feeling of character progress is absolutely non-existant. You will see everything the game has to offer in the first 2 hours of the gameplay time. After you master melee fighting/demon hunters' spells/whatever you will just be able to do more mistakes (letting enemies hit you) and you will kill enemies with one or two swings less. Every single enemy has exactly the same set of moves - if they have actually different ones, I didn't see it, because fighting with a big rat feels exactly the same as fighting a shadow beast, only requires few swings more/less. You can beat the whole game not using any potions or spells, actually. I never used demon hunters' overpowered spells and summons besides the Morgoloth fight (the ONLY enjoyable fight that required spells and curses and actual tricky kiting of endless enemy spawn). I crafted the best sword in the game mid-game and 1-2 hit everything. I never used buff potions but a rum for healing. I never learned any other crafting schools as the blue-prints I found weren't simply worth it.I can actually see the character system working and worthwile, but not in the game that shows you everything it has in the first hours lets you beat it all with finger up your ♥♥♥♥♥♥.What else? Game boasts with HUNDREDS of quests, but let's make things straight. There's 100 quests at max and I wouldn't be surprised if there were less. If you take a quest "follow person X to point Y" and split it to 7 (SEVEN) separate quests it doesn't mean you deliver 7 more quests. It's still 1 quest that takes 1 minute to "accomplish" - it's only cut into smaller pieces. I think the developer really wanted to "shine" but the "hundreds quests" talk is a fraud. I mentioned laughable hitting towards their braindead fanbase. There's more than scavangers. They actually copy-pasted Moe the bouncer that wants all your money before you enter a tavern and Kyle, the guy from Gothic 1 which had a hut that everyone walked through. It's miserable and shows that developers are aware that they can never make nothing new and good at the same time: they're slaves of "those guys who made Gothic" and will never achieve more. CUT OFF MORE COUPONS, LET'S THROW SOME "NOSTALGIA" CRAP! Don't make more games, please.

												The Combat is sadly still like Risen 2's and not as good as the first Risen's, wich had the best combat of PB's games, Gothic series included.Though it seems that PB doesn't even WANT you to use melee combat since every class gets the option to use powerful magic that is superior to melee in every conceivable way.Like Risen 2, I ended up not hating this game simply through picking the most fun class/playstyle there was (back then it was the gunslinger, this time its the mage.) This also means that the game doesn't lend itself well to multiple playthroughs.Now, all that sounds pretty negative, but everything else here is at least solid. I liked most of the quests and NPCs, the dialogue and interactions are fun, the magic is satisfying to use (though that is partially by virtue of being overpowered) and the presentation, while not amazing, still works in creating distinct and cool looking environments.All in all, while I still cant wholeheartedly recommend this game to people that are - understandably- still sour about Risen 2, its a step in the right direction and I want to see where PB takes the series.

												I just finished Risen 3 - Titan Lords for the second time, so I feel comfortable writing a review.Risen 3 is a vast improvement over Risen 2, although I did like Risen 2 myself as well, but what can I say, I've loved PB's games ever since Gothic 2. While I do admit Risen series has been a lot worse than the original Gothic trilogy, they are still great games in their own sense. At first Risen 3 feels more like an expansion of Risen 2. Lots of assets have been recycled and even a few areas have been brought over from Risen 2. Luckily, however, that feeling vanishes pretty fast when you notice that the recycled areas aren't really that important and all the main areas are brand new, and then you notice how much better Risen 3 does everything. So it ends up feeling like Risen 2 but only less♥♥♥♥♥♥ Risen 3 is a lot bigger than Risen 2, and more refined in almost every aspect. The combat is great, the exploration is awesome and the world is actually open this time around.It isn't without its problems however. My biggest problem with the game is that it is WAY -WAY- ---WWWAAAAYY--- too easy! It's alright in the beginning if you play without a companion, but it becomes faceroll in the end. Even on hard. On my second playthrough as a voodoo pirate, I managed to max out all my stats. All 8 stats! Maxed! Why is this even possible?So the balance is ♥♥♥♥ed. It doesn't ruin the game, but it takes away all the tension from the last quarter of the game. Possibly even earlier if you use companions, or something else than melee. In order to get a satisfying challenge out of the game, you pretty much have to shoot yourself in the foot, by not using alchemy or companions. Alchemy is probably the biggest criminal here. It is so ridiculously overpowered it's insane.Economy balance however, is amazingly well made. There's never enough money if you really want to get the most out of skills. If you're fine with a few skills here and there, you might end up with some extra pocket change, but that wasn't the case for me. The moment I got 10k money, I used them right away, and there were so much more I wanted.Graphically there's a lot to say as well. The graphics are all over the place. The game looks dated and runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥ I got it running on reasonable fps only after tweaking a lot of the ConfigDefault.xml file. The level design which PB has always been amazing at, is also bit of a let down. Some places are extremely gorgeous, but some places are hideous. There's also a few narrow canyon paths too many for my taste.The story is.... Well... The story is. It just is. It exists, but isn't important on any level. I have never cared much about PB's storylines, but I've always loved the world, and the history of it. And here it's interesting enough to keep exploring. But the storyline itself is completely irrelevant and forgettable. Combine that with a pointless ending and that's it. But it isn't the meat of the game anyway so who cares?Some of you guys played the DLCs of Risen 2? Remember how♥♥♥♥♥♥they were? Well, the DLC of Risen 3 was a massive positive surprise to me, because both Fog Island and Uprising of the Little Guys are awesome. I enjoyed both of them thoroughly. So those are recommended if you don't have them. Nothing to say about Adventure Garb. It's a pile of gear that I don't use because it's too good for the beginning of the game. As if the game wasn't easy enough.So all in all, it's better than Risen 2, but the difficulty holds it down. I loved it. If you're a PB fan, chances are you'll love it too. If you're not a PB fan however, you probably won't like it. I hate to see people bashing the game when they've never liked PBs games. Why do you expect this one to change your mind? The "mistakes" people claim PB makes, are all things that have always been around, and if they were magically fixed, I doubt it would be the same thing anymore. Which would make the old fans disappointed. Even moreso than they already are.So yeah. I love it.Sinathor out.

												first of all I think this game is great, it looks great, in terms of visually it is very polished, i havent seen any flashing textures even far in the distance like you do in skyrim, colors are vibrant, and nothing looks out of place the art style is attractive.i dont know why alot of people are complaining about combat, sure its not the best combat system ever created, but its not boring and hopefully it will get some tweaking, think the witcher 2 when it first came out. the voice acting is great, only very rarely do i think that the script detracts from immersion, I did have some trouble with the game at launch, the game would not save, so i had to restart it like 10 times before i finnally figured out how to fix it, add me as a friend if u have this same trouble and i will tel u how to fix it. but olther than that, the world is vast, offering many choices of where to start your journey once u pass the first chapter, YES this game does take a while before you start to feeel even a little powerful, to get magic and abilities takes a while, but that is all in good fun, lets u explore first and doesnt hand you victory very easily. there is as plethora of people to talk to that can teach you different things, and they are located everywhere, not in just one place like in most rpgs. tho the important combat stuff is mostly close by the faction you choose. This game is not a rushed cheap experience like many think. I think this is the best effort of this franchise and while i havent come close to finishing it, I am having fun and not regretting the money spent.

												Just finished the game, I had good time palying it, especially the first 3 chapters, but after that the game felt super easy and got a bit boring, maybe because I did a lot of grinding and tonnes of sidequests, other than that, the game is really good and fun, especially if you are a Gothic fan, it has its downsides though, and sometimes it can be frustrating.Good:True open world (just like Gothic series, the world is completely open, no restrictions and other kind of tricks).Beautifully crafted levels.A lot of sidequests (even though some of them are pointless).Good graphics (some scenes are really beautiful).The world feels alive.Monster models are cool, I really liked it.Player is free to choose its path (can choose to be evil, or good).Voice acting is good (in my opinion).Swords, guns, bows & crossbows, magic... its a mix of everything.NPCs are nice and funny.Gothic feel is there but its still not Gothic :(Neutral:Story isn't the greatest (its completely personal though).A lot of swearing when NPCs talk (it got boring after a while hearing all the f**ks & craps. Gothic had done it right without all the crap talk).Negative:The game gets easy once you master a fighting skill.There aren't a lot of enemy varieties.Loot items are just meh.Stealth isn't as good as in Gothic, guards and NPCs won't beat the hell out of you when you sneak in front of them.Weapon/armor variety is very limited.Optimization isn't the greatest.No SLI support (that's optional though, there aren't a lot of people who runs 2 graphics cards).Overall game felt too easy after chapter 3.I think Risen 3 is a good RPG in its own category, it isn't the greatest game but it isn't bad either.It was worth my time and money, so I'm giving thumbs up.

												Risen 3 marks off the end of an era in the Risen-series. As far as I'm aware, there won't be another one. However, that doesn't matter since this final game finishes the series close to perfectly. From the first moment of playing Risen to this last moment of Risen 3, the series has made me replay the games several times, that's how good they are. There are a few noticeable differences between Risen 3 and Risen/Risen 2, apart from improved graphics of coure. In Risen 3, the combat is slightly different, as many people before me has noticed aswell. While the combat in itself is very cool and not very hard, your character is pretty weak and your NPC companion has to help you quite a bit. At least in the beginning. In Risen 3, you don't play as the character from the previous games. You play as Patty's brother, who I hadn't heard about before playing Risen 3. But that doesn't matter too much since you get to know him during the game and there's a little surprise somewhere in the game if you've played the other games...I highly recommend playing this game if you've played the former Risen games first, if you haven't. you risk losing out on a lot of the precious story. The combat gets better and better the more you play and it's the kind of game you just want to keep playing, even after finishing it. Even more so since there are different factions that you can join, changing the gameplay for every playthrough (to a certain point).
