content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												*NEW REVIEW UP-New Review after 20+ hours in the game-I'm going to write this review from a Gothica/Risen fans PoV. You will have to understand PB games to appreciate this game. it is a niche game for players who like hard combat Action RPG's like Dark Souls.-For returning players from the Gothica/Risen universe, PB made a solid game in Risen 3. The engine is a more efficient less buggy redo of Risen 2, so the graphics and physics are techinaly the same but have now been recoded for less bugs, locked high frame rates, and less stress on your hardware. So if you're looking for a new top of the lin graphics engine on par with a PS4 game don't expect much. The Game was released on 360/ps3/WinPC, so it's made for last gens hardware.   You play a new hero, you are not the nameless figure from Risen 1 and 2, but instead you are one of the sons of Captain Steelbeard, your sister is Patty and you start off the game together.==FOR NEW PLAYERS==Pirahna Bytes, aka PB, is known for making EXTREMELY STORY driven RPG's with DIFFICULT COMBAT mechanics. Not combat thats clunky, but combat that reflects starting off as a new character, as you gain skills in combat training you will notice the improvement and growth of your character. If you're new to this kind of game, then the start of the game (first 4 hours) will be a pain in the butt for you. But you will feel your character grow and get a real sense of accomplishment as you gain more skills and stats. It's one of the staples of PB games and it makes it a very niche genre not unlike Dark Souls is a niche genre. I highly suggest purchasing Risen 1 since it's dirt cheap and has no DLC to get a feel for PB games. if this is your first PB game and you don't like the game style you will feel ripped off, but I don't feel ripped off, I love it.==COMBAT==Combat will be more in line with Risen 1, then in Risen 2. More emphasis on dodging, and reading opponents ques, understanding when they combo attacks and when what they do when you dodge, moving in combat to avoid getting ganged up on, and choosing when to attack is key. Unlike Risen 2 you will not be able to move from Parry to Attack seamlessly, lending a step of difficulty more in line with traditional PB games. Which for PB fans is great, Risen 2 had hard reviews from PB veterans for making the game more cupcake and less hardcore. So Risen 3 is a step in the right direction.==CRAFTING==Unlike Risen 1 and 2, weapon crafting actually has a USE in this game. A new feature is that you take some of the misc items and combine them with weapons to make a better weapon (Thrusting sword + 2 silver plates+6 iron ore) gets you a Disked Epee, with better stats of couse, it is very money effecient. This is also in line with Guns, Muskets, and all melee weapons, even with the unqiue weapons that require difficult to find parts can be upgraded with lots of rare mats to make superior verions or to change it's damage type. Example the Crest Wave SLASHING sword 55-85 Damage +10 Slashing can be changed to the "Lightning" 55-85 Piercing +10 Piercing *and it has electric particle skin and can partialy pierces blocks*Potion crafting is back along with the rare + perm stat potions made from the perm stat ingredients, The raw ingredients give +2, the potions give +5More emphasis on temp buff potions is used since there are more skills to allocate your Glory(XP) too. So expect to use buff potions often to surpass early Lockpicks, Persuade, and Pickpocket checks==GAME LENGTH==24.5 Hours into the game at the time of this review, i am still in chapter 2, I have 4 islands explored,  2 islands un explored, and just started my 5th island. Like a good book, PB games tend to have 3 acts, I have not chosen one of the 3 factions available yet, and don't expect too until I'm near the end of chapter 2. I have only encountered 2 of the main factions so far. The games factions are the Guardians/Mages from Risen 1, the Voodoo Pirates from Risen 2, and the new faction are the Demon Hunters. You will spend hours revisting islands to find more quests, NPC's, loot, buried treasures, and open hidden passages. These do not feel like tacked on back tracking to add game time thank goodness, but honest progression, both in character development and story. I expect to drop 40-55 hours on the campaign easily.==OVER ALL IMPRESSION SCORE==Using 10/10 as a base line for Risen 1Gothica 3 beng 9/10and 6/10 as a Baseline for Risen 2and 4/10 as Gothic 4: Arcaniaand 1/10 being Daikatana or Superman 64I give Risen 3 a 8.5/10Graphics 7/10The graphics are last gen but RECENT last gen, so they are smooth FPS on Max graphics and are plenty pretty, PB games aren't known for shiny, they are known for superb story and gameplay.Combat 9/10Not as varied or complex as Risen 1, it is much better then Risen 2, you can still feel your character grow, and get that sense of accomplishment. PB vets/fans should play on HARD. Pb did a great job getting back to it's roots.Story 10/10 Well written and capable of being a book, deep and lengthy but not stale, and a continuation from Risen 1 and 2. It's fantastic, a game with great plot, it is perfect for the Single Player western RPG fans who miss plot.Is this game worthy of the PB saga? Yes it is, it is a redeeming light for PB since the goofs of Gothica 4 and Risen 2. A great sign that they are getting back in touch with what made them our favorites. I would compare Risen 3 with Deus Ex 3 in terms of taking a step in the proper direction to it's roots.Is the game worth the 49.99 USD price tag? YES, most new games cost 59.99 USD, some Early Access games cost as much as 125 USD and are utter crap. 10 dollars cheaper the most AAA games and a positive growth in game style for PB fans makes this a steal!PB vets should buy Risen 3 if you are on the ropes.NEW PB PLAYERS should buy Risen 1 or Gothica 1,2 or 3 to see if this is the game style you;d enjoy. Feel free to read my review for Risen 1 to see what I mean.*DAY 1 OLD REVIEW*Finished my third island. taking I'm taking a break to write a short early impression. I like the game so far, the combat early on was dissapointing but it picked up soon. i restarted a new game and made the entire first level without getting hit onceIt's closer to risen 1 in combat then risen 2. Main difference, you can't go from Parry to attack, and you use dodging a lotOnly found one bug and it's in quest text, there in Antigua, you'll have to find a bag of clothes and it says it's on the FIRST floor, it's actually on the 2nd floor, use a parrot flight to get thereI am dissapointed that damage types aren't damage styles, now all weapons swing like slashing weapons, makes the fencer in me sad i play on hard difficulty, the game is still fairly easy, about on par with risen 2. the soft 50 fps lock is nice. It's superior to risen 2 in story, size and gameplay, i need to play more to compare it to risen 1. if i had to review score it based on the first 4 hours. 8/10 but I'm not into the meat of the story line yetPatty broke my heart, they got rid of her curly long black hair, and I'm her god damn brotherI wanted to continue as the nameless hero and finaly get her in the damn sack!It's a solid game, and worth the 49.99 USD, which need i remind people is not the usual 59.99 of most games. If you played both Risens and liked risen 1 better, you'll like this game. not as much as 1 but more then 2. I think it was worth the purchaseOn to Fog Island next to get the 10% Glory special item

Posted: August 20, 2014
												Risen 3: Titan Lords is a solid RPG with awesome (but cheesy) dialogues, pretty nice story and large world that rewards exploration.Every other system in the game is somewhat basic:- Leveling? Yep, just put your XP into your stats.- Combat? Yep, just 3 buttons - evade, attack and block. You can do riposte by blocking at right time and you can do heavy strikes by holding attack, but that about it. Oh, yeah, there are spells that make combat a bit more enjoyable, but you get them only after ~10h into the game.- Crafting? Yep, just gather mats and click "craft" to get the item, no random stats or minigames.- Lockpicking? Yep, no fail state though. Just a lot of annoyance with complex locks >_>- Naval battles? Yep, but so arcadey that you can actually tell the ship to go forward...- Other mini-games? Yep, drink game, knife throwing game, arm wrestling game, etc. All come down to either using one button, or just QTE stuff.All of those are VERY basic, but not bad. They can vary gameplay a bit from time to time, but get boring pretty quick.If you are looking for fat loots - you won't find them in this game. Items are pretty limited, but getting a new one almost always feels like a large upgrade. No random stats either. (think Witcher 2 style of itemisation)If you still want to be a pirate and good storyline and quests is what you are searching for - then Risen 3 will deliver in full.All dialogues are nicely voices, there's tons of quests to do and places to explore. Quests often has several ways to complete them and some of them are pretty amusing. Once again - all of that is pretty cheesy. So if you don't like cheese or searching for fat loots - this is not the game. If you want RPG, dialogues and exploration - this is the game, and quite good one.More in depth look on the UI, mechanics and other things in the lengthy video:


YouTube™ Video: DevPlay.. Risen 3: Titan Lords

												When I look around the internet, all I see about Risen 3 are bad reviews. Now that I finally got to try it myself, I can say that most of the people's complaints about this title are overstretched by what may be a long lasting hate for the Risen series started from Risen 2, just because it "wasn't like Gothic". This game is a product of high level, featuring an interesting storyline with moral choices that affect your gameplay (even though some decisions that should alter your soul just don't), can be played in many different ways (swordsman, mage, ranged to make some examples) and lets you choose between three factions that provide you with spells that give you more options in a fight (even if the more skilled may stick with meelee, because of the riposte). The animations for sprinting and jumping look strangely similar to the ones of Assassin's Creed Black Flag (I could be wrong), but I don't care because they look and feel more realistic than the ones of the previous chapters. My sole complaint is about the Demon Hunters: I know, I know it's lore... but does he really have to shave his head?!

												Game is an improvement over Risen 2. Without Making this review overly complicated, I enjoyed the gameplay elements so much, but I do have some nitpicks on it. Positive first, the world to me was very expansive and for the most part you could go multiple ways to reach your destination. Now for the negative: main characters voice acting I feel was not normal and felt just plain wrong to me. Cutscenes and ending felt thrown in and out of place. The implementation of hunting for additional ingredients, while something I like, doesn't seem fit in without a reliable respawn system for monsters. The implementation of how much glory it takes to raise a skill should be balanced so that it doesn't take into account permanent potion bonuses.7/10*very minor min/max character spoiler below*Only reason I mention the last item under negative is because I like to min/max my characters, but you have to raise your skills in a way where you drink the permanent potions at the end so you spend as little glory as possible leveling skills.

												I loved Risen and Risen 2.  What I mostly enjoy in games is the plot and characters and the interactions between them.   In the first two, I loved the "Hero" and Patty, and the way it danced around them having a romantic relationship but never really went that far. content:
Posted: March 17
												If you enjoyed the Gothic series, you will enjoy this game. Risen 3 represents the latest incarnation of that long long of role-playing games. If you haven't heard of the Gothic series, or Piranha Bytes, or JoWooD Entertainment, chances are that you will not enjoy Risen 3. By the standards of modern RPGs made by U.S. developers, Risen 3 is archaic. Gameplay can be boiled down to fetch quests and go-there-and-kill-that quests. But when you think about it all RPGs boil down to that. Combat is clunky by modern standards. In fact I knew this already and didn't bother playing combat and cheated, giving myself all requisite skills to avoid the frustration of constant stun-locks and whatnot. Plenty of wise sages before me has described the problems at length. The only remotely interesting aspect is the morality system. Good deeds result in soul gains, resulting in good guy rewards. Bad deeds result in soul losses, resulting in bad guy rewards (which are still rewards, so that's more realistic than most RPGs). Don't expect anything like the Witcher 3.Visually, it looks nice for a 2014 release. Some parts still look stunning, like the forest regions. Just don't expect FarCry. The story's serious parts, much like the serious characters, consist of non-descript, entirely forgettable, and highly generic fantasy tropes. You couldn't get more vanilla if you tried. There's a Dark Lord of course. However, the game is made much more spicier (and racier) by its non-serious parts, thanks in no small part to the fact that the main character is basically a pirate. Or privateer to be more accurate. Finally, you should be aware that Risen 3 is pretty sexist and racist by the standards of modern American politically correct non-triggering entertainment values. For example, I ran into two quests where the awards were sex with women, without even trying (incidentally if you're trying to be a good guy -- just remember that obvious harlots cannot be trusted!), and the only female crewmember is my hot sister strutting about in her tights and lovely bust. She is generally useless, except that she's very good at acquiring the locations of treasure by "being nice" to ornery old pirates. What is not useless is my gnome companion, Jaffar, who likes to steal gold and loots my defeated enemies. We also have an IQ differential that is comparable to our height differential. Jaffar is a good chap though, speaks with a strange accent and talks about his gnome buddies, named Kasim and Ali. Besides the gnomes, you also meet Voodoo natives who I swear are from Africa, with the spiritualism of Native Americans (as interpreted by modern old-worlders), but I'm surely mistaken. In any case, all of these things put together have caused many butt-hurt game reviewers to complain that the game is racist and sexist. Funny as hell though.By the way I applaud Patty's pants because they're low-rise.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												Even though I'm a huge Pyranha Bytes fanboy and I can forgive them a lot....I just can't recommend this game. Gothic 1, Gothic 2, Gothic 3 and Risen 1 are all absolutely amazing games and I recommend wholeheartedly every one of them. I can even recommend Risen 2 even though it's nowhere near as good as the previous games. But Risen 3 is just too a blatant attempt to extract some more money from the Risen 2 engine and assets without too much effort.This game still retains some of PB's trademark systems and there IS some enjoyment to be found if you look hard enough. On the other hand it just exudes an uninterested, glassy, dreary atmosphere. The story is a complete joke, the writing lacks the spark and wit of Risen 2, NPCs are vapid and long winded, quests are boring, character models and entire areas are cynically rehashed and reused and the combat, the greatest strength of PB games, isn't very satisfying either. There's way too much of it and it stops being challenging or interesting very quickly, especially if you go for the mage build. You're just blasting hordes of trash mobs again and again into oblivion. Sometimes it feels like a 3rd person Diablo which is the complete opposite of what PB games traditionaly strived for.Many fans claimed Risen 2 marked the end of true Pyranha Bytes but Risen 2, even though a significant decline, is still worth playing. Risen 3 is not. It's cynical, disinterested, boring and routine rehash of Risen 2, nothing more.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												Basically It boils down to this. A good role playing game rewards fastidious exploration. The Risen franchise is no exception.The more you explore the more loot you get, the more loot you get, the more money you get, the more money you get, the more skills/items/equipment you get. To me, this is the attraction of the Risen franchise. Exploration=reward, pure and simple. This is a very important element in any pure single player RPG. This particular element is handled well in the  Risen series of games. However the Risen franchise is still struggling to find a solid identity. The first Risen was very ambiguous, the second chapter, the developers, despite giving the franchise a more polished pirate themed aspect,  were still experimenting with the combat system. This 3rd chapter is wonderful to the hardcore RPG'er, the pirate element still remains but the combat remains slightly clunky and experimental if you will.  However, the exploration vs. reward idea remains solid in all 3 games. Risen 3 is a more finely polished example of where the franchise could go. Exploration and completionism is the key in the Risen franchise. However to be perfect the Risen franchise could do well with a lot more polishing.  Some examples being, keep working on the combat system, the combat system in Risen, being the core of the game still feels slighty clunky. I figured out the obvious pattern in the combat system early on. And there is a definite pattern still. This pattern in the obvious timed moves still hinders the combat system from feeling fluid and natural. If you attack at the wrong time, you get hit, if you attack at the right time you strike. There is no fluid inbetween. The combat feels "timed" more so than natural. Another aspect the developers could benefit from working on.  Make the skill earning system more complex. The skill system in this game is OKAY but not perfect. It still feels slightly limited. You spend cash on new skills, and you add power points to existing skills to "level them up". However there is no complex skill tree per se. You don't get to master a whole entire set of skills in any one combat style. This all lends to a slightly limited combat system. You can get BETTER at guns...but all you'll notice if you do so is that you do more damage with ranged weapons. To be blunt, the leveling/skill system needs a serious overhaul to feel more rewarding. Also very importan to the hardcore RPG'er is, reward all the hard work put into the game with a beautiful well thought out ending. I notice the Risen titles in this franchise have lackluster endings. I realize the games themselves tell a story. But a moving, rewarding ending for a role playing game like this, where hard work and exploration should lend to the game's ending  is needed to complete the immersion process. I hope they continue this franchise, and fine tune the understandable flaws until they release a game that surpasses all other RPGS.In short, this RPG does exemplary on the exploration verses reward aspect. The more you explore, the more you benefit. However this franchise still continues to fall short on the combat system, skill system and endings for the games. This game will tickle the fancy of any die-hard fan of single player RPGs, but there is still a ways to go if the developers want to perfect this franchise.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												I wanted to like this. Risen 3 is clearly a bigger, more ambitious, and more polished product than its predecessors, which always felt like they wanted to be bigger than they were. The combat is slightly less clunky than before, but still recognizably the traditional Piranha Bytes plodding, stunlock-loving style that I would inevitably toggle God Mode to avoid eventually.The fact that I can't actually do that this time without 3rd party programs is a factor in my negative review.Honestly, the killer problem with this game, the one bad enough to make it the first of these games since Gothic for me to abandon outright a few hours in, is that it's just horribly balanced. I don't mean "unfair" - Piranha Bytes games are always unfair. But normally they're a consistant level of unfair that simply presents a steep learning curve, like a poor man's Dark Souls.Risen 3, meanwhile, is just plain inconsistent. You can be playing along, managing to more-or-less stay on top and not meeting the traditional fate of being stunlocked to death by a passing ostrich, when you'll wander into an unremarkable-sounding quest and be killed in three shots by some complete nobody that the game in no way warns you is fully capable of handing you your♥♥♥♥♥on a platter. And with no way to cheat my way around it this time around so I can enjoy the parts of the game that aren't awful, I simply don't have the patience to roll the dice every single time I fight a new enemy and hope that they just haven't arbitrarily decided to make this nondescript monster deal five times as much damage as everyone around him.I suppose it's worth noting that this inconsistency is foreshadowed somewhat by the story, which is by far the least concrete of the series. After a kind of rushed-feeling tutorial level, you're thrown into the wide open world with what the previous games would've called late first-act gear and a vague mission to do something about your missing spirit. I didn't like the way Risen 2 bottlenecked you for the first third/half of the game by locking you onto a single story path, but at least it gave me time to understand what the hell I was doing and what the stakes were. Risen 3 by comparison legitimately feels like the entire first act is just missing, and I frequently find myself feeling like I'm showing up to certain areas prematurely as random plot points are discussed as if I should have been told about them beforehand somewhere else.Between that and the random difficulty curve, I'm not sure the game was designed to be as open-ended as it is, and ultimately it just winds up feeling like a mess. I know it's not Piranha Bytes' style, but this is probably one game that could have benefitted from the traditional RPG approach of having character and quest levels to guide the player along. The intent was to make a game that doesn't hold the player's hand, and I can applaud that, but I don't have the patience with a game that not only doesn't tell me what to do, but then kicks me in the gut whenever I fail to read its mind about what it expects me to do. "Open-ended challenge" isn't the same thing as "be psychic or die."

												If you're a fan of the Risen games, this iteration won't dissappoint.  The character levelling/RPG elements are unique and as entertaining as always.  The writing and voice acting are extremely rough.  If you're a fan of exploration, there are hundreds of secret nooks and crannies if you're willing to spend the time to look around.  Unlike the previous games, the melee combat in this one is actually enjoyable.The game does one particularly interesting thing - it opens up pretty much the entire world to you immediately, and the enemies do not scale with your level.  This has advantages and disadvantages.  The beginning of the game is quite hard, but as your character develops, you really feel yourself becoming powerful.  It's very satisfying.  However, by the end of the game, you feel like an unstoppable god and just plow through the same enemies that you've been fighting for the last 30 hours.

												Honestly, it's not what I expected when I first played through the game. I was looking forward to a more challenging Gothic-esque follow up. The game is way too easy for a "Gothic" game. No real challenge, all you need is your trusty fireball spam and you are good to go.Overall the story is not that great and engaging as the one Gothic 1 or 2 was. Characters are plain and have not much depth to them. In Gothic even a simple guard was more interesting than a named NPC is in Risen 3. Simply put, there is not enough character development going on in Risen 3. (For example Milten the mage from the old camp becomes a close friend later on in the story of Gothic, turns out to be one of the closest helpers of the Nameless hero and in the end helps restore the blade Uriziel. Something like this was missing from Risen 3.)The game is fun overall after the first playthrough, but after that, it becomes bland and not that interesting at all. Maybe it is, because it is so simple or it's just me who expected it to be even more challenging than the original Gothic 1 and 2.Overall, if you are a new generaion player and want to try a "Gothic" game, Risen 2 and 3 are the games for you. If you are up to the challenge, try Gothic 1 and 2 too. (Even though if you ask for my opinion, neither is Gothic 1 and 2 that hard for new generation players to play it, but whatever...)Piranha Bytes should have focused more on PC players who expect difficult RPGs from them and put less console like tutorials and mechanics in Risen 3. I almost felt like they were holding both of my hands while I was playing. Consoles really ruined this game the most as I see it.The DLCs are a sorry excuse of aditional content. They are by far not that satisfying as one would expect. The 2 islands added have only a few quests and even though you meet some old faces from Risen 1 and 2, they didn't hold my interest for long. 1 hour of gameplay per Island is not worth 10€.Even after all this, I still recommend this game, but you should buy it once there will be a discount, as it is by far not worth 50€. Maybe if they upped the difficulty a bit and added more depth to characters, Risen 3 could have been the game we all waited for so long. (And of course less hand holding and console nonsense.)

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												5/5Gameplay: + Oriented on Gothic 1&2 and Risen 1+ Same humor as ever+ Very much atmosphere, in terms of quests and the game/level/island design. + I can not! confirm, that the quests are generic or anything like that. Also every character has it's own personality and position in this game, there are only very few unnamed characters with no kind of background in this world. But this does not only to npcs, but to all items and locations aswell, truly handcrafted!+ I love the way magic got implemented in this game! No exhausting mana-potion collection or brewing which I always disliked, but just a cooldown-based system. Some critisize that, I love it and think a lot of games should go that direction!+ I do not find the story boring and do not agree with (most) reviewers.+ I love flying or gliding around like a parrot.- Sometimes there's not enough feedback whether a quest is completed, failed or still pending in status, e.g. before being promoted to a guardian you have to talk to your pirate admiral. He then tells you to kill the undead dogs, swirling around the city. Although this is not hard to accomplish, one may still miss out on some dogs and ask him-/herself, why one can't get promoted. Another example would be the "di fuego" related quests.- Sometimes npcs can't follow you and get stuck, however if you wait long enough they will eventually be back at your position (Teleporting and/or going back to your ship or another island helps in this case).Graphics:+ I don't know where to start. All people critizing the graphic of risen 3 can't have played it. + I have rarely seen such beautiful sunsets and sunrises as in this game. Just as an example if one stands a bit away from the council hall or tower in antigua and in front of it, and if it's dawn and you look up in the sky, you see the air glimming inside the council hall, with a warm fire enlightening the whole building and if you look up, you have this dark, star filled sky, which at the very edge slowly fades into a warm pink/purpleish kind of color. There were countless moments like that and I can truly say that I have met no game, where the graphic is that atmospheric, some of the steam-screenshots catch very well how beautiful the game looks!- I mean, yes, sometimes!!! there are very low resolution textures, but most of the time they don't catch the eye.Sound:0 Well, there has been written a lot about this part of the game so I will skip the extensive part and sum up that although I also find that the sound is very atmospheric, there are some downsides. + The german synchronization however is very well!To sum it up: If you liked the Gothic series and Risen 1, buy it. The basis for this game may be a pirate setting and of course it plays in the Risen universe, but it catches the Gothic flair from old times quite well and has some (good) adjustments to it.Also I have not played Risen 2 so I can't say which textures got reused etc.One last comment I want to make is, that most of the negative reviews seem to be from people that have played the game only a few hours and could not immerse themselfs in it, whether it is because their personal taste of a game is different or because they were not patient enough. I also think that this is reflected pretty well in the metacritics score which has a lot of negative reviews, but just as much positive reviews and nothing in between, so this game really splits based on your personal taste.

Posted: September 7, 2016
												At first I was really sceptical when I entered the game and it looked just like Risen 2 but after the first few quests I realized the numerous improvements the devs have made to the game. Some major complaints I had with Risen 2 have been resolved.Gameplay & Story:The standard melee combat system is still not at a level that i can truly say I liked it. Muskets felt really underpowered in this title. But magic is straight up powerful and feels (and looks) pretty nice. I really like that they don't use a mana system in this title but rather cooldowns only. It helps to remove those annoying downtimesI really liked the idea of the parrot spell, where you can just fly around the world for a limited time. A stronger version you can learn would have been great thoughLike in the previous title there are some minigames you can play in most major cities, which is a nice idea although not a time dump like in some other games.The very numerous quests played out nice. The map system has a solid design. The fast travel points are well placed enough to be helpful and still in "believable" locations.As in all RPG titles the story plays a major role. The story telling is pretty solid in this title. The story is interesting to the end although nothing too new.For fans of the series there are a lot old acquaintances to meet.The voice acting was pretty solid, although some npcs obviously shared voices. Calling spiders insects all the time drove me nuts though (Yes, I know that in olden times people probably didn't know, but still).In total it took me a good 40-45 hours to play through on a high difficulty and complete all quests I could find, which were quite many as stated before.Looks & Performance:The game looks really pretty for a huge world story driven RPG. There are very few bugs and glitches. The world design is well composed and feels for the most part realisticFinally I really want to praise the optimization levels the devs have gone through. With all options on max my old third gen i5 used all it's cores equally and rarely went above 50% total load. Most of the work was done by my GPU (as it should be)

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Risen 3 is the type of game that will appeal to those who enjoy the solo parts of certain MMOs.The nameless hero is ultra cool and seriously♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off that he has lost his soul. The language that spews forth from his mouth is foul but it is also smart and full of confidence and no nonsense attitude. In my opinion the voice acting altogether is  very clear and consise for a pirate themed game. It is sometimes exhausting to listen to the amount of voice work in RIsen 3 though and I found myself skipping it to get to the point of meandering conversations or more prominently when the fixed camera gets stuck behind an object.The orchestral score adds to the cinematic quality of the game, more on that later. Classically epic for a swashbuckling adventure to the pit of a man's soul while slaying undead monsters and feral beasts. Music quality seems muffled underneath the sound effects but reappears at the right moments to genuinely solidify the moments of sentimentality and heroics. The sentimentality that exists between the gamer and this adventure, the game supplies the avenue for the heroics.Sound in general is good. Your going to hear the seagulls high pitched squwack on the beach and  they are there to accidentally interrupt those moments of sentimentality that this experience provides. The sound of the waves and ocean could encapsulate the vivid scenery when the 3d sound would like to work. Chatter from npc's is repetitive.The views displayed during gameplay are heavy hitters for sure. If you like the bloom, then keep it on, but by default it is a bit too much. I am not sure if the landscape design and environmental effects are purposely directed to the player's best field of view but you can rotate the camera enough to see the brilliance. Which is nice, the game is not over trying to establish itself as an over-achiever with AAA graphics, but what is there is decidedly cool looking. Player models do their justice and close inspection of monsters shows surprisingly deep design. I feel the land design, including craggy landscapes and beautiful beach vistas are only eclipsed by the feeling of traversing over them and losing your poor AI companions in the process.If you can see it, then you can go to it - most of the time, that is a good thing because with the amount of exploration here - not being able to go somewhere is a clue that there is absolutely nothing to gain by going there. okay, the game is deep on many levels. The islands are charachters in themselves and hold many secrets and surprises. You will explore shallow and deep caves, old ruins, mystical rock formations and many more fantasy cliches. This game is different, firstly it is a pirate adventure so things are just a bit off kilter than the standard fantasy fare, the lore holds it's own steadfast and doesn't apply the pressure to the player to like it. Secondly the level design is in my opinion, the entire game and it surely amounts to being something to experience in it's entirety. Quests are abound and only those who play CRPGs all the time will get sick and tired of the hubs and fast travel openings that games like these emit. There is a large portion of learning the game here, then a middle part that is exhausting but refreshing up until the final chapter which plays out kind of like a thriller. That is how this game is like a cinemaic experience. Seemingly so in the perspective given to the player and his choices during gameplay such as dialogue or it's open worldness. This ancient world made up of islands did feel a bit like it was showing the player the motions to run through it, but there is so much charachter depth to sink your role playing teeth in here. Lots of weapons and skills, crafting. It should be stated that there is not much armor to choose from but there is cosmetic diversity thats fundamental to the storyline. The companions you accumulate over the entirety of the quest definetely makes it feel like family and the comedy shines through more than a handful of times.It could be said that this game is a loot grind or simply quest after quest after quest but that is not necassarily an insult as I have meticulously attempted to be a completionist and loot everything. I have enjoyed the game as a whole and really liked going on treasure hunts and living like a pirate in this fantasy role playing game.  As far as combat is concerened, I felt this - there is alot of it! The amount of enemies to fight is comparitive to an all out action game, minus the bosses, but the combat system here is extremely banal compared to a spectacle fighter. Although the combat engine is adequate and it is up to the player to find their own style of magic, melee and missile, the wish for a quicker resolution to encounters may occur due to the engine's simplicity of hit or be hit and remembering enemy patterns. All in all this method is rightly better than all out button mashing or turn based applicatons. There are the occassional stuttering animations not just in the combat, but this can be overlooked, but add in, at the same time a grossly boggled camera in unleveled jungle floors mired in bush, then you may be reloading a previous save.This is a game that knows it is a long ordeal, and epic it may be when realizing the credibility of the game design and excellent mechanics overshadowing the many minor bugs that fail to sink this ship. Advice: Try the shapeshifting skills and admire the animation.

												Great game.  Loved the pirate setting.  Much like Skyrim your character in the beginning plays as though they were crippled but by end game I had improved my skills and was a nimble wrecking machine. 												Any game that has pirates gets my attention immediately and in that sense I feel like Risen 3 definitely delivers. It also delivers horrible combat mechanics, a fair amount of bugs and some poor dialogue here and there but the experience is still worth it and still enjoyable if you can get past that. The graphics look pretty good and there are some really beautiful areas. The game has a ton of content and side quests that can lead to some pretty rewarding stuff. I don't recomend this though, as you lose out on some content that you could have had earlier in the game.I really love the attitude of the main character even if his dialogue feels a little bland, he just really doesn't give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about mostly anything and tends to mimick the attitude that a lot of players have who just want to get on with things and shut those NPCs up mid blab :p (this does save a lot of conversation skipping lol).There are even a few battles to be played out with your ship, though they don't even come close to the awesomeness that are Assassin's Creed: Black Flag's naval battles they're still a nice addition to the game.All in all, if you're looking for a pirate themed game I highly suggest this. If not, it's still a good game if you can get past some of the obstacles such as combat. It might be worth waiting for it to be on sale either way though.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												7.5/10Fun game, like the previous ones. Great story, let down by some dodgy voice acting and stilted dialogue. Some of the gnome voices are on the Jarjar Binks end of the annoying spectrum. Sometimes they verge on casual racism, sometimes they say funny things. It's like they are trying to do bad asian accents and sound ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the same time. There are some notable exceptions to that criticism. I thought the characterisation of "Stax" was done very well.Some criticize the combat system, and I can see why you'd love it or hate it as it requires a little patience. It's real-time-turn-based, if that's a thing; similar to the Gothic games. It's not a mindless hack-n-slash so you need to time blows, blocks and dodging. It's generally easy with one opponent but gets quickly impossible with 3 or more. You need a party to act as combat decoys more than you need them to assist you in fighting. The lore is a bit of a grab-bag but I enjoyed the pirate/inquisitor/voodoo/druid/mage/aztec ruin/underworld thing they mashed together. I like sandbox sprawlers that let you jump up to seemingly inaccessible places and reward you with hidden loot. There's no character creation, but it also doesn't lock you in to classes so your character will end up evolving towards the skills you like using.Very playable RPG fun....After 70+ hours of game play, I can say it's well worth it given the price on release was around half of what a premium game would be. There's some amusing quirks that are either poor translations or dev in-jokes, for example every single bird yields chicken drumsticks. I suppose everything tastes like chicken. What I said about classes, well you don't need to hold back, you can max out a lot of skills by the end so there's no compromises. There are 3 guilds to join, I played mage because lightening, but going back I'd probably have a go at demon hunter. Voodoo is powerful but to be honest that was my least favourite part of the game. Pirate Patty's boobs are ridiculous. And she's supposed to be your sister, thanks Borat. I recall the character from a previous Risen, but I don't recall her being dressed like a pirate-stripper on halloween. I love boobs but really, it was a bit out of place. Witcher did that way better. They swear a lot too. I spose it's pirates, but if you're gonna swear do it well.

												If you enjoyed the Gothic franchise, you're going to love this game.I won't lie to you and say it has the best graphics for its time, because it doesn't. They're mediocre at best.The voice acting is some of the worst I've seen since Daikatana.The combat is a bit clunky, but once you understand the subtle nuances of timed combat, and learn the patterns of the different enemies, it's actually quite enjoyable.The story is alright; with better voice acting it might even be pretty good.Here's the thing, though... This is basically Gothic 3 (without the awful frames / freezing bug), except you're a pirate. There aren't a lot of games like that out there. Additionally, the sea combat is wonderful. If you don't really enjoy the genre, this game isn't going to be for you. However, if you love this sort of game - your elder scrolls, your gothics (before 4), or earlier Risen titles - this game is going to be a blast. It's very open in that it doesn't force you to visit places in a set order. You can go just about anywhere right from the start, and the different gameplay styles and factions give it a fair amount of replayability. Overall, I'd give this game a 3/5. For me personally, though, it's a 5/5. It just comes down to what you're into and what you're willing to put up with.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
If you liked the Gothic series and Risen, and can stomach the pirate theme of Risen 2, this game is for you.It was, as usual for PB, made for the audience that enjoyed their previous work.PositivesThe game is beatiful in my opinion, shaders and reflections are some of the best I've seen in a long time. Game runs mostly solid 60fps on my system (660ti and a first gen i7), dips rarely went lower than to 50fps, max settings.Combat system really did see improvements, even though many reviewers fail to see them.The new islands are much larger (at least 2 times the space and 3 times the quest density) than the two taken from Risen 2, ( the islands many criticized for being copy pasted, which is only really half-true, they have been noticably reworked and don't play as of a role in the story, I spent as much time on both of them as I did doing one half of one of the three main islands)The UI has never worked this well; instant response times and logical structure make necessary UI navigation easyNegativesThe sea battles are half baked at best, luckily they didn't take up more than 5-10 minutes at a time for me. Shame one of them starts off the game, so you see shoddy scripted animations and QTE's as a first impression, when either are rather rare throughout the entire gameWhile most of the UI is very snappy and responsive, the Inventory system is on a list basis, so scrolling is necessary. I prefered the Risen 1 system of a big open square based inventory, but I did get used to it easily.The overarching story is, as usual, quite cheesy and uninspired. That said: Obligatory "hero looses his abilities" we come to expect from PB games twist is probably better executed than in most previous iterations. Nice set pieces, areas and generally diverse side quests though.English voice acting is mediocre to 'meh', with many characters, german v/o is decent for a german v/o, many characters voices dont really fit their characters though. Many german voices are by voice actors that were in RIsen 1 and subsequently in the old Gothic games, so nostalgia bonus.That's really the biggest point, nostalgia bonus. If you liked Risen and loved Gothic, like I did, I would recommend, for anyone else, you may wish to wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												I usually never write a review for anything unless it is extremely warranted but here we go. This is a more regrettable purchase than WarZ. Boom! You get screwed by the developers here. They know it, you will know it. It is absolutely disgusting that they come out with something like this. *EDIT* I came back to the review and figured I should add that when you play this game, just don't expect anything spectacular. I concluded its made to be bad. I can understand that, but not for $50 can a game be that intentionally bad.Oh, its pretty? So what?! It doesn't even preform well and is a mockery of a game that should come out in this day and age. I feel like I have been pretty ripped off by the quality of this game for the price of $50. I think I have been made fun of for purchasing this game due to the extreme lack of quality and substance. I cannot believe this is even on Steam's market right now to be absolutely honest. For $50 you expect a game to actually be polished and work well and play well. Risen 3 does nothing of the sort. This is the type of game I would have expected to come out in 2003, not 2014 and certainly not for that price tag. It was advertised as an improvement from Risen 2 in every way and offering a new experience in ways of storytelling and combat that will be relished. That is completely false. Actually the biggest load of crap I have fallen for. The combat system is the same with no redeeming qualities. Here is how it goes: you strike twice, maybe 3 times, most of which the enemy blocks if they are a humanoid, then the enemy strikes where you hold down the RMB until you get to throw a strike of your own. You can try and dodge, but guess what? The enemy will probably come at you with his strike nearly teleporting to hit you. This is the entirety of the combat system. Nothing built on and certainly nothing improved. Nothing tactical or even trying with this system. It literally consists of just waiting and waiting and waiting. COMBAT SHOULDN'T BE BORING, THIS MANAGES TO BE SO. They should be ashamed for trying to get this game out on the market. The creation of this combat system actually makes me feel sick. Thinking you can slap something that bad together and be happy with it is ridiculous and is part of why this game was just a cash grab.The voice acting actually feels like they were joking while making this in the studio. With the main character sounding like he just got out of bed the entire time and Bones (your kool companion) trying to sound interesting and mystical, you can tell nothing was seriously done with this trash. At first I thought it was funny, now its just getting on my nerves and feels like a repeated kick in my junk for falling for this horrid game. I will keep trying to play this game again but heavily discourage it to ANYONE else because it is in all sense of the word, a cheat to the gamer. I really do feel screwed by it in every way.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												I think there's one character that truly captures the game's problems: your sister. I can imagine that design meeting:"Ok, we need a girl in the game. What do we know about girls? Uh... they have boobs. Good, perfect. Make them huge, because pirates would value the extra buoyancy. Now we have a boob pirate... oh! But let's be different, and instead of eye candy she's your SISTER! Right... so, what do brothers and sisters talk about? Being brother and sister, of course! Make sure that she reminds you with every sentence. That way the player is convinced that she's both a boob pirate AND your sister. It's called immersion. Look it up."I don't think the game was actually written by a real writer. I've played it for 12 hours. I will probably beat it, and I actually enjoy the game a little despite itself.The overall issue that will prevent me from ever truly recommending the game is how poorly-devised the world is. The writing is stupid -- and I use the word "stupid" because it really is the most accurate. It's simply dumb. I actually find myself sympathizing with the writing at times, because the problems remind me so much of the "books" I wrote as a young teen (I'm almost 30). Characters say things ALL THE TIME that create a hundred different questions. "If he uses magic he'll die like all the others." What others? Who died? Who used magic and had it go poorly? Why does everyone treat magic like it's a part of life, a boon, or a blessing, and then this character acts like it's certain doom OUT OF NOWHERE. Why does no one else reflect this? Why haven't I been presented with lore? Why didn't you use this opportunity to GIVE me lore."If you don't do this you'll die."How do you know that? Where could this knowledge have possibly come from? Why does the main character not find any of this strange?Those are just two small examples in what feels like an absolute barrage of inconsistencies. I don't feel like a world has been created here. It feels like a few game designers sat around and threw around cliches at each other until they had a script. The main character suffers three-fold: for some reason they wanted him to look like an unlikable version of Christian Bale. His voice actor (or the director) can't seem to nail the mood of a single line. You're constantly being reminded through his gruff cursing that this is a recording of an actor in a booth somewhere, and not a real person. And third, his writing is terrible -- both in WHAT he says, and in his robustness as a character. Some of the voice actors truly are great. There are good performances that stand out, despite the rest of the game. That point needs to be made. But even these GOOD performances have issues. I feel like no one directing the game's talent had any true vision for what the game was supposed to be or how lines were supposed to be delivered. It feels like a discovery-writer's first draft. OR, the opposite problem, they could have had TOO many creative hands in the development. This is an issue of leadership and vision.Perhaps the absolute worst thing about the game is that when it makes me laugh (and it does, it can be quite funny), I'm not completely certain the game MEANT to make me laugh. I'm fairly certain the "funny parts" are supposed to be when people curse. I just don't believe the creators were capable of intentionally making me belly-laugh. I don't know if I'm laughing with or at this game. I go back to my earlier comment: this game is stupid, and I hate using that word to describe things. The game labors tirelessly to convince you that not a single talented designer has ever touched Risen 3. I enjoy it a little, and am rather determined to finish it. But every single person who had a creative hand in this game's writing, design and acting needs to take a long, hard look at other themselves or other professions. I would be embarrassed to ask people for money for this game, and I feel foolish having given them the benefit of the doubt.

												Buy this game if you love RPG's, and don't mind if a game is a bit rough around the edges, people who played the previous gothic and risen games know. You will get a good amount playtime for your money, and the game becomes alot of fun as soon you figured out the combat system. As the gothic series and the previous risen games, one of the biggest appeals of the game is the exploration. You will always find some hidden treasure and secrets, if you just look for themThis game gets a bad rap for being not as streamlined and polished as some other AAA rpg's, quite undeserved if you ask me. And i'm not a blinded fanboy of the franchise who desperately wants to defend it. I started playing this game after Witcher 3, and the transition was more than rough, since Witcher 3 was  doing everything right that matters in a good RPG.  Going over to risen was very difficult, since the clunky animations, odd combat system, and campy dialogue made it very appaling after Witcher 3. I even stopped playing entirely until i got back into it much later. But if you're willing to put some effort in the game you can get alot of entertainment out of it. Especially if you love exploring, this game will be for you. While the seperate Islands that you will visit throughout the game are not as huge as for example Skyrim, there are still tons of areas to discover that are completely optional, but will always reward you for exploring them.In conclusion, i'd recommend this game to every rpg fan, although if you only want to play perfectly balanced and polished games, this one might not be for you as it comes with a series of issues coming from the sometimes faulty game design. If you played and like the previous Gothic and Risen games, you can't do anything wrong with this one.

Posted: February 15
												I bought the entire trilogy, and I have to say, I really enjoyed the witty humor some times, and the game flows well.  I started with the first game, and while it looked like a bad high school project, it was still fun to play.  After beating the first one, I played the second right after.  It was an absolute joy to see how much the game improved in terms of overall quality versus the first game and how it continued the story line from the first game.  At times it got a little slow, like a bad movie with lots of sex as a saving grace to keep the movie interesting, but once you get out of the crud, it picks back up for a great finale.    After beating the second one, I moved on to the third game I am currently playing.  WOW!  Absolutely huge improvement in overall quality versus the first two games, but the story was a little... concerning.  You play as Patty's brother, whom there was NO mention of in the previous games.  However, a lot of the characters and towns from the previous games were here as well, and GREAT fun.  It's rare to find quality games like this, and if you are thinking about the game, definitely get it.  I wish there was a 4th game of this series coming out, but I need to start playing Witcher 1 up to 3 now.  LOL!  I don't understand the negative comments, but they are way off.  I do agree that there was a couple bugs, but they weren't game breaking.  I had one bug where I floated across the screen on the first board.  Then after death, I jumped back up and played as an immortal... don't know how, but when I spoke with a townsperson on Fog Island, I just died.  Hahaha!  Those were the bugs I noticed so far and only bugs so far.  I salute you Piranha Bytes.  Well done!

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												Why? Why Piranha Bytes, why must you hurt me like this?It's like you've taken the good parts of their older games and thrown them all out, while at best not doing anything about the bad parts, and at worst magnifying them, or even shoehorning new ones from other games in.The NPC Hubs, unlike the ones from about every Gothic game they made, seem empty and dead. The liveliest one is the Guardians big hold, but it's a single one, compared to the countless other ones that simply seem...barren. The inter NPC banter which made the towns in Gothic and Risen seem especially lively is almost completely missing, as is the ambiance that came with it. Most of the NPCs become completely meaningless, after you've done a sweep through their area and finished whatever quest they were involved in. Unlike the previous games, there are almost no quests that become available at a later point, making the gameworld seem even more devoid of life. Because apparently nothing happens while you're away.Choosing a faction also has almost no impact. There is only a handfull of faction-dependant perks, most of which carry little weight. Apart from that, faction dictates which set of spells becomes permanently available to you, but during one playthrough I found a sufficient amount of scrolls to make that meaningless as well. After that, the only thing left are AFAIK about 2 quests per faction that wouldn't be available without joining. There are almost no other reactions or consequences to your choice in faction. Though that might be rooted in the choice to have no conflict between the factions, which I think is a rather boring design choice. Along with the factions comes the comparable tiny variety of equipment. There is a miniscule selection of 3 sets of armor per faction and they don't have that much impact on gameplay, as the values of armor seem laughable (150 points of damage mitigation, of which about 115 are from character attributes and perks at the end of my playthrough).  Though there are a bit more weapons available, a good part of those are already useless at the point one can optain them. All special abilities and perks no longer cost any learning points. All that is left is an amount of gold one has to pay for them, which undoubtably enables players to get anything they want without any need for choice. And with the Potion Brewing Perk, which costs 2000 gold pieces, the upper half of the attribute scale becomes meaningless as well. Why invest experience points into enhancing an attribute past a value of 50, if one can instead do it with not that hard to get potions?The Sea-Battle minigame they implemented seems like a sloppy attempt of copying Assassins Creed's sea battles, but with only 3 instances happening, none of which are avoidable, I couldn't familiarize with it's mechanics enough to be particularily good. It thus simply became a chore, each one taking about 20 minutes of gametime, while not being any kind of fun or adding anything to the story. The other three minigames were less of a chore, but also weren't required at any point, which is a good thing I guess. Why the hell they decided to implement the seabattles, and do so the way they did still is beyond me.The other, more "puzzely" possiblities of the game were mostly ignored. The "trained monkey" sequences were few in number and rarely provided anything of value (only 2 times IIRC). Same goes with the "transform into Parrot" sequences. There was only a hand full of them, and most of them only provided mediocre loot. None of them were in any part needed for any quests, neither main nor side. In fact, there weren't even meaningful possiblities to use them during the mainquest. The final battle was (again) only a "whack the damage sponge" with the occasional "follow the damage sponge" which felt kinda anti-climatic.While you get seven possible followers, it's of little meaning which one of them you take with you. They simply didn't add that much, appart from distracting monsters during combat and only occasional lines of banter. The game simply never made me (as a player) care that much about them. Of the three followers that I never took along, there is one whom I never found out anything but his name and his fondness of Alcohol, one I only found out that he had gotten ret-conned into a cruel, mercyless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and one that only seemed to be fond of stealing things. Nothing else. Nothing upon which I could build any feelings towards these characters but disinterest.So I have to ask: What the hell went wrong at Piranha Bytes? Why did you build something so completely forgettable, so unbelievably mediocre, so underwhelmingly plain? You guys were the heroes of my youth. A small scale studio, making such incredibly awesome games. And now this... please Piranha Bytes, please stop slacking.Edit1: "PC Gamer: 83%"...guess thats where the money that would've improved chapters 3 and 4 went.

												Having played 14 hours of ther game, I've had to revise my opinion downwards.  Still a recommended deal if you can get it 75% off, but it's not worth full whack. It's a few steps improved over Risen 2, but sadly still suffers from jerky movement and scrolling control -- easy enough for the programmers to fix by upping the screen refresh, but they don't seem to take such suggestions on board, despite just about every review of earlier games going on about it.  As you progress through the learning curve, and get used to the awkward klunky combat control, you wait in constant expectation of the game getting better -- but it doesn't.  It's island hopping and running chores for NPCs who can't do simple tasks themselves.  "Rough round the edges", but for the discounted price, it's a steal.  Dialogue has clearly been recorded at different studio sittings rather than sequentially and often doesn't flow smoothly, or share environmental reverb effects, or even mesh sensibly.There's some minor humour in this dry game when Mud joins the team, but only because he's an annoying pest and a hindrance.  All integrity leaves the game if and when you choose to become a "Voodoo Pirate", that's just silliness, but alas it may be necessary to progress the levels if you can't make headway joining the mages.  Some quests won't resolve -- bugs in the code -- so don't expect to rattle through this one on autopilot.They've back-pedaled in gameplay processes to Risen 1, which it resembles a bit too much.  Worth investing in Risen 1 if you haven't got it, as it's the stand-out of the 3 games so far.

												It's a Pyranna Bytes open world RPG. It's got factions, day an night cycles and FLYING. (albeit as a Parrot). I went through my first run through as a Voodoo Pirate due to having the unlimited flying spell. This was one of my favorite features of the Might and Magic series and they included it in Risen 3. I hope PB keeps it for its upcoming games.The game does have its issues however. The number one being an over relience on arcadey sequences with its boss monsters. While not as bad as the Risen 1, they are still annoying having them in my RPGs. Why did they feel their games would be improved with that addtion. The game also had some irratating video sequences. They use the same brutal combat sequence for killing baddies as they do challanging an ally. It makes no sense for an ally to get up after you slit his throat . . .It make me ask the question, If your original template is the superior Gothic, what direction would you take to make the game better?The game world is fairly large but needed a wider diversity of monsters. And it needed more regular human monsters/bad guys. (Remember the bandit caves in Gothic 2)  The bullet shield was wortlhess becasue there simply aren't many baddies with guns. The cities needed more people and way way way more women. And while the game was mostly set in a carribean setting, I would have preferred a couple different climates. ( I admit a preference to snow)The UI is horrible. It needs more tabs. Some of the screen inforamation has to be scrolled when there is no need to such a thing. And some of the Voodoo Pirate magic is stored as a weapon and not as a spell. Those items should have been sold as wands not spells.Powergamers can easily have godly avatars by the mid game if they smartly allocate but since my avatars are usually well rounded (I allocate dumbly) I didn't achieve the near invulnerable status until the end game. Many powergames who achieved that early power, looked at the game as super easy. However that is "never" a problem with me because my main enjoyment of open world RPGS is exploration.  And this game does have it. And couple open world exploration with flying and this game many times had me in RPG nirvana.The moronic video combat sequences, the horrible UI and the far too many arcade sequences knock this game down a few notches. But the nicely implemented open world, the over all great voice acting, superior music all coupled with flying take away many of the flaws. I would rate this game 7.8 to 8.5.

Women are (aside from Patty, the protagonist's sister) extremely scarce, but what few there are seem to fall cleanly into 'witch' 'housewife' and [loose woman] stereotypes (the filter system does not let one use the normal english word for this.)  NPC and protagonist dialog includes numerous misogynistic remarks and 'jokes', with a few racist and homophobic ones thrown in as well.  This is a change from previous games, so I can only assume the the developers made a conscious effort to be more negative towards women and other minorities.  As this is a high-fantasy game with monsters, powerful mages, etc... any 'historical accuracy' excuse is mooted without consideration.  As a developer I find this sort of behaviour from a game designer unprofessional, cowardly, offensive, incompetent and embarrassing - at best. Because this is a change for the developers from previous games,  I cannot help but wonder if they have not made some serious internal errors in management allowing angry feelings in their staff develop into such such near-hateful content.  Development is hard - sometimes one ships a buggy, incomplete, and/or less than fun turd.  This is different as it was intentional; they published text, quests and, dialog, etc... expressing these sentiments. Ultimately the senior management of the firm is responsible for the sentiments expressed in their software, and holding them to this responsibitly for me requires not supporting the firm with my purchases again.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Don't let the metacritic rating fool you, but don't expect BioWare quality either.Risen 3 is a solid and competent roleplaying game.  Featuring a decent magic and combat system, interesting variations on "classess" (factions within the game), interesting and attractive environments, a good looting and gear system and a good chunk of play time, its a game that can be easily enjoyed with a little patience and forgiveness.  The leveling system is complex and interesting, asking you to increase stats to be able to learn perks and improvements to your combat abilities, which can be bought from trainers scattered all over the world.What is wrong with the game are niggles and annoyances more than bugs or bad concepts, and even then are only highlighted because we, as consumers, have come to expect things that aren't provided here.  For example, the story told in the game is threadbare and confusing, never coherently explaining what's going on or why we should care.  This is only exacerbated by the  dubious voice acting, particularly by your own character who speaks in a constant gruff monotone.  There are allusions to the past games that can make it even more confusing, such as a cameo by the past two games protagonist that should be foreshadowing and cool but is instead just strange.The dialogue options are not the range you would expect for an RPG, giving you little choice and little chance to actually roleplay, being limited to gruff piratey responses rather than varied.  The combat system takes some getting use to, and requires a combination of attack, dodge, parry and riposte, and enemies have a tendency to mob you even when there are other characters attacking them, resulting in a lot of constant dodging and pot shots until their ranks are thinned and you're back in control.  This can sometimes be exacerbated by clipping problems, or the mobile camera being blocked by scenery.Overall, Risen 3 is worth playing and enjoyable if your expectations aren't too high, and I would recommend playing it when the price drops to a level that is better value for money.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Forget Risen 2. Let it not bias you. Risen 3 is all you'd want from the Risens and the Gothics, too.GraphicsThe game is gorgeous. Sunlight/Godrays crash through the canopies of the trees; distant mountains cast their shadow on distant land realistically; fire never looked as good; water makes you want to jump right in; distant ruins beckon you to explore them; higher tier armour -- the cloth properly dancing as you move, the steel reflecting the light -- makes you drool as you stare at your hero. The physics engine is also fluid and realistic, enemies falling back after having received their killing blow will tumble over objects or droop down from them.GameplayIt's still what you expect from any Risen or Gothic game: The HUD is simple, and that's perfectly fine. In fact, I wouldn't have it any other way. You can now also change into a parrot with scrolls that you'll find everywhere -- specifically in high places! -- the devs silently begging you to use them as turning into a parrot makes you glide however long you want. There's a little energybar nonetheless which will slowly empty whenever you want to fly upward. It's fun! And as for the combat...CombatIt has improved SO MUCH! If you time your attacks properly, you can swing with heavy attacks almost as fast as you would with normal attacks. This needs some practise, but once you get a feel for it, it becomes easy. For some too easy, though many players still think combat is hard. As you gain enough experience (or Glory) you'll be able to gain the Riposte skill, which, if you time it right, your parry will execute a sweet animation of your hero evading a strike and counter-attacking with a strike of his own. You can also still dodge, which is an ability that can be exploited since there's no stamina bar. I say exploited, because during a dodge you're practically invincible. A fantastic addition to the combat is the finishing move on humanoids. When you kill the last enemy in an encounter, you watch your character execute him. There are multiple finishers. Your hero pushes an enemy against a wall, rams his weapon's hilt into the face multiple times before running him through; your hero turns the enemy around and slits his throat, etc. etc. etc. My most favorite finisher is where the enemy runs toward the hero and the hero steps aside at the last moment, leaving his weapon stretched horizontally in the enemy's path... the enemy runs into the blade, stumbles past the hero and eventually drops on the ground a few strides further, quite dead. Imagine stuff like this with a perfect physics engine. Yes, if there's a ledge a few strides behind your hero in said finisher, the enemy will stumble and drop down the edge instead. Deader than dead. So awesome.ExplorationThere's so much to see and do and find in this game! Almost every NPC with a name (which is almost every NPC) has a quest or more quests. When you climb up a mountain and see these mysterious places in the far, far distance... well, that telltale feeling rushes through every RPG player -- the feeling that says: I NEED to go there and explore every nook and cranny! And I can guarantee: You WILL be rewarded for it.Final verdictI love this game. I am not kidding. It's the best thing in the gaming world that has happened to me in YEARS. And that's coming from a guy who fell in LOVE with Gothic 1 & 2, Risen 1 and very much disliked Risen 2. I catch myself playing this game with a content smile on my face. It's crazy. This game is phenomenal!

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												Having played 14 hours of ther game, I've had to revise my opinion downwards.  Still a recommended deal if you can get it 75% off, but it's not worth full whack. It's a few steps improved over Risen 2, but sadly still suffers from jerky movement and scrolling control -- easy enough for the programmers to fix by upping the screen refresh, but they don't seem to take such suggestions on board, despite just about every review of earlier games going on about it.  As you progress through the learning curve, and get used to the awkward klunky combat control, you wait in constant expectation of the game getting better -- but it doesn't.  It's island hopping and running chores for NPCs who can't do simple tasks themselves.  "Rough round the edges", but for the discounted price, it's a steal.  Dialogue has clearly been recorded at different studio sittings rather than sequentially and often doesn't flow smoothly, or share environmental reverb effects, or even mesh sensibly.There's some minor humour in this dry game when Mud joins the team, but only because he's an annoying pest and a hindrance.  All integrity leaves the game if and when you choose to become a "Voodoo Pirate", that's just silliness, but alas it may be necessary to progress the levels if you can't make headway joining the mages.  Some quests won't resolve -- bugs in the code -- so don't expect to rattle through this one on autopilot.They've back-pedaled in gameplay processes to Risen 1, which it resembles a bit too much.  Worth investing in Risen 1 if you haven't got it, as it's the stand-out of the 3 games so far.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												It's a Pyranna Bytes open world RPG. It's got factions, day an night cycles and FLYING. (albeit as a Parrot). I went through my first run through as a Voodoo Pirate due to having the unlimited flying spell. This was one of my favorite features of the Might and Magic series and they included it in Risen 3. I hope PB keeps it for its upcoming games.The game does have its issues however. The number one being an over relience on arcadey sequences with its boss monsters. While not as bad as the Risen 1, they are still annoying having them in my RPGs. Why did they feel their games would be improved with that addtion. The game also had some irratating video sequences. They use the same brutal combat sequence for killing baddies as they do challanging an ally. It makes no sense for an ally to get up after you slit his throat . . .It make me ask the question, If your original template is the superior Gothic, what direction would you take to make the game better?The game world is fairly large but needed a wider diversity of monsters. And it needed more regular human monsters/bad guys. (Remember the bandit caves in Gothic 2)  The bullet shield was wortlhess becasue there simply aren't many baddies with guns. The cities needed more people and way way way more women. And while the game was mostly set in a carribean setting, I would have preferred a couple different climates. ( I admit a preference to snow)The UI is horrible. It needs more tabs. Some of the screen inforamation has to be scrolled when there is no need to such a thing. And some of the Voodoo Pirate magic is stored as a weapon and not as a spell. Those items should have been sold as wands not spells.Powergamers can easily have godly avatars by the mid game if they smartly allocate but since my avatars are usually well rounded (I allocate dumbly) I didn't achieve the near invulnerable status until the end game. Many powergames who achieved that early power, looked at the game as super easy. However that is "never" a problem with me because my main enjoyment of open world RPGS is exploration.  And this game does have it. And couple open world exploration with flying and this game many times had me in RPG nirvana.The moronic video combat sequences, the horrible UI and the far too many arcade sequences knock this game down a few notches. But the nicely implemented open world, the over all great voice acting, superior music all coupled with flying take away many of the flaws. I would rate this game 7.8 to 8.5.

I think you would all enjoy the Risen series, and I'm sad to see it end.
