content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												First of all, let me emphasize that this is a Piranha Game in all aspects. Which is good for me, but apparently does not fit well with some people.I started playing Piranha Games with Gothic 1 and played every game since, so I knew what to expect and am happy to report that the NPCs talk at length about trivial things and have to be forced to get to the point, you only get a fixed set of useful Armor that is restricted to your Group etc.A lot of people apparently don't like this, but for me that's a Piranha Game. If you liked the first two Gothics, this game is for you.Warning: From here on there might be SpoilersAs a long-time fan, here's what I think about Risen 3 compared to the Gothic series and the other two Risens:I loved it. It reminded my why I fell in love with Gothic and I am going to play it again to see the way the game goes if you choose to be something else then a Voodoo-Pirate.In comparison to Risen 2 I think it's much better. Which is great, as I thought Risen 2 was way better then Risen 1, so this seems to be a trend. Even the usually sucking Piranha Final Boss Battle was bearable. As a reminder, in Risen 1 the final Boss Battle neglected all your "life choices" and stuck you into magic Armor and Weaponry that made you a great fighter, even if you had gone the Mage way and put you into some kind of Arcade-Battle against a Big-Boss. Ugh.Risen 2 had Mara, but I only remember from that fight that I didn't like it.This time, it had sucking moments, sure. But I could play to my strengths I acquired during the game and at one point Bones jumped in to save the day, which I assume was a bug, but I liked it.Compared to the Gothic Series I dare say this is the game I was hoping for when Gothic 3 came out. It had all the charm, wits and anecdotes that made the first two Gothic Parts great and none of the empty world and hastily crafted Quests. Playing Risen 3 I couldn't but think of how great a game Gothic 3 could have been if it came out a year later. Even half a year. So all good? Of cause not. There are a lot of things they can do better and I hope they will for Risen 4. But none of the following "bad stuff" really impacted my great experience, so read them as "minor issues".The Bad stuff- I love the Kila, but hate the Post-Imperialistic, "noble savage", "half naked exotic beauty that speaks in Umpa-Lumpa" stile. You can do better than just throwing together all the cliche to mix up a "tribe". - Whatever happened to Patty? Why does she look like some Pirate-Porn Star? Honestly, this kind of "Fan Service" makes me feel treated like a 14 year old with a puberty issue. I see what you thought I would like and feel dirty. - Where's my Marvin Mode? One of the really cool things about Piranha Games was the "and now I will change everything to how I like it" Marvin Mode. Missed it greatly. Reduces replay-value. Basically, give me back my Marvin Mode. - If I have to hear Bones say "Aus deiner Haut mache ich mir eine Mütze!" one more time...- I would have liked a way to solve the Noise behind Paula's house without killing the armadillo.- Light. I know this does not happen to everyone, but every time I entered a cave darkness took me like a black flood that even torches could not dispense. Looting caves without telekinesis was basically impossible as I could not see anything smaller then a sword. - Story-restriction to Voodoo body-snatching. I get that this could be a story breaker, but there have to be better ways to restrict this then simply allowing it only if it fits the narrative. The "meh" StuffThese things I could go without* Astral View. Never used it. No idea why I would or should have. The Great Stuff+ The World. I liked to just hang out with the Pirates on Kila or the Kila on Kila (Reaaallly smooth...) or...+ The Characters. There are no Diegos, but a lot of likeable NPCs and taking some of them along was great fun.+ The Story. It was easy to follow without being too predictable. Yeah, there was obviously some arch-nemesis going to be there for the surprisingly minor-sucking End Battle, but other then that I liked it. Quests were mostly fun too.+ Easy mode that means "easy fights" for people like me who take fighting as a "have to do that" in RPGs+ Mud. Yeah, really. Loved it. Even took him along after he left on his own free will. That's how it goes with old “friends”...++ Parrot-Flight. You'll know it when you get it. I've spend hours flying around.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												The game starts off with a great opening.  A good way to introduce the basic movement and controls, easing into the free reign exploration without making the player go through long tedious tutorials.  The story premise and foreshadowing was at first engaging and did well to draw the player (or at least myself) into the story.  After the prologue however things  quickly nose diive.The sheer amount of recycled content was insulting.  From repeat fgihts with slightly skinned differences to outright repetition (dream vs actually happening ship battles) most of the game felt as if there was no creative mind behind it.  The story ended up rushed and in the end it seemed as if the game designers wanted it to be done even more than the players.  The "boss" fight at the end was also an extreme let down.  Frankly, I had a lot more fun fighting Mara in the previous game. The story sucked, outright.  Great premise, great idea, but a horrible execution.  All of that could be forgiven if it  was at least fun to play, but sadly, it was just boring.  Even an old school hack and slash game is more entertaining than this.  Character developement is also extremely limited.  There is very little if any real reason to upgrade more than one stat, based entirely upon your playing preference of course.  The varying skills all cap out at a flat 100 rating (105 with items).  The level up is handled very poorly with various permanent effect potions affecting the total amount of points needed to upgrade.  (bascially it costs x points at level 50 to go to 55, but use a +5 potion and you won't have enough points.. free level sorta, but now it costs more to keep going.  This creates a sort of optimum level barrier that depends on the number of potions you can find/craft.  I won't say it's detrimental, but it's certainly annoying.) Minor detrimental points also abound, from dialog errors, to quests that jump ahead before you get them, to the wonderous fall damage that can occur if you go off the beaten path (I mean falling through objects).  Give me the first Risen over this anyday.  I whole heartedly cannot recommend this game to anyone.  I would say avoid. If you're a fan of the mechanics or the "story" of the Risen world, give it a shot.. but othewise, avoid. Sadly, there's really nothing for most people in the game.** Last note: Risen 2 introduced a foul mouthed gnome.  Sadly, he seemed to have tempered his tongue a bit in Risen 3, limiting his swearing, but he's still the only good point in the whole game.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												Overall a decent, but not great, game.If you played and enjoyed Risen or Risen 2 (or any of the Gothic games, for that matter), this game will feel immediately familiar. It continues with the pirate-y themes from the second, which I wasn't crazy about, but it didn't take away from the game too much for me.The gameplay mechanics are solid enough, and the graphics are decent. The voice acting and dialogue is almost all hilariously terrible, and the story is pretty poor, but I still found myself enjoying playing it.Honestly, there are better games out there. There are better games trying to do this exact same thing that you could play instead. I tend to have a soft spot for wonky European RPG games though, so take this recommendation with that in mind.In the end, should you play this? Maybe. Did you play and like the other ones, and did you want more of that? If yes, get this. You know what you're getting in to. Do you just want an open world RPG and haven't played one before? You can probably find better options. If you're looking for deep character customization or a great story, you'd be better off looking elsewhere.Still, not bad. I enjoyed it and it's lengthy enough.

Posted: June 5, 2016
												I feel like they aimed to make a worse game every time they made a Risen game.  Risen 1 was very good and wasn't fantastic but it wasn't garbage.  Risen 2 was really trashy but kept my attention and I was able to get through it and enjoy the story.  But this game.  Oh my god I have never had a worse combat experience ever.  Game says you can chain 3 hits.  No you can not at all.  2 hits fairly easily but the 3rd will always be interupted by an enemy attack and even power attacking enemy block will just cause them to hit you first or roll away instead.  Combat ends up being this really slow boring grind of slash roll slash roll.  Theres no real strat as you get frames when you roll even if the attack hits you.  It feels like it tried to be a budget darksouls combat system and ended up just being trash.  Story is meh.  Not much to say but pirates and feels like a recycled plot from the second game but much more watered down.  Only play if your fan of the games already otherwise the completely garbage combat system will upset you.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												This is one of my first reviews for a game on steam, so I will try my best to cover the pros and cons of Risen 3. I will bring the conclusion at first, so that people searching for an indicator may find my judgment without reading the whole text. IMPORTANT: This games has problems with some CPUs or system configurations! - It won't work in some cases!! - Therefore, consult the PB forum for more information!Conclusion: This game is not worth 50 €/$. Let me be me ore specific: For fans of Risen it may be a must have, but for all others that are looking for a good/excellent rpg game which provides you with tons of quests, variety, a good combat system, polished gameplay and game engine, Risen 3 should not be your choice. The graphics engine is really old, textures are not provided in a high resolution, and even the world design (even if it is really good) cannot hide the shortcomings of the really old engine. The designers tried their best but the engine does not provide enough features to create a fully living world and this is experienced in the very first moments you enter the jungle in Risen 3. This fact is reflected if you take a closer look at the scene. The models are, how shall I say, really really bad; no (face) gestures at all, animations are choppy.  Another very important aspect of an RPG is the combat system. This is the biggest shortcoming of Risen 3. First, it is completely unbalanced. In the early stages of the game each creatures might be your death, later on you feel like god and nothing can really kill (except you head for a coffee and it takes you 5 minutes until you come back ...). Second, the factions are more or less a nice to have but after you have learned the most "skills" the spells earned by the factions are just for fun and do not seriously influence the combat.Detailed Review:Impressions/Opinion:I have to admit, I am a very big fan of Gothic 1 & 2. One reason that I bought the game were the reviews that are provided by computer magazines. In fact it was the "open world" which disappointed me already in the beginning of the game. I felt somehow cheated because the game has not the freedom as a Gothic 1 or 2. It still fells like Risen 2. NO, there is no "open world" or freedom in the game, except the selection of the so-called factions. The game follows a strict chapter system and islands are quite linear. The world does not feel like its living. If you have cleared/killed all creatures on an island, you are done, there is nothing left to kill and there will nothing respawn (that’s it). Sure, there are a lot of side quests but there is no real difference between the main story and the side quests. I have played many RPGs but I seldom come across such a bad story telling. The "quests" are very generic like, "kill x", "bring me xyz". It feels like playing an really old RPG in 2014. If you have seen the 5 (including the first one where you start and are brought back to "life") main islands, which are not that big as it looks like in the beginning, there won't come any more (SPOILER: a sixth island at the end for the very last fight/quests). The combat system is useless at its best. In the early game it feels like every creature may be the last creature you will face and after the first 4 hours you get so strong that fights become just a necessity and does not feel like an epic fight. I won't talk about boss fights because they are not really any better but writing about them may spoiler one or two things. But, bosses are just like events, nice to watch. A real challenge is the gameplay and that you do not fall off some shores or edges if you are hunting for hidden places...Technical discussion:There is not much positive to say. As already mentioned in the conclusion the engine is old and the models are far from state-of-the-art, such as in Witcher 2 or BioShock Infinite. The models are definitely missing vertices, such as the terrain and everything in this game. The textures have a really low resolution and sometimes they look awkward and misplaced. Furthermore, the game crashes from time to time (if it even decides to run on your system).  The animations of the models are really choppy and are not that smooth as someone may expect for a game that was released mid 2014. Last words:I am just curious why this game got such good review from computer magazines. This game is just a refresh of Risen 2 with some really MINOR improvements. In fact, its more like a joke for 2014. PB you could have done way better and you know it!Fans will buy it anyway, but all the others should think twice!

												So ive beaten the game. My end cutscene went to play and the character starts walking to the camp on skull island. It looked like Bones was going to say something but before he could it cut to the ship sailing out of the island. So if i want that end sequence ive got to kill the end boss again which is ok i never got anything from the story in this game so I will wait for someone to upload it on youtube. So complaints.1) Combat starts off very slow, this is the only game ive ever played where you absolutely rely on your companion to kill things when you first start. 2) Combat requires no skill. You can cheese almost every fight effortlessly there is little to no reward to killing anything except for the 3rd Kraken which is the only truely frustrating part of the game.3) Glitches, Oh my god glitches i felt like I was playing an Alpha of Risen 3 mind you none of these glitches caused a blue screen, full system crash, or crash of game. 4) Guidance at times is at an absolute bare minimum. I consider myself an Intelligent person and I found myself frustrated more then a few times even after listening to all dialog options. My most annoyed moment would be the Books of Evil quest from the Demon hunters for your first promotion.5) Dialog was often incredibly annoying and no I am not talking about the Gnomes their dialog was intended to be absolutely annoying. Thankfully right clicking cured this for me just dont do it during a quest giver.6) Cutscenes throughtout the game are soooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo excessive and not in a good way like Metal Gear Solid 4's 7 or 8 hours of cutscenes, Most cutscenes in this game are clearly rushed everything from key speakers faces blurring out to horrible choices of background music which most of the time sounded incredibly close to the fight music.7) Enemy Diversity is bleh. I also took note of the spiders working with the shadows on skull island. Was mostly confused by that considering the Oracle was using them to attack both humans and shadows from what that whole ♥♥♥♥ty story explained.8) Most points of the game I would complete quests like allying with the Inqusition and it had a moment to do a cutscene or give dialog options and it wouldnt. So when you kill Sebastion it just cutscenes to your boat pulling into its destination and your character saying well they will fight for us. There felt like a lot of information was just skipped over it felt like listening to an average 5th graders explination of their family vacation. There were holes all throughout leaving you wanting much more. I just wanted a "Hey thanks for saving us from that crazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ i thought he was going to kill me next.".9) Some skills pop up as weapons in your equipment page whereas some skills like Monkey Trainer pop up as an Item in your inventory so you have to dig and find them. I for instance forgot I had monkey trainer which actually would have been helpful much earlier on in the game but when you buy skills theres no hey idiot your skill is right here when its not going to be in the normal place.So in closure I still will not recommend this game until it goes on sale. Regardless of my complaints I did find myself having fun with Demon Hunter skills stacked with blade dancer and how OP they make you if you are melee built. I barely died at all with all of them being in the same spot the 3rd Kraken.This is one of the few games Ive played and gotton bored while playing... I had literally more fun in Aliens Colonial Marines then this and that was a flaming POS with a much better written story.5/10 its very "Meh"

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Its not bad. (you could stop there. Medicore but fun would also do. Feels a bit small at times in terms of real estate to explore but still a better job than many similar crossover / ports.  It is also not so heavily burdened by a terrible field of view as you play in third person and the character doesnt take up the whole screen. Somehow, despite having a fair bit of choice in your direction it still feels pretty linear at times.  Mainly because the areas are  path driven channelling you where your probably meant to be.  Calling it a free roam is pushing it as it is actually far smaller than it appears but true enough.  I have to mention the combat.  It feels pretty awful  early on in the game.  However, if you played the Risen series before it will be familiar.  A positive for the combat is that you do need to consider your timing and enemies are a little more unpredictable, on the other hand, until you develop, your personal skill is less important than building up your character.  It can be very frustrating early on but it does improve a bit as you progress. The NPCs are very wooden and tend to be just standing around doing nothing 99% of the time but the voice acting is pretty good. Characters do have a habit of sounding like one another but then again, they probably would when they are supposed to be from the same place. A little corny, a little mediocre but undoutedly fun.   Annoying that it cant fully utilise PC hardware (you have to switch off anymore than 8 threads or cores but to be honest, the graphics while pretty enough are nothing special so its probably not using half of what it could on a good rig anyway.  I am guessing here but this is a fairly typical console style light weight RPG that is beyond the average for a console RPG but cant match with more open PC RPG's or heavily modded crossovers such as Skyrim.  All things considered  it is worth a bit of a romp through. Is it worth buying?  For me, yes..   It has been a slow year so you on one hand you could say, what else is there?  It does have a fair bit of content and unlike the likes of Witcher 2 will have a little more longevity (I would certainly rate it far higher than TW2 as I like open world games).

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												The only reason I am not recommending this game is it's price tag... the quality of this game is NOT up to par with other titles in the $49.99 price range. I purchased the game during the Holiday sale when it was $24.99, and personally, I believe that's about what this game is worth. I'll list off some things that bothered me and, yes, I understand I've only played the game for about an hour... but that hour alone gave me enough "feel" for the game to know that I simply do not enjoy playing it and I probably will not boot it up again. 1. The intro was rushed, and it felt cheap and plagurized.A. You start off on a boat sailing to who knows where, from who knows where (possibly this information is known if you've played Risen 2, which I haven't, but I still had no idea what was going on in the beginning of the game), and seemingly out of no-where, you're attacked by pirate sea creatures STRAIGHT out of Pirates of the Caribbean. I don't have the slightest doubt in my mind that the artists had pictures from PotC up on google as they designed these guys. B. During this intro, the game briefly shows you how to move and look around, jump, attack, unsheath your weapon, shoot your gun, dodge, etc. The controls just feel off to me. If this makes sense, which I hope it does to some of you out there; there are just some games out there with controls so fine-tuned that you could do an obsticle course, jump from object to object, avoid things swinging at you, etc, with ease (think TF2, CS:GO, CoD, Skyrim). In this game there is no way in hell I would be able to jump from object to object or dodge ANYTHING, the controls feel that lousy and unsynced. A side note added onto that... when I hold down the sprint key... I want to sprint NOW, not after a delay of 1 second.2. The story. (FIRST HOUR SPOILER)From what I understood, you're a pirate on a jouney with your sister who, by coincidence, has huge jugs, The intro lets you play through getting attacked by a ship of sea creature pirates captained by a "Ghost pirate"... who, after losing all of his men onboard to your sword, summons Gyarados which ♥♥♥♥s your♥♥♥♥♥♥up and you're stranded on an Island straight out of the TV series "Lost". It then seems your objective is to find or chase down the pirate ghost... at least for the beginning part of the game. I didn't get that far.  3. Voice acting.Imagine the worst home made movie you've ever seen, then imagine paying those people each $1,000 to actually try to act. That's about what the voice acting is like.4. Looting, "Open world", other RPG elements.A. The looting system is very off from traditional RPGs. Yes, I get games can be different from others, etc, and that's cool, that's awesome, but not having a menu pop up when you go to loot a creature and instead having it auto loot everything and spam the side of your screen RECIEVED SPIRIT MUSHROOM x 1 !RECIEVED RAW MEAT x 1 !RECIEVED CLAM x 1 !RECIEVED GOLD x 1000!GLORY + 200can get annoying. Strangely enough, however, if you go to loot a container, you ARE given a menu and the choice to loot whatever's in the container. B. Despite claiming to be open world, the game is still very linear. To put into perspective, Skyrim is the obvious king of open world games, you can literally go ANYWHERE. The Witcher 2, on the other hand, is pretty linear, and isn't necessarily open world. This game isn't remotely close to The Witcher 2, and is about as linear as a CoD campaign. C. Other RPG elements such as how the inventory is managed, quests, maps, etc... it all works, but it all feels cheap and rushed. In conclusion, the Risen fanboys will hate me and my review, but crossing over from other RPG's like the Elder Scrolls series, the Diablo series, the Borderlands series, etc, I was not prepared for the incredibly, insultingly, low quality of the game. TL;DR: If you're coming from Skyrim, Borderlands, Diablo, Mass Effect, The Witcher... (all high quality and finely tuned RPGs), and looking for something new whilst staying in the RPG scene, stay away from Risen 3.

Little things like:* speaking to someone and having no option to end the conversation among the multiple choices when its super easy to accidentally talk to someone* speaking to people accidentally because loot and speak are the same buttonIn conclusion Risen 3 is a pretty good example of the old saying "Don't judge a book by its cover". Because the cover looks lovely. But the game sucks.(Think my conflict must be because some people rated it well so it might get better later...don't think I'll ever try to find out after the bit I played though).

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												I find Risen 3 to be a very atmospheric experience. Pirahna Bytes seem to have a knack with created well thought out land masses that you can remember and recall, long after leaving.I have played Gothic, Gothic II, Risen and Risen 2 to completion multiple times. The Gothic series is one of those gems that just never gets old, no matter how long time goes by.But, to Risen 3.10 hours in, Risen 3 is definitely the best of the Risen franchise. Combining multiple islands and quests seamlessly, without much interuption. Including the old Faction based quests and pursuits. Creating the well known atmosphere of past PB games.I was scepticle, once I saw the piratey beginning. Felt exactly like Risen 2, which I did like, but not as much as I wanted to. Then after a short introduction on an island, things change and open up incredibly. Like, choose anywhere, and go. And you can swim between many points on each island, yes!  Each island holds a different feel and attitude. With different characters and ideologies. Characters have there own agendas and ideas, which I am enjoying. They have added many dialogue sequences dependant on the character that is following you, or location you have entered, or who you're talking to. I have replayed dialogues with diffferent characters, with some interesting dialogue responses, that can change the way the charater interacts with you. Makes them feel more believable. Combat has it's flaws, but is ultimately enjoyable. Some (me) may find it easier then traditional Gothic combat, but animations and cues are properly executed this time around. No more countering, and finding nothing happens, even though you were perfectly timing the counter. It just works. And crystal magic. GREAT. Really fun stuff.Although fetch quests are prominent, I enjoyed walking between points, as to me, the game looks great.I have read many reviews stating that this game looks like a PS2 game, or that it is downright horrible. I think it has a very unique style and artistic flow, that combines many new systems that enhance the overall aesthetic. Also, the lighting, looks incredible. Some scenes are truly breathtaking. Yes, there is certain instances, where the game looks kind of funky, but to base the entire graphical experience on these minor flaws is downright stupid.Anyway, I feel this game is a step in the right direction for Pirahna Bytes.Though, I would love to see a brand new series, more akin to the Gothic series pop up. Anyway, great job team! Thank you! :D

The actual main quest that should keep me playing took me about 3 hours. Doing all side quests and explore all the unimportant stuff took me about 48 hours (DLCs included). I have to say that I was not entertained by all this useless exploring and sidequesting.- It is better than the second risen game but it is still a bad sequel to the first game. I have no idea why in the world this game takes place in the southern sea while the actual action takes place on the mainland. The story has no real direction and is totally disappointing. I would expect something magnificent from the third part of a storyline. Until now I am not even sure who or what Titan Lords/Ladies are. - I finished the game 5 days ago and I cannot remember 99% of the characters. content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												This is one of the worst RPGs I ever played with the most infuriating combat system ever.  I'm glad I got this on the sale as I would be extremely annoyed had I paid the full RRP for this trash.  First off the voice acting on the main character is the worst I have ever heard on any game, let alone an RPG.  It is truly dreadful and the writing is just as bad, it is like some 12 year old who just learnt the F word had written the script.  Within only an hour or 2 of playing the bad voice acting and writing had already started to grate one me.Then there is the truly awful combat system.  The tutorial shows you how to parry and do combos and is set up so you can do that in the tutuorial but good luck actually trying to do that in the game.  For a start parrying seems to have no effect on beasts like rock spiders and scavengers so the combat ends up with constant dodging and then hitting the LMB to get a quick slash of the sword in which takes precious little health off whatever you are fighting in the beginning before you are dodging again.  This isn't challenging, it is extremely tedious when it seems to take near enough 20 hits to take out various creatures at the start of the game.  It doesn't lend itself well when you are outnumbered either as sooner or later you end up rolling into a strike from 1 of the 3 enemies you end up being surrounded by frequently.  Then of course if you happen to dodge in to vegetation you can't see what is going on resulting in being struck again.  Your character is also slow to respond to the LMB and often gets hit before completing the strike and yet your enemies seem to be able to jump backwards at alarming speed so many of your strikes don't hit home.  This makes one on one tedious enough but being outnumbered even more so and I quickly found myself going through provisions and rum, even on the easy setting just because I don't have the patience to spending an hour on each fight constantly dodging and rolling around the place. I don't get the reviews complaining how OP your character gets - I found him hideously underpowered at the start just trying to do the tedious quest of going to all the mines in order to join the guardians when having to go through seemingly undending rock spiders, shadow warriors and hellhounds.  After just 4 hours playing I have had enough of the game already with the immensely repetitive dodge/strike nonsense.The only positive is that the game does look nice but with the dreadful combat system and equally bad voice acting (at least from the main character) I can't recommend this game, in fact I would save time and money and don't buy it in the first place.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												DO NOT LISTEN TO PROFESSIONAL REVIEWS, IGN and Gamespot both gave this game deceptively bad reviews. I will say that I watched some reviews whining and complaining on how bad this is or how "average" this is but I recommend you get the game on sale if you're uneasy about it. I received it as a gift and I personally think it's been unjustly panned by reviewers. The combat has a learning curve but when you get used to the timing, it can be pretty fun. The story is kinda crazy, most of the characters are nicely voiced with unique attitudes (The shaman is really weird though), but there are moments when you will see a characters face that resembles a previous character you have encountered. Some voices seem off in how the dialog is delivered and the shaman, though funny at times, can get repetitive with his one liners during combat. There is a ton of content in this game and surpirsingly the graphics look quite nice though not mindblowing as this is also on PS3. Thankfully the PC version looks and performs much better (Duh). For those who want fluid smooth animations though, you may not like the attack animations, though it's not as bad as demonicons slo-mo loaded combat. Some may also be put off by the need for gold to learn skills, but you can find places in this game where they basically throw gold at you, if you take on a lot of side quests. The story has a sort of pirate theme but it's overall a means to an end. If you want a blockbuster story, you won't find it here. You may find great gameplay and hours of quests to kill time, but not much hand holding. The map is a very appreciated addition over Risen 2, I found it frustrating that Risen 2 lacked a map, making pathfinding really tedious.You also have 3 factions to choose from, each with unique abilities and gameplay. Overall, there are a lot of reasons to give Risen 3 a try, save for the so-so story.Gameplay:8Graphics:8Story:7.5Sound/Voice:7Replayability:8Overall:8

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												I'm a big fan of the original Gothic Series, and I quite enjoyed Risen 1 & 2, but this last installment was mostly disappointing.pro:- Nicely build world with O.K. graphics and good atmosphere- PB-style dialogues and story, if you are into itcons:- REALLY ANNOYING combat system. I appreciate that they tried something new other than the mindless "click-to-death"-system of earlier games, but this time they just failed. Instead of attack-spamming you have to keep spamming evasion rolls, the combat often feels random and parrying is a game of chance, even the most basic critters attack really fast and without a telltale sign. The melee targeting system does'nt work out at all: When you fight more than two enemies simultaneously, it is almost impossible to target a specific individual, so that it is just a random chaotic beating in all directions. Often you hit in a direction where there is no enemy at all, or the focus stays on a recently killed enemy.- Balancing is crap. Some boss fights are extremely unfair if you do not posess certain skills or magic spells (the Margoloth fight for example).Although I love the general PB-retro-charme of the game, I can not recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
 Risen 3 - Titand Lords(Scroll down for a tl;dr version.)As a fan of the classic Gothic series I was really looking forward for this game, since I heard that Piranha Bytes got back the rights of the Gothic series. And also, when I started playing this game, I was not disappointed regarding this aspect; I was amazed by all the elements and jokes that I knew from Gothic. Finally, I could fight some Scavengers again. But this is not what makes it a good game. Actually, I was uncertain about liking or disliking the game.Pros: + Level/map design: There are caribbean-like islands in the south, and "not-so-sunny" islands, like an island with swamp, a somehow big forest or partially wasteland (with lava and burnt down trees) + Very much related to the previous point: Exploration. I am pretty sure that I did all possible quests, that I collected every piece of loot, and I did not even get tired of it. And still there was room for more, because it did not use the parrot a lot. + Incredible high amount of quests + The fractions: I liked the division of the voodoo pirates, the wardens and the demon hunters. Not only stupid bad guys from king's army and good guys from the rebels. + They finally gave me some Gothic-feeling again:  E.g. you can screw around with some peasants or Jack who was kicked out of his light-house, like in Gothic II. + Something that I found out too late: The evil dialog options are really funny. I really laughed when I was mad at some of the gnomes. (E.g. the one that is enslaved, where you could go and tell him "Sorry, but I needed the money." After you got paid for not telling anybody that he is enslaved.)Cons: - The so called "story": Like in Risen 1, the end of the game feels artificially stretched. Risen 2 did this far better. Not only this, the story is just weak in total. - Combat system - Difficulty level far too low( - Despite the environment's variety, there is no snow level :'( )Risen 3 is, in my opinion, not a milestone in the history of RPGs. But it does quite a good job. Also, I would not have thought about thumbs down, if there wasn't this horrible last island. Why did the developers think like "For the end of the story, let's build the f***ing largest island, tell the hero that time is running out so bad, but still there is time to run from one side of the island to the other, just to find some camps, that aren't even useful." Seriously Piranha Bytes, what the f**k? Moreover, you (the developers) could have just let Eldric and the other two die. I really would have prefered it in this way. But no, even in the hardest fight in the history of humans, no "important" characters dies (excluding Horas). That is a childish story. But I was able to spend around 70 hours of fun with that game, which I pretty much like (Until now I spend 80h playing this game. So 10h of "not-fun".)Sorry, if you expected more Gothic related information. In the draft I had much of this stuff, but I decided to remove these things more or less completely. I think I would have to replay Gothic I and II, to being capable of giving a fair review.TL;DRDid you enjoy playing Risen and Risen 2? Then you will most likely also enjoy this game. Because Risen 3 feels like a good extension to the pirate setting of Risen 2. If you don't like becoming a pirate or a voodoo priest, just become a mage or demon hunter, which I think are like the dragon hunters from Gothic II.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												DO NOT LISTEN TO PROFESSIONAL REVIEWS, IGN and Gamespot both gave this game deceptively bad reviews. I will say that I watched some reviews whining and complaining on how bad this is or how "average" this is but I recommend you get the game on sale if you're uneasy about it. I received it as a gift and I personally think it's been unjustly panned by reviewers. The combat has a learning curve but when you get used to the timing, it can be pretty fun. The story is kinda crazy, most of the characters are nicely voiced with unique attitudes (The shaman is really weird though), but there are moments when you will see a characters face that resembles a previous character you have encountered. Some voices seem off in how the dialog is delivered and the shaman, though funny at times, can get repetitive with his one liners during combat. There is a ton of content in this game and surpirsingly the graphics look quite nice though not mindblowing as this is also on PS3. Thankfully the PC version looks and performs much better (Duh). For those who want fluid smooth animations though, you may not like the attack animations, though it's not as bad as demonicons slo-mo loaded combat. Some may also be put off by the need for gold to learn skills, but you can find places in this game where they basically throw gold at you, if you take on a lot of side quests. The story has a sort of pirate theme but it's overall a means to an end. If you want a blockbuster story, you won't find it here. You may find great gameplay and hours of quests to kill time, but not much hand holding. The map is a very appreciated addition over Risen 2, I found it frustrating that Risen 2 lacked a map, making pathfinding really tedious.You also have 3 factions to choose from, each with unique abilities and gameplay. Overall, there are a lot of reasons to give Risen 3 a try, save for the so-so story.Gameplay:8Graphics:8Story:7.5Sound/Voice:7Replayability:8Overall:8

												After the very mediocre Risen 2, I was wary if Risen 3 was worth a look. And I am happy to say that it really is. If you liked Risen 1 and the Gothic series, then you will probably like this one too. The mostly very pretty world feels as lived in and gritty as ever, the combat system has improved greatly and exploring the different islands is fun. Quest design could be more interesting though - almost every one is a variation of "fetch x and murder y on the way".A lot of the atmosphere comes from the rough and quirky voice acting, which is excellent in German, but truly miserable in the English version. If you know German, that's the way you should play it.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Risen 3 is laughably bad. For a few minutes I thought it might be a parody game, a Sharknado of gaming where the developers were intentionally trying to make things as laughbaly awful as possible. Terrible voice acting, stilted animations, laggy and boring combat and a generally unprofessional polish and feel. The graphics are bizarre; the game came out in 2014 yet somehow looks much, much older. The environments are passable, but the character models are stilted and poorly put together. The interaction with my "companion", an entity that a 13 year-old boy would find over-sexualized, was, like the rest of the game, stilted and awkward. She spent much of her time pointing out glaringly obvious gameplay mechanics. I lasted a half-hour. I cannot imagine the game improved even marginally after that. If this was a game made by a couple of college students for a senior-level games programming class, then I have been overly harsh. Otherwise, this effort is an embarrassment and to date the only Steam game where I have asked for a refund.

												A marked improvement over Risen 2, however there are still some areas that need work on. Combat animations are way too long, making it that most enemies can stun lock you without you being able to break out of it. Most of the quests are fetch/kill X amount quests and I'm pretty sure the main character has throat cancer (Although this might be a positive since it means Piranha Bytes give jobs to cancer vicitms) The exploration is still rock solid and fun, movement is fluid, the story is really good and the magic system is back and better than ever. I got this game for $5.99 and I didnt regret until the update gave me all the dlc's then brok my save's by removing them. Hopefully deep silvr and PB fix this so i can change my rating to positive, since i like this game.Edit: The problem has finally been fixed. PB has given everyone with the issue the dlc for free and now I can go back to enjoying the game.

												First of all i have played and enjoyed risen 1, and played about 20mins of the demo for risen 2 (hated it, just couldnt get into it,) but risen 3 on the other hand is amazing. I highly reccommend this game to anyone who enjoys rpg's or open world games. I pre ordered this game because it looked quite promising and it highly exceeded my expectations. There are tons of areas to explore. The game is broken up into islands, all which have a good variety of enviornments, enemies, people, ect. There are different factions which you choose to join in the game and each gives you a unique playstyle, and quests so there is need for replayability. The game is filled with tons of quests, and many which are quite enjoyable, not the typical oh go here and collect 10 tree roots and get a reward kind of quests. There is tons of dialoge in this game and the voice acting isnt perfect but its quite acceptable in my opinion, they throw in humor sometimes too which is great. This game has a really good atmosphere to it, someting which i enjoyed about risen 1. Soundtrack in this game is also superb. A neat twist to this game as well, you use a ship to travel from island to island, and sometimes there are random encounters and you'll have to fight off enemy ships or sea monsters. The combat in the game is a little clunky, but it just took some time getting used to. Once you build your strength abit it becomes much more enjoyable, its just a little tough in the beginning. I usually dont take the time to write reviews, but i am enjoying this game very much, and since its an rpg theyre automatically competing with the big companies that make skyrim, dragon age, ect. So im happy to voice my opinion of the game for others to see and hopefully they will give it a try.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2014
												Phiranna Bytes may not be earning awards for stability, but they delivered again on a game that explains why they have produced three of my favorite RPGs.  In the spirit of the original two Gothic's, and the original Risen is an open-ended and rather buggy adventure for RPG enthusiasts, with a layer of modern polish and features that really brings it to life.  The game is rough around the edges, but has more personality and charm than you'll get out of the latest Dragon Age.  It harkens back to a time when people were more concerned with what they could do than how it looked to be doing it.Once you get through the fairly standard 'tutorial' and intro sequence, the game opens up.  You are free to make mistakes and follow the story at your own leisure and choosing.  This means you can go places you shouldn't be and do things that make your life harder.  This isn't a point-and-click follow the dotted line adventure, this time you are in charge with nothing more than your sense of adventure and desire to explore to fuel you.  Thanks PB!  After Risen 2 I was skeptical, but you've put those fears to rest.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												People complain about the characters being boring, the dialogs and voice acting being bad, I don't mind that. I don't mind a mediocre 3rd person RPG, I enjoy them anyway.What really ticks me off is the extremely unbalanced melee combat of this game. I mean, what the hell? Every enemy attacks faster than the hero. The hero first has to swing his blade for even a standard attack. This gives the enemys plenty of time to attack themselves. Basically, the hero needs about one second to commence a standard attack, while an enemy needs half the time. Thus you can expect the enemy to hit you during your attack, interrupting it.Enemies do combo attacks, meaning they will knock you back and onto the ground without you being able to do anything. Even on the starting island, I spent more time laying on the ground than actually doing anything. Feels strongly reminescent of the boars from Gothic 3. Only in Risen 3, pretty much every enemy is a boar.Now imagine fighting enemies in groups.As long as there isn't some proper balancing here, I can't recommend this game.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												If you really liked Risen 1 & 2 and/or the Gothic series, try it. But don't go in there with somewhat high expectations.The story is something between AC4 and Pirates of the Caribbean. Not deep, not shallow, not very original. The phrasing of Quests didn't impress me positively. I'm sure there would've been another way than "Next Quest: Pull on the lever". "Open the temple door" could've sounded a little tiny bit better.I'm playing with a controller (don't give me♥♥♥♥♥♥for that, it's easier to handle than a mouse with a wrist beyond repair), and it's just frustrating.Controls are clunky and it's responding late or not at all sometimes. Press the block button - get hit - block. Dodging in the direction you want? Eeeh, I'll try my best and- whoops got hit. I ended up spamming the Dodge button in every fight.Have your weapon drawn and want to open a door or pick up loot? No. Away with your weapon, manually. In a painfully slow animation. Something attacks you and is already in your face? Press B. Then A. Got hit? Too bad. Kind of like the chinese blackmarket rip-off of Assassin's Creed's combat.The camera's jerking around making it almost impossible to adjust it to your likings: A slight tilt to the left with the joystick results in a complete turn around-up-down-left-right making it stupidly hard to see or hit any enemy. Even without your doing, it'll just zoom in or out at the worst times. Fighting in a tight spot and dodging, against a wall because you can't really control the direction, and you're done for. It's no help to have a close up on that stone behind me, really.Lots of unneccesary small cut scenes. Opening a chest is fine, but I do not need to see the same kneeling down-opening chest-looking inside every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ time. They tried to make a kill cam as well, but it only takes time and isn't anything special. I'd rather do without. Accidentally facing Patty and pressing A results in yet another short cut scene whereas she tells you 'Not now, later' most of the time. Voice acting makes it all the worse. First look, the world looks like it's been modelled with lots of love. Second look, not so much. The screenshots are deceiving in my opinion - I just recently built this PC. The best of the best, because I like nice looking games, and i certainly want them to run smoothly.This however, I could play on my Mothers Laptop and it would still look the same. The highest settings are a joke. It's atmospheric, don't get me wrong, But not aesthetic. If you told me that this game came out in 2008, I'd believe you.And OH MY GOD how slow do you have to walk. That is ridiculous. Running ain't better.

Definition of clunkyIs this the worst RPG ever? Well, maybe it‘s not the worst. I heard about Raven‘s cry and it‘s re-release Vendetta which now is taken from steam too, but because of awful user feedback i did not even consider to support that scam of a game. This one on the other hand has plenty of good reviews and feedback. But how? Probably from the people who only played Piranha Bytes  games?Since the Gothic 3 Piranha Bytes are making horrible games. I remember Gothic 3, it was beautiful looking game at the time, but it had worst combat ever and messed up quest system, i just stopped playing that crap after a few hours.I did not play Risen and only tried Risen 2 for an hour or so and uninstalled it. Risen 3 titan lords is a very strong contender for the worst combat in an RPG game. It‘s like Piranha Bytes do this intentionally, just to irritate people.The combat makes this game unplayable. It‘s absolutely broken. Your moves are so slow that you just can‘t hit anything, you slowly swing your sword and get interrupted by the enemies attack. If you try to block them and attack after blocking, the enemy just jumps away in a speed of lightning and you miss, then immediately you get attacked again. Blocking does not always work, i‘d say you can‘t block 1/3 of attacks. You/enemies getting stuck on a rock, or camera rotating randomly to the angle where you can‘t see anything is nothing compared to awful combat. The controls are unresponsive and clunky, your character is very slow. In addition to the sword you can shoot a gun which again is so slow that you get attacked by an enemy which moves and react too fast before you shoot the gun. And if you get lucky to use your gun without interruption it misses most of the time even if the enemy is 2 meters away. But there are things which will make you laugh instead of being angry. The voice acting, it‘s hilarious, i don‘t know if it‘s intentional but it‘s so bad that it‘s making you laugh. Generic NPC‘s have better voice acting than main characters.Dialogues are boring and uninteresting. Same as quests. It is generic as it can be. Also quest tracking doesn‘t work most of the time. The map is pointless, NPC's or shops aren't marked on it, but gladly you don‘t need to search for shops long in those cities with 3 traders and other 2 random people giving you generic quests.Game imitates the feeling of open world. Similar to Age of reckoning. But Risen 3 does it much worse. The locations are much much smaller. It‘s not an open world game!The graphics probably is the best thing in this game. It‘s average but at least it‘s not ugly. Character models is another thing, they‘re ugly and generic, with poor animations and almost no face animations.Avoid this game. Avoid it even if on sale at 75%. I regret my decision buying it for that price. It‘s not worth your time, unless you feel obliged to play it because you paid for it, there‘s no reason to play it. Just stay away and stop supporting Piranha Bytes.Pros:PattyCons:GraphicsVoice actingGeneric questsPoor combatSmall generic mapsClunky unresponsive controls

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												EDIT:I've made a review before finishing the game, and now I'm going to review again.This game isn't the best RPG I ever played, but I garantee you, it'll be one of the most funny and enjoyable since Skyrim.+ Good story, but with some clichés+ Great improvement in voice acting (still, the main character's is aweful) comparing to the previous games in the series+Despite the game's engine being old, the shadow and lightning effect is one of the best out there, providing beautiful and colorful scenarios+ Cool artwork+ Most of the quests are original and they don't repeat a lot.+ Tons of secret treasures and chambers to be discovered+ It give's you that Gothic series feeling, which is really nice+ Combat system is captivating...-... if you get through the first hours frustration- Soundtrack is just decent, it could be much better- Face expressions are pratically nonexistent- There could be more to loot in the maps- The ship battles are cool, but it gets old real quick- Some missions are just tedious- Some bugs here and there- IA is mediocre, companions get lost frequently and after some hours in the game, the enemies are just dead meat-Dialogues are too lengthy- If you played Risen 2, you'll recognize most of the scenarios, since they are basically the sameFinal: If you can get through the frustration of the first hours, you will discover a magnificent and original RPG, that gives a perfect balance between a pirates and a common RPG theme. There's a discover here, the scenarios are incredibly rich, there's secrets everywhere, and the story is compelling. Of course, you can see that the budget wasn't very high: The combat system suffered great improvements, but it lacks some adjustments; the voice acting could be a lot better; the game engine is recycled (still, huge improvements!), some bugs are just really annoying. But still, this game is a must have in every RPG-lover collection. Specially the Gothic fans. Seriously, it's the first time in a decade that a game gives me a Gothic game feeling.Final Score: 8/10

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												A pretty good game for sure!  I got about 60 hours of fun with it using both DLCs.On the plus sideGreat exploration!  They don't limit you so don't be surprised when you finish a quest you didn't even know about yet.Graphics are quite nice.  There's an "enhanced" edition rumored but the stock graphics are really quite nice.Good quests.  Organization of the quest log can be a bit dicey (was that an island quest or a crew quest??) but having so many quests that they can be a bit hard to track is a great problem to have.A nice sprinkling of good humor.Mostly bug-free.  There are a few bugs here and there but nothing that really hurt my fun.Good autosave PLUS quick save PLUS named save system.  Why can't all games do this?On the minus sideManual level scaling (see below).Too few monster types.Sea battles start interesting but get tedious.  (Luckily, there's only a few.)Inventory gets too huge to find things.The game is open world and is intent on letting you go wherever you want, with only a few areas locked off.  Unfortunatly, that means that at least half of each island is full of stuff you can defeat with your starting character!  (The fog island DLC is an exception to this.)  So, once you finish a bunch of the first island you go to, the second will be a bit easy and the others will be a LOT easy.  To counter that, you'll need to up the difficulty level as you go along - essentially doing your own level scaling.The game has lots of crafting.  You can craft potions, rum, spell scrolls/stones/dolls, and so on.  I collected TONS of crafting ingredients but I barely used any.  Why?  See the previous paragraph.  Why bother making yourself stronger when the game isn't difficult?While the game has major balance issues as the game goes on, don't let that throw you.  The game is fun!  Just don't make yourself too powerful and keep pushing the difficulty up.  There's much to see and many, many people to chat with!

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												The best looking game in the series but the laziest and weakest overall.Except for the visuals there really isn't anything that's improved since Risen 2 and much has gotten worse. The Good:I like the visuals, the enhanced edition really looks good.  The models, the colors, and the overall look and feel of the environments are well done.  There are are few small anomalies here and there but nothing horrible or overly distracting.  Weather effects could be a bit better, but it doens't really take away anything.I like the magic.  While I haven't used all the systems if the others are similay to the way voodoo works then that's pretty good.  While magic isn't a very in depth process it's interesting and diverse enough to be fun to use.I have always liked the quest system, where you can complete the goals of a quest even before you get assigned the quest.  So if you kill all the creatures in some corner and then come across a guy who gives you the quest to go kill the creatures in that corner, you can complete it right then and there.Some minor (and major) rewards for exploring.  I like being able to look up at some rocks and ask "What's up there?" and much of the time I am able to clime up there and find something there; a dead body, some gold or food, or whatever.  Very rarely have I been disappointed from randomly exploring the areas.The BadSo mcuh of in this game is left over from the previous games.  Very little is completely new.  You'll interact with just about everyone you met before in the previous games, many of these meetings are forced and add absolutely noting to the plot. Especially the ones you meet in your very short stints into the underworld which are forced upon you at various times when you go to sleep.  Boring and a complete waste of time.Combat still sucks♥♥♥♥♥  You pretty much have the same moves you did in Risen 2 and most of the enemies still use the same tired old attack routines.  Save for a couple of the newer mini bosses and bosses every creature uses the same attack pattern that existed in previous game.  It truly boggles my mind that an alligator has teh exact same attack pattern as the wild beaked birds. Combat adds almost nothing new in installment.  Even my voodoo combat is the same as my melee combat save that it will hit multiple creatures rather than just one.  Not to mention even on hard this game is easy save for the random times the AI just goes ballistic and starts throwing up a stream of attacks there is no way you can defend against.  Also, some monsters, despite how powerful your armor is, will kill in one hit if you fail to dodge.  Combat is an annoying chore instead of a fun activity.Auto saves:  Autosaves are nice, but they are very strangely activated.  Most are okay, but there are times where they should be used when they're not.  An autosave should activate right a fast travel and tehy aren't.  If you forget to save after a fast trave to your ship and then travel to another island and then get killed by something on the beach, when you reload you'll be way back on that other island.  Also, I have encounterd puzzles where once you solve them you get ambushed and if you don't save and get killed you have to solve the puzzle again.  One took me 10 minutes to solve and I got ambushed, die almost instantly, and had to redo the god damn puzzle.  That's a horrible flaw.  Autosave on complete puzzles is a must.Vague quest resolution:  A few quests are completely vague in how they are supposed to be resolved.  One in particular I have done every single quest on the isle of mages and all I get is "I still have soem things to do before we can start" with absolutely no clue what I need to do or am waiting for.Companions:  Kinda hand for combat, though they're really slow to start fighting (I can fimish most foes before the companion even makes one attack) they are almost always in your way when you wanna loot the corpses.  You have to specifically make sure the corpse is highlighted because you companion will usually be right here in your face when trying to loot.  This is annoying as hell.The underworld:  Often times when you sleep you're whisked away into a stint in the underworld which serves one of two purposes.  So you can have a brief chat with someone you killed in Risen 2 which adds nothing to the game in the least and another to collect "soul dust" which can help elevate your soul rank, but they always end abruptly as you collect one or two and then a creature appears and kicks you out of the underworld.The UglyThe main character is a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  This guy is absolute o fun to play unless you want to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  Even if you follow the "good" path everything that comes out of this guys mouth is pure garbage.  Even when you select the nice dialoge option the character sounds like he's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off that he even has to talk to someone else.  He has set a new standard for me as most unlikable video game protagonist ever.This game is a disjointed mess.  All of its parts do not equal up to its whole.  Most of its parts are average at best, a few are good, more are bad, and a lot just doesn't make any sense.  All in all, I'm just not really enjoying this game.  Risen 2 was so much better.

												My negative rating is based purely on my own opinion, so will differ from that of others. I think conceptually, the game has a lot going for it; the levels are nice, it is graphically pleasing, the characters (despite the very VERY poor voice acting) are unique and interesting, and the pirate setting is fun - but that's all.The voice acting is very tedious. I'm not one to get hung up on such details, but when a game relies so heavily on conversing with NPC's, it can/has ruin/ed a/this game.The story is so diffuse I struggled to know what was going on, and i'm very much a narrative junkie. Where to to go, why you're going there, and what to do next were questions that for me were left unanswered. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy running about 'just because', but after the story is done. I struggled through these ~4 hours of gameplay, and, unfortunately, didn't enjoy much of it. I have Risen 2 and 1, so I will give those a go. The game holds promise, but falls flat. For those looking for a fun RPG, look elsewhere. For those who have exhausted all possible RPG's, go play a FPS.

												Having put a lot of time and effort into the first two titles (and the Gothic trilogy, of course), I figured I'd review this final title.The ability to sprint is a welcome improvement from the sluggish movement in the first two titles, with the second game's fast-travel making it more bearable than the first game. I don't think the music keeps in line very well with the themes of the earlier games (risen 2 all the way back to the first Gothic title), though it has its moments. I found the interface clunkier than the second game's, which is very unfortunate.The main character's (English) voice is terrible; I really wish this horrible voice was allotted to a minor character that dies off very early in the game rather than the one person you have to endure through its entirety. While the voices on the other characters are nice enough, with some, like Bones', improving a bit in my opinion, I find the characters less interesting than in the earlier games. I thought the combat in Risen was too plain, I thought the combat in Risen 2 was *excellent*, and I think the combat in Risen 3 is...not very good, though not necessarily a step backward. I was hesitant to try Risen 2 after my pleasant experiences with the Gothic titles and the first Risen, but after getting it on sale I was extremely impressed and thought it kept the spirit of the earlier games alive. As a consequence, I approached Risen 3 with very high expectations, none of which were really met. I don't think anyone stands to *lose* from trying it, but I can't recommend it.

Posted: August 19, 2014
												What is and what isn't Risen 3 - A guide for buyers and playersI decided to write this guide/review after all the hate that's been spreading through the forum from people who were expecting something different I think, so here it goesWhat is Risen 3?-It's a Piranha Bytes game, which means you'll be thrown into a world with little to none knowledge of how you're supposed to play, fight and deal with stuff and you'll have to learn by yourself by experimenting tactics and fighting styles-It's an exploration RPG, which means you'll be spending a big amount of time just roaming through the place to find stuff, people, quests and places, some of what you find will be rewarded, some will just be for your own personal curiosity and pleasure, you'll find yourself saying "Hey I wonder what's in there, let's have a look" a lot.-It's a piratesque/fantasy mesh game, which means you'll find a mix of both genres in it, you'll have pirates, mages, warriors, musketeers, demons, sea creatures, big ships, big castles, ruins, treasures, etc...- It's not a game about combat, which mean you'll often find yourself presented with the option to avoid fights by talking, running away, sneaking past enemies, etc. Or, if you so desire, you could smack everyone's teeth inside their skulls, the choice is yours.- It's a living world, which means NPCs have routines, interact with eachother and have lifes and monsters aren't all out to get you, sometimes you might happen to stumble upon a guy too busy to care about your problems or a dragon snappers killing worthogs to eat them.-It's a game where you choose your difficulty, which means the game won't get harder the more you progress, but you'll have to shape your character the way you like in order to fit the game, you want fights to be hard but you want every possible shiny coin in the world? Spend all your glory points into dexterity and influence, you want to stomp everything with powerful blows? Focus on melee combat. You want to survive everything and just run through hordes of enemies unscathed? Max out your toughness.What Risen 3 isn't?-It's not Gothic, which means that you won't relive your days gone by getting mauled by orcs and wargs, it has some nostalgia easter eggs and it's still a Piranha bytes game which means there are some strong points of connection and if you liked Gothic 1/2/3 you'll most likely like Risen 3 too, but don't expect to play another Gothic because it isn't such.-It's not Risen 2, which means if you played Risen 2 and didn't like it you should tell so in Risen 2's forum, not here.-It's not a combat driven action RPG, which means that if you care for insane combos with stunning animations and insanely big numbers flying all over the place you'll have to look elsewhere, fights in Risen 3 are milder and more realistic, you won't launch your enemy in the air and slash him 400 times in 3 seconds before he hits the ground.-It's not a Sandbox game, which also means it's not Skyrim, you won't have heavy modding, you won't have a world that answer to your bidding, you won't have an immense amount of general sidequests that all look the same and have no soul.-It's not a game you can understand in a few hours, which means that you'll have to put a bit of time into the game before you start to grasp all the details and untold gimmicks of the game's mechanics.And last but not least, it's not a game for everyone, which means you shouldn't get mad because people buy it and enjoy it and you shouldn't feel offended if others don't like it, it's a game so peculiar that it can only appeal to a core group of people, just like all PB games so far.All in all it's a fantastic game and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes RPGs and isn't afraid of a bit of thinking instead of buttonmashing all over the place.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												If you are looking for an action packed, gore-filled game...then look elsewhere. Piranha Bytes' games have never been about mindless slaughter, but rather deep and careful exploration of the rich environment, carefully crafted quests, interesting characters and total immersion. Risen 2 may have strayed away a bit from some of these factors, but I can confidently say that Risen 3 has certainly improved greatly over it, and the feeling and atmosphere of the game is much more reminiscent of the original Gothic games and the first Risen.One of the biggest complaints of the previous game in the Risen series was the combat system. This time, however, not only is the magic system back, adding greater variety, but melee combat feels much more satisfying, and it's certainly NOT a left click fest - if you want to defeat a strong enemy, you must dodge, block, riposte and time your hits.Risen 3: Titan Lords is a game for all the players who loved Piranha Bytes' classical works. Perhaps the plot isn't up to par with Gothic 1's, but nevertheless, as the final game in the series, it has certainly lived up to its promise to go back to the roots - the more observant fans will even notice some very pleasant surprises involving familiar characters from times gone by.

												PB came into this title promising that they'd returned to their roots and had learned from their past mistakes, but have they? Yes and no. The bad: -The story drags a bit in the middle. They do things to improve this and try to keep it interesting, but it's easy to do things in an order which can feel like a slog and not a fun progression of events. -Companions are tanks. This isn't as much of a problem on the hardest difficulty, but on medium it feels like they are more powerful than you for far too long and are neigh unkillable. If you're spending glory on skills you don't have until you join a faction, like magic or voodoo, this is especially true.-Voice acting is hit-and-miss. Sometimes your main character can sound like a badass that you'd never want to mess with, other times he has a mouth full of gravel for no reason. Also, there are too many times where you'll hear that the voice actors didn't have good direction and say lines with the wrong inflection.-Combat can be clunky. I actually put this in both the good and the bad because they improved some aspects, but from friends I know who've played the game on a console the controls can be a pain without a mouse and keyboard. This is where you'll really feel the "companions are tanks", because you can often just roll circles around enemies while your friend rips them apart. Seeing enemies get stuck behind a fence or rock and glitch out during can also break immersion.-Day one DLC. This is more a knock on the publisher and not the developer, but for ♥♥♥♥ sake stop making Devs do this♥♥♥♥♥♥ It only hurts the customer. The neutral:-Reused areas. I put this in neutral because PB has done this before to great affect, like in Gothic II. Seeing how areas change over time is fun and they are disimillar enough that I didn't feel it detracted from my experience, but it annoys enough people that it can be a negative.-Ship combat under utilized. This was one of the most fun parts of the game, but like Assassin's creed 3 it just leaves you wanting more. The Good:-Magic system is a blast. Anyone who played Risen 2 can tell you that the voodoo magic left a lot to be desired with a few cool tricks but damage spells that came much too late. Now you have three different schools of magic to play with (rune, crystal, and voodoo) all with fun and unique spells. Instead of a mana pool that gives out over time you have different elements that you can wield like weapons at melee and range supplemented by timed spells with effects like fire rain or summoning. Enemies also have vulnerabilities to elements that you can discover with experimentation. -Exploration. This has always been a strongpoint of PB games and this iteration is no different. A bevy of secret caves, islands, and treasure to find will keep you wanting to see what is around every corner for hours if you're anything like me. -Arcane Vision. For anyone who likes collecting every ounce of junk as a metagame this upgradable ability highlights objects so you don't have to worry about missing anything and squinting at every corner. It reminds me of the wisp ability from Gothic II, but much more efficient. -Huge number of interesting quests. Many may knock this game for having quite a few 'fetch' quests, but it's what you can do within these quests that lets them shine and wash away any tedium. Asked to hand out some crystals to your compatriates? Scam them instead and make them pay for the privelage. Conclusion: It's a solid 7/10 RPG, 8/10 if you like the PB style of exploration and questing. For any fan of PB's previous Gothic series I'd recommend buying now, but if you're just a general lover of open world RPGs you might want to wait for a sale. The day one DLC added a lot of content but the it will leave a sour taste in your mouth if you buy full price.

I do so I think the game is a success. I read some people saying the game isnt worth 50$ more like 30$ and I almost agree. The graphics, clunky combat is totes a 30$ game but the game has so many quests, places to explore, and frankly I have played to close to 33hrs and I still have 3 more islands and havent picked a faction... and the game seems like i havent even come to the climax of the game yet... I think it is worth the other 20$ for that alone.

Posted: July 11, 2016
												I'll try to keep this short. I didn't really enjoy the 5 hours I've played, so I probably won't play it more, even though I've heard it gets better. I was so frustrated from the combat that it wasn't fun. I didn't want to play the game, I wanted to STOP playing the game. Judging from what I saw, I was expecting the game to be more like a Medieval fantasy RPG, not about pirates, and I saw absolutely nothing about Titans. Not that that's a bad thing, it just didn't meet my expectations.Pros:Attractive environmentDecent UIYou can warp to your boatPirates are kinda coolCons:One of the worst combat systems I've used (only better than Dragon Blade: Wrath of Fire, maybe Genji: Days of the Blade)Low-level combat difficulty is not scaled well/at allSome kind of stamina system, but no stamina barUninteresting dialogueMediocre voice acting (protagonist is the worst)Performance issuesCan't change controller keybindingExcessive profanity for the sake of using profanity (yeah we get you're an F-ing pirate)Stealth skill taken away after tutorial without telling the playerThe combat consists of little more than clicking, followed by slow animations, and lots of rolling. Risen 3 requires more rolling than Dark Souls. Blocking is worthless, as you can only block the first hit and then take the rest of the enemy's combos, and almost everything is faster than you. This means they can also break your combos. The only useful tactic I found was to roll after nearly every hit, unless I was lucky enough to fight an enemy that was slow and stuck in a corner I could combo attack. Don't expect to hit anything with your pistol at a low level, especially short enemies like goblins. The combat system is also based on auto-targetting, so you can't choose which enemy to attack. Sometimes when you're just about to kill an enemy, another one walks up and then you have to deal with that for the next couple minutes before finishing the other. I found that it was really easy to accidentally hit NPCs because of not being able to target well, and had to reload my game because I don't know if they ever stop trying to kill you.My main issue with the voice acting is the protagonist. He sounds like he's always in a bad mood, and he talks incredibly slowly. I didn't have the patience to listen through all the dialogue.The opening tutorial battle was awful on my computer because of all the water FX and animations. My computer isn't the best setup, but I can play games like Skyrim decently. The only thing I can say is the game just isn't optimized well.I'm somewhat disappointed now I bought the complete edition and I can't get a refund, but at least I bought it on sale. If you really want to buy the game, don't buy it at full price. I wouldn't even pay half price for it.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I really, really wanted to write a positive review about this game. I've really enjoyed games by Piranha Bytes in the past, and Risen 1 was actually a really enjoyable game. I started but didn't finish Risen 2, because I stopped enjoying it. I was hoping that Risen 3 would have learned from the mistakes of Risen 2, and been better. I was wrong. Risen 3 is worse than Risen 2, and by a large margin.Risen 3 has some good things. The world is lush and pretty. The theme, pirates and magic, can be a lot of fun. Okay, two good things.It also has a lot of things that are not good, and in some cases very bad. The physical mechanics of the game are crap, frankly. You walk like you're on a flat plane that skates across the ground. There are invisi-walls all over the place. More specifically the fighting mechanics, are even worse. All the things that Assassin's Creed IV got right about fighting, such as the pace, the fluidity, and the using of different weapons, are all things that this game gets horribly, horribly wrong. You click to attack, and then there's a pause, and then there is a slow attack. There is no such thing as a fast attack. The enemies, however, do have a fast attack; and it interupts. Meaning there you are, slowly pulling your sword back for an attack, and 'whack' you get hit and have to restart the attack. I could continue on this subject, but there are so many other things wrong that I'm moving on.This is supposed to be an open world style game. It is one, in a sense. You have the open world of the path, and the few trees on either side. But wait! What's that toward the end of a path? It's a temple complex! So you enter the temple complex, and then you have the open world of the corridor! Don't get me wrong, the world is open to you going back and forth within the path or corridor. I admit that I've only played the first area, so maybe the world becomes more open later on.Let's talk about pop-in. Usually, pop-in is a draw distance issue where textures go from either blurry or just not there, to suddenly clear and apparant. In some horror games however, they used the sudden appearance of enemies as a scare tactic. As in, you would be walking along and suddenly BOO! an enemy jumps out at you. In this game you're walking along and enemies will suddenly pop up from the ground. It's not a slow, un-burying of an enemy. It's a quick 'look I can phase through solid matter' jump up. Not only that, but they can go from appearance to attacking instantly. Considering the time it takes for you to be able to attack, even if your reaction time is amazing, you're going to get hit multiple times before being able to land a blow. Also, this game is set on islands. Islands with rivers running across them. There is a lot of water. There are enemies that do the pop-up effect while under the water. The further problem here, is that a lot of the water has a 'foam' effect, making it opaque. That renders these popped-in enemies invisable. So then you get to fight invisiable fast-attacking enemies. I cannot, in any way, describe this as 'fun'.There are more things wrong with this game, but honestly I think this review is long enough. So to sum-up: This game is filled with poor mechanics, has a terrible story line (sorry I didn't write a paragraph about this part), has poor voice acting and scripting (or this part), but occasionally looks pretty. On a scale of 1 to 10 I would give this game a 3. [3/10]

												This game feels like it was originally a DLC for Risen#2 in which you play as Patty's brother that ended up getting turned into a full game.
