The worst thing about this game though, is the horrendous decision, to move away from the nameless here we played in Risen#1 and Risen#2 and introduce a completely new protagonist, Patty's brother.  WTF ?  Whoever smart guy at game studio made that decision aught to be taken out the back and flogged.  Long-term fans of the franchise like me were looking forward to Patty and the Nameless hero finally getting together in Risen#3.  Totally unfinished plot arc from the first 2 games.Now, to be clear I loved the Risen franchise, up until #3.  I have recommended the original Risen, and also Risen#2 multiple times.  How could the devs be so dumb as to completely change up the protagonist we came to know and love in the first 2 games ?  Not only that, the world is almost the same as that of Risen#2 with the addition of a couple of scorch marks and some fog.I totally cannot recommend this game.  I am bored with it now, I already played Risen#2 and I dont want to play Risen#2.5 which is what this game really aught to have been called.  Game uninstalled, and not completed.So, the major gripes about Risen#3 :- Same maps as Risen#2, just with some minor changes- Different protagonist from the one we spent 60+ hours with if we played the first 2 games- Game feels cheap and definitely not as well done as first 2 gamesSo basically IMHO Risen#3 is a cheap piece of crap and a money-making scheme on the Risen name from the developers.  Avoid.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I purchased, installed and attempted to play Risen 3 - Titan Lords today.Playing a game is as far as I'm concerned a way to enjoy yourself. Just finished four hours playing Risen 3, and it was not fun. The graphics are nice, and the audio is fine. My source of irritation was with the 'combat' system. My apologies for the single quotes, but that was what it felt like.First my gaming background. I've played (and enjoyed) Morrowind, Oblivion, Skyrim, Kingdoms of Amalur, Fallout:New Vegas, Dishonored, Fable: The Lost Chapters, The Witcher. All on PC.  Each with a slightly varying combat system, showing that I can adjust to different systems.Please remember that I'm giving my experience with the game; these are not criticisms, just reasons why someone who thinks and plays like myself may want to give this game a pass.My expectation in playing any game where combat is involved is that the combat is straightforward. That is, the laws of physics apply (I press 'Hit', my character attempts to swing), not the laws of combos (you can only swing at the right time as decided by the game).  And this is my reason for writing this review: Risen 3's combat system is not straightforward as far as I can tell.Here are the things I observed:- in a number of instances (during combat) when I click the left mouse button to attack, my character just stands there.- during combat, my character decides to sheath his sword (I believe I can say with confidence that I did not click the middle mouse button by mistake when this occurred).- more that 50% of the time, a standard attack from any creature resulted in my character taking damage, even while parrying/blocking.- my character would strike a creature, then perform a 180 degree pivot and strike the person behind me. I only clicked the left mouse button once. Force of habit with games like Kingdom of Amalur meant my left hand was firmly pressing the 'W' key to keep moving forward ... didn't work apparently.- the creatures at level 1 are incredibly fast. I like a challenge, but the lapse in response time by my character just meant many cycles of: Kill a creature, save, get killed. restore, kill another creature, save, get killed ... you get the idea.- in most of the games I mentioned above, there was always 'wiggle' room; you could choose which encounters you wanted, when you were prepared for them. In Risen 3, encounters are about every 50 feet, no getting around them. This would seem that the developers were more focused on combat than anything else. In the one quest where I was escorting Balbor, there were a minimum of 15 different creatures all within a 150 foot radius. (the distace is a guess, it's just to show it felt close) And when attempting to follow him away from the water source, you had no choice (not even sneaking worked, even though it is an available skill) but to engage the animals. I partially blame Balbor, as he went out of his way to 'pull' them towards me.Altogether not enjoyable. I've read a few comments by some folks in the community here, and some have expressed the thought that this would be solved by 'training harder'. I believe that can be interpreted to mean 'learn how the combat system works and you'll be fine'. My response would be 'but I have'. I know how to attack by pressing the left mouse button. I know how to parry/block by pressing the right mouse button. However, the actions I see on the screen are not consistent with what I want my character to do.Let me explain myself a bit, using Skyrim as an example (it's still one of my favorite games). If I meet an NPC whose skill level with his chosen weapon is higher than my skill level with my chosen weapon, it's quite likely I'll lose the battle. But I'll lose it because the NPC is better skilled than I am. I can still swing a sword at him, it just won't do as much damage due to my lower skill level. I can still fight and block, until he gets the better of me and overwhelms me. I don't mind losing to a superior foe, as long as I put up a good fight.But when ALL of the creatures are superior foes, and my character is effectively incapacitated during combat, it's no longer a challenge, it's a chore. And perhaps some might think me lazy, but the 'click the attack button, wait two seconds then click it again, wait three seconds and then press the Ctrl key as you click the attack button again  to perform the Super/Ultra combo' formula doesn't mean that you've mastered the game as I see it. It means it's mastered you.I read the description of the game, and viewed all of the videos available on Steam for Risen 3, spending a few days to think about purchasing it. I gave it a chance because it seemed like the character interactions would be interesting and I thought it was along the lines of other RPG games I enjoyed in the past. Except for the combat, unfortunately a crucial part of the game, it was. It would have been a great game to play otherwise.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
Risen 3 - Titan LordsYou either love it or you hate it.If you enjoyed the previous titles you will like this game - a lot.If you did not enjoy them you will not enjoy this game either.The advertisments in form of the the game trailers are kind of misleading.There you are basically promised that you get a " Gothic " experience.Instead you get a Risen 2 with slight improvements.GRAPHICSThe graphics are solid but unimpressive, they look outdated but still fit the game in a strange way.The game will probably run on less powerful machines as smooth as on high end rigs.Some animations look incredibly clunky and wooden ( like drawing your weapon ), others look organic and fluent ( agitated animals ).SOUNDThe Music of the game is beautiful and immersive, it has both a pirate and fantasy vibe.The ambient sounds are well done as well and add to the immersion.The Voice acting seems to be a matter of conflict to many people.Personally I thought it was fine, the voice acting has the typical Gothic / Risen characteristics which I personally enjoyed.The language is rude and direct most of the time, with its own kind of dark humor.Lips of the characters are usually out of sync with what they are saying, but I just noticed that because I actively looked for it.[b}COMBAT[/b]Combat is a mixed bag.At the beginning it is frustrating and feels unfair as well as clunky.Every enemy you encounter appears to be able to attack twice or thrice as fast as you can, constantly interrupting your attacks.This changes later, once you get a feel for the enemies attack patterns.The majority of the enemies utilizes a combo of 3 attacks in a row. Which become quite predictable after a short while.This is later mixed up with enemies that can block your attacks, instead of dodging it, or throwing the occasional stone or fireball at you.Later in the game you are able to improve your combat skills significantly, you will be able to learn to attack faster, add more attacks to your combos, riposte and interrupt enemies attacks.Combat feels harsh and unfair at first but quickly becomes menial as you progress in your skills.This continues to the point where you are basically a demi-god, an almost indestructible force of mayhem.Some people like it some hate it.I personally enjoyed it because it instills a feeling of gratification, like you worked hard to get there and now you are able to enjoy the fruits of your labor.One thing about combat however seems quite annoying, almost all types of enemies are able to knock you on your♥♥♥♥♥Sending you flying through the air.It makes sense with certain type of enemies such as big rhinos or Golemts.However I fail to see how a small spider, a lake lizardman ( which is basically a water-ghoul ) or an over sized chicken ( scavanger ) can constantly send you flying.Magic seems powerful and satisfying, there is no mana just cooldown rates which you can decrease by unlocking various perks.There is a good amount of spell variety. COMBAT AT SEAThe game offers some mini games to liven things up a little.You will have to combat other ships and Sea-Monsters.Combating other ships is very scripted you basically just have to fight some pirates on deck and beat their Leader.This is accompanied by some shooting the board cannon, which feels quite underwhelming in terms of power and destructive force.The Sea monster combat allows you to steer your mighty vessel and give the sea monster some broad-sides.This battles with Sea monsters become progressively more difficult, the last encounter is frustratingly difficult.Everything about it feels wrong, the monster seems overly powerful and have homing shots.After I beat it I felt more like it was a stroke of luck than skill.Many people seem to complain about it, especially since its a " mini game " that you can´t skip.If you reached that point it basically blocks your progress until you beat it.There seem 2 ways around this issue :1. Lower the difficulty, which makes the battle mind numbingly dull and underwhelming2. Prepare yourself to try it 10-20 times in a row.Maybe there are some very good players who found a pattern or strategy to use, I personally could not find it.ITEMSAny good RPG like game needs vast amounts of Weapons and Armor and othe trinkets to make you feel like a truly mighty Warrior.The game offers a variety of Armors consting of hats, chests pieces, pants, boots.Depending on the faction youi will join you get access to 3 exclusive types of Armor.As you progress in the ranks of your faction you will advance from light armor to medium to heavy.Armors look good and characeristic for their faction.You can also get some general pirate themed armor from vendors or as special rewards from quests.These all look nice but are utterly inferior to your faction armor.With the exception of something just labeled " Heavy Armor " that you can find on your adventures.Which is slightly better than your tier 3 Faction armor.If you own the Adventurer Garb DLC you get a set of armor that is slightly better than your first faction armor.Which makes quite a bit of a difference at the start of the game.The armor just looks kind of whacky.There are various accessoirs to choose from, such as rings, earrings and amulets.Those basically boost your stats and allow you to specialize your skill sets.Weapons, there are plenty of weapons to be found.Swords, Axes and Maces, sabres and fencing weapons.I personally could not see a big difference between the weapon types.You get perks for each class, and all seem to do the same amount of damage.There are slight variations but they make no difference in actual combat.Wether your weapon does 95, 100 or 110 damage does not matter, you still need at least 2-3 hits to kill an enemy in the end game.So it just is a matter of taste.There also is a Musket type of weapon, allowing you ranged combat.If you choose to use this combat will change slightly but soon falls into the same patterns as meele combat.Last but not least you are able to utilize dirty tricks, which basically are secondary weapons.You will be able to throw daggers, fire a pistol or crossbow in the heat of battle.If you have enough ammunition this can change your combat style a bit.However it is quite tedious to use in the beginning.Without proper training your will miss a lot, this has nothing to do with your personal skill however.It is purely stat based, an enemy can stand point blank and you still will miss with your scatter pistol ( which is like a pumpgun in pistol form ).There are only 2 components that matter : skill level with your desired dirty trick weapon and range.CRAFTINGThe game offers an extensive crafting system.You can Craft new weapons, repair broken legendary weapons which you can find in your adventures, craft rings and amulets, brew booze ( yay ) and alchemical tinktures.You also can create your own spell-scrolls / rune stones.You gather resources by picking them up ( herbs and so on ), ripping them out of defeated enemies ( requires hunting perks ), finding them in chests, or buying them at vendors.OVERALL GAMEPLAYThe game plays smooth, you can reach about everything you can see, there are few invisible walls that block you from reaching zones that you are not supposed to reach yet.I only got stuck once in the environment but could rescue myself with the parrot spell.Combat becomes boring fast, since its very basic. The old Gothic Combat system is far superior.Quest / Quest logs are sometimes confusing, leaving you wondering what to do next.The game does not hold your hand much, which is nice.You can get additional mini rewards by talking to people that had a part in a quest you completed

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												Don't be fooled by the overall positivity, this game in almost all of its aspects is atrocious.The first and most standout aspect of this game should be the combat; fast paced, exciting, fluid, and interesting combat should be a staple for any game of this type to make up for the long sequences of talking and looting.  Unfortunetly, this game is none of that.  The combat is separated into light and heavy attacks that look no different from each other, (Don't even get me started on the hilariously terrible idea of "heavy attack" in swordplay, but I'll spare you my historical rant).  Your light attacks feature a spinning flourish for every single attack except for one that leaves you completely open for counter attack from the VASTLY quicker and deadlier enemies that you face (even the pitifully tiny fish monsters at the start of the game).  Should you choose to string together attacks in a combo your strikes will become progressivly slower until the final strike where the enemy would sooner die from boredom while it waits for the attack. Dodgeing is neccissary but commically utilized, and the "parry" system is downright useless when compared to rolling around like an idiot with invincibility frames.  Secondary weapons are consumable and boring in excecution.Bottom line for combat is that it's unintuitive, boring, and most importantly just not fun in any way.Then we have the story.  The plot takes after "video game trope A-4" in the fact that it does almost nothing new in its excecution.  Demon overloard was woken up from a nap and now he's cranky, as the player character only you can stop him because why not?  I will say that the distinction between reality and the spirit realm was entertaining for a momment before I realized it had no impact whatsoever on how I played the game.Bottom line for plot is that it's only a background for tearing into new land for looting, no real significance to how you play the game.Sound track isn't noteworthy, while it does serve as an adequate filler.Animations are stiff and cringeworthy. Seems like they poured all of their budget into the spinny dance techniques the character employs in his swordplay.The only reason I would ever have to want to play this game is the hear the protagonist swear at NPC's more.  It's actually really fun to  have a pirate as the protagonist because he has no obligation towards manners, which creates the  exceedingly rare vaguely pleasant momments in the game.Final margin: the game is simply bad.  It's based around systems that are honestly not fun at all.  I bought this game when it was 75% off and only 8 or so Canadian Dollars, and I feel guilty for my idiocy.  I could have just bought a toy cutlass from the dollar store and had ten times the fun this sopping mess of a game gave me.  Please, do not buy this game for any ammount of money.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												This game is a gem and you wont find many others like it. It has so much heart and character. The world just feels so deliberately crafted. Everything in the game world is placed with a purpose. This design choice deviates from the random events and occurrences in modern games like Skyrim, but brings to the table a feeling that this world was crafted with care and attention to detail. This, among other things such as the loot, craftable materials, varied jungles, caves, beaches, fortresses and more make exploration a real treat! My favorite location is Calador, a volcanic island with a massive waterfront fortress and green bonfires dotting the coastline. It really is a sight to behold!Ultimately, this game is all about getting lost in the vast world and forging your own destiny! It's about exploring and finding all of the secrets and content packed into the game! it's about side quests, and loot, and character progression, and choice! The choice to pick a direction, any direction, and be confident that there will be something new to discover right around the next corner. It's about all of these things... and while the game certainly isn't perfect, it's definitely a rare gem in a sea of mainstream rpgs that all try to do the same thing over and over.In short, if you're a Gothic/Risen fan, you know what you're getting into, and this is some of PB's finest work. You may love it, you may hate it, but I urge anyone who's on the fence to give it a shot! I hope you can find as much enjoyment in this game as I have so far.

												I'm a big fan of the Gothic series and saw this on sale so grabbed itI haven't gotten that far but I am thoroughly disappointed and feel ripped offtl;dr : it feels like a mediocre xbox action gameMovement is slow and choppy as hell. My fps is just fine but there is lag to the input and the movements are too large and clumsy to feel like anything but a clutzCombat is♥♥♥♥♥♥ Partly related to movement and partly mechanics and timing of the attack/combo/parry system. Input is laggy and actions take too much time to have any feeling of fun, it feels like i'm sending orders to a wooden puppet stuck in molasses. Movement and dodging is so slow you can't react to anything you just have to guess if maaaybe the guy is going to attack in 5 seconds so you have enough time to start the animation. The only viable technique seems to be standing around in parry until the enemy finishes their animation so you can start yours.Maps are claustrophobic and feel fairly linear. Again, feels like an old mediocre xbox game that didn't have much memory to load bigger maps or display many polygons. You don't feel like you have much room to move around, and movement is so slow and clumsy it's a chore to run anywhere. The 'side' areas are just tiny branches with a few things on the ground to pick up off and then you are back on your one main path again.Graphics aren't that great. I like the style but the graphics feel dated. I'm running with everything on the highest settings possible and it'd still get beat by games 5 years older than it. C'mon, my computer can handle a few more polygons or foliage that doesn't look like abstract art. Bad ui/controls/ai - Controls are super simple.. again feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ console port. You pretty much just spam mouse clicks everywhere to do anything.. which includes picking up gold or talking to your annoying ai companion. Just from the start I've already gotten sick of trying to pick up gold or something and constantly going into the short 'talk' action with the companion. Her sass gets old reaaaal quick. Horrible combat/non-combat modes - There are two basic modes.. combat where your controls are all for fighting, and non-combat for things like running around, interacting with the scene, looting and picking up stuff. And the animation to draw your weapon is laggy and slow as hell. What does this mean? You can either run around in non-combat mode so you can look for loot and stuff to interact with, and then when you get ambushed from nowhere on the tiny maps sit there getting♥♥♥♥♥♥♥until the monster gives you enough time to finish your draw weapon animation. OR, run around with your weapon drawn unable to loot anything. Awesome choices!Pros: I don't really have any at the moment. I like the pirate/magic crossover. I haven't gotten far enough to experience many different skills so I'm really hoping those help provide a tiny bit of fun for the giant waste of money this has been so far.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												PB games are NOT for everyone, the stories won't blow you away, the graphics are usually not up to par with current tech, the camera usually sucks and animations are some of the worst you will come across. Yet there is alot I enjoy with the games PB has made (Gothic 1-3 and Risen 1-3). Risen 3 is here and in my opinion it is the best of the series, Magic is back, melee combat is improved (you still have to go to trainers and learn new moves, improvements,etc.. Some of the series long lasting issues rear there head such as what I mentioned above with the terrible animations and a story that could be alot better). Risen 3 won't win Game Of The Year awards and probably not many RPG of the year awards either with games like Divinity Original Sin, Wasteland, Dragon Age and Pillars of Eternity out or coming out this year, it does have a good amount of issues but for me the good outweighs the bad and overall is my favorite PB game since the wonderful Gothic 2.The overall combat is a nice improvement from Risen 1/2, you have the option to put points into skills with glory points you have gotten (from doing missions and killing enemies) and also training with trainers in towns for new moves like Parry, Pickpocket,etc.. These improvements help big time for things like combat,etc... Hit a trainer up for Parry, Speed and what ever type of sword you use (Slash, Sword or another) and you will be kicking♥♥♥♥♥in no time. This game does not hold you're hand, it is a very nice challenge, although not quite as hard as Risen 2. Combat is not perfect though, there are still some issues but bringing Magic back and improving the Melee abit has gone a long way. Far from a flawless game but a nice step in the right direction for PB, hopefully they can improve even more in this department for the next game.The start of the game is a bit slow and can also be very tough, especially for new players. You're character has not leveled up and doesn't have any moves really other than a normal and a heavy attack. Get past the first little bit and things start to pick up quickly. You have lots of trainers to pick from and also a bunch of factions to pick from so make sure to use them. These games don't hold you're hand and you will feel overwhelmed at the start, just make sure to visit trainers and save often and you should be good.The graphics are improved from Risen 1 and Risen 2, but its still inconsistent. Some of the landscapes, character faces and colors look gorgeous, while other things like buildings up close and animations are laughable. Although for me I dont expect top of the line graphics or animations from PB games, they are much more than just fancy graphics or animations. Sure I would love a Risen game on a Witcher engine or something (speaking of witcher, the devs said they have taken inspiration from the old Gothic games also made by PB, for there upcoming open world game Witcher 3), but this is a smaller dev team and atleast for me animations and graphics are last on my list. Still there are some spots where I was in awe of some of the beauty in the game, come over a mountain at night with you're torch and you will witness a beautiful scene.The leveling up is very good and you have many options with how you want you're character to go. Want to do some thief aspects? Put tons of points into the categories that support pickpocketing and locksmithy when you level up and also go to some trainers and improve that way to. Also depending on what faction you join you will have access to unique things and missions (I joined the mages, which I am liking alot, especially there island, looks like Risen 1/Gothic style.The audio and music overall is pretty good, the soundtrack is very good that really kicks in when you are exploring these wonderful levels. The voice acting for the most part is good, it ranges from poor to fantastic, but most are good I will say. The game also has the usual PB humor which I love (Divinity Original Sin also had some good humor to), and the dialogue in general is well done (few cheesy parts but would it be a PB game without a little bit of comedy?).One of my favorite aspects of PB games is the exploration and scavaging and Risen 3 does these with flying colors. Each island is different from the last and while some of them are frmo Risen 2, they look completely different, this is the game Risen 2 should have been imo. Also the characters are great and interesting once again, where ever I go in the game I always meet characters that I enjoy talking to, some are funny, some are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and some are in the middle. In that sense the writing of the dialogue and characters is good but the writing of the story is not very good impressive.It really comes down to what you think of PB games in general, yes it is an improvement over the first two games but it still has some of its long lasting issues that might throw some people off. But for me I am 30 hours in and having a blast, findng some new areas have me saying "Just another hour Kozzy". Risen 3 has been fun as all get out so far, but I don't expect everyone to enjoy this game. The level design is also very well made, each Island I want to explore EVERY INCH. This is something alot of open world rpg devs need to take note of from PB. Sure there is alot of things they can do better, but they have exploring, level design and characters NAILED. What is next for PB? I would love another Gothic game with the improvements made in Risen 3 and hopefully even more improvements down the road. Weither its a new game on a new engine or another Risen or Gothic game I look forward to playing there next game.Sure I wish we could have a new Risen game on a new engine with the best new tech, a better story and for them to keep improving the combat, but in the end I have had a blast and while it won't be my GOTY from a technical standpoint, it has given me some of the most fun ive had in all of 2014. Sort of like indie foreign flicks in the sense that they might not be the best from a technical standpoint as they don't have as much money or people working on the games as some of the big wigs, but they end up doing some aspects better, while some aspects are not as good.In the end Risen 3 is a flawed gem that I recomend to anyone who enjoyed Risen 1, Gothic 1-3 to play, it is a nice mix of the old gothic games and Risen 1/2. Will I say it is better made than say Skyrim? From a design perspective, Hell no. What I will say though is that I have had much more fun on this game in 30 hours than I did playing Skyrim 80 hours. For me the characters are much more enjoyable, the exploration is much mroe rewarding, it is much more challening, I have had more FUN and I like the gameworld design better. If you can put up with a slow start, some terrible animations and a meh story, pick this up with the quickness, it is quite enjoyable.For me this is the best overall PB game since Gothic 2, it is not as open as Gothic 3 and while Risen 1 was a blast, if we are talking best overall package I have to say this is my second favorite PB game. It definatly has its issues and it seems impossible for PB to nail everything perfectly, but I would be lying if I said I havn't been hooked to my computer since I got this game and that a few things have been a nice pleasent surprise. No its not GOTY material or better than the wonderful Divinity Original Sin that we got this year, but I have had a very fun time with Risen 3 so far, a flawed gem indeed. Not quite the masterpeice it could have been, but still my overall experience has been good to great.

												***Updated*** I was asked to be less vague about the combat issues.Maybe worth $20-$30, graphics and animations are sub par. Not terrible, but nothing special to look at even on max settings.Combat is clunky and boring, I'm one for diffuiculty, but this is just frustrating. The game is unclear to areas you should be going too. Dailogue is so bad an uninteresting, they try to spice it up with curse words. It's not about them holding my hand, I went to the begining island after the intro chapter. I fooled around with getting some new gear at the shop and upgrading some skills. Even with these upgrades I would be 2-3 shot by an enemy.You get a light attack, a medium attack, a cheap shot (your pistol), a parry and a dodge.Light attack- everything is faster than you, the chance of attacking and not getting hit at least a few times is slim. Wouldn't be a problem if I didn't die in a couple of hits. (Yes there are potions, but excessive prices and the amount of damage you take eats up your money fairly quickly)Heavy attack- needs to charge and is slow, 75% of the time the monster just jumps away from you and you miss.Cheap Shot- This is kind of cool, but damage is weak and you only have a finite amount of ammo or throwing knifes.Parry- this is useless most of the time, even an enemies light attack can break your guard and since most enemies double attack you get hit anyway. A parry is supposed to break the momentum of enemies opening them for an attack. This is a crappy block function at best.Dodge- My least favorite mechanic, your recovery time almost always leads to you getting hit by a follow up attack or another enemy.You end up just blocking and dodging waiting for your companion to kill things. I don't need to be the god of war, but I don't appreciate being a punching bag either.The real draw back to the dialogue is the horrible animations, making it almost unbearable to sit through even a 30 second engagement. I'm sure the game gets better, but almost 2 hours in and I can't even stand to look at it anymore. Reminds me of two worlds, if you remember what that was like I would steer clear of this title.In short I would not recomend buying this until it goes on sale and only if you are an older style rpg fan, or you really enjoy the series.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Risen 1 was not that good of a game. There were few objectives other than just wondering around and not dying. The landscape didn't really change. The quests were repetitive.  And you played 99% of the game by yourself with no help from NPCs.   Risen 2 made huge strides.  Suddenly you had objectives and travelling companions.  The NPCs were unique and interesting. I saw many of the elements that made KOTR, DAO Baldurs Gate and even Mass Effect great:  The concept of having a ship/stronghold and seeking out and finding NPCs to form a crew/party capable of taking on some monumental task.  In the process you visit different lands that showcase very different environments, keeping the game from getting boring.  At the end of the day, I can say that I would replay Risen 2 a second time, and that says a lot for a game. So when I saw Risen 3, I bought it hoping for something at least as good and hopefully better than Risen 2. Sadly I was disappointed.  You are no longer playing as the same nameless protagonist that you played in Risen 1 and 2.  Instead you are playing as the brother of the protagonists love interest.  And instead of being educated and well spoken, like someone who could just as easily be a mage or a pirate, the protagonist is a typical pirate thug. One of the games themes is overcoming your thuggish nature...You still have a ship. You still have to gather NPCs and you still get to visit different lands, but it is not fun playing a jerk. I figured there would be a reason why they forced this on me. A plot twist or something special about being related to Steelbeard that was key to the plot.  But it never happens. At the end of the game, I said to myself, "There is no reason I could not have been the protagonist from Risen 1 and 2". Regardless of the plot twists or other RPG elements they incorporate, this is one choice they take away from you is simply unforgivable. And since the love interest from game 2 is your sister, there is zero romance and flirting. An element that made most of the other big hit titles I mentioned so successful.So no, I can't recommend this to people. Even if it was free, you are looking at wasting 40+ hours of your life that you will never get back.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
 The Death of NostalgiaI think the nostalgia force might be a bit too strong with this one, young padiwan.I myself am exempt from such forces - the first time I played Gothic 1 and 2 notr was Xmas 2011. Make no mistake, I get it. I get why they are such great games. Rewarding combat, memorable soundtrack, brilliant world design etc. but for me Gothic 3 Community Patched with Alternative AI and Balancing trumps the first two, and so does Risen 1. Risen 1's combat is probably the best combat in any similar RPG. The fact that it is possible (though very difficult) to beat the hardest enemies and NPCs with just your starting hero and a wooden stick, is a testament to its greatness. Memorising the enemy's tendencies and combat behaviour is very rewarding, and does not make the game too tedious later on even, as I doubt people will always remember the AI patterns perfectly and perfectly counter them. Dungeons, baby. Dungeons. Brilliantly designed, extremely rewarding dungeons. Of course not too challenging, but you were always under the illusion that you were doing something fairly clever when levitating across lava to morph into a snail to use telekinesis on a lever. The illusion of being a gaming genius and treasure hunter, tomb raider.The voice acting is brilliant too - Lena Headey as Patty was sublime and I wanted to have sex with her animated body. I couldn't have been the only one. Also, memorable music from none other than KaiRo seals the deal. I could go on about Risen 1 and how underrated that game truly is, but alas we need to deal not only with the hits of Piranha Bytes, but also with the misses. In comes Risen 2. ...What were they thinking? How...on earth could they have destroyed the combat so utterly. So profoundly. In the beginning there was no dodge either so to occassionally back away you resorted to this very awkward bunnyhopping. Eventually you realised how OP firearms were and just said ♥♥♥♥ it, let this game be over and done with. Moments of brilliance were seen with the rare use of Voodoo magic to complete some quests, and the beautiful world design. But the voiceacting was atrocious, in addition to the animations, music was forgettable and there were severe vegetation morphing issues (granted fixed by the community later on).I was very very disappointed.In comes Risen 3. Combat still not as good as Risen 1, or even indeed the older Gothics, but it is passable. Music is almost memorable. World design is PB at its finest yet again, with so many levels intricately, hand-designed, with loot sparingly thrown into nooks and crannies waiting to be discovered. But the point is that it is good *enough*, it scratches that Gothic itch. The combat, though a lot more forgiving, will still punish you if you are lulled into a false sense of security due to your stats and weapons and magic. The graphics are gorgeous, especially when tweaked, looks better than many dx11 games, though art design plays an important part in this.What was my point? Enjoy Risen 3 for what it is - it is not Gothic 5, it is not the nameless hero (we know his name is Steelbeard after all), it is not surrounded by KaiRo's music, it is cross platform therefore dumbed down for console peasants, it is Piranha Bytes giving us the best they can whilst trying to earn a living (PC sales are usually a fraction of console sales), it is fun.Oh, and remove those rosetinted nostalgia glasses once in a while and smell the coffee. It's time to move past decade old games.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												EDIT: To address the whole, "You haven't played this game enough to judge it" thing, the reason I haven't played this game that much is because i saw the core mechanics of the game, and they were very flawed, so much so that it made it clear to me that i would not have an enjoyable experience playing this game.   ALSO, there are no pros because this game did not impress me in any way; therefore, i did not find it important for me to say something like, "Yeah, this part wasn't totally bad", or "I guess they did this part okay-ish".  I found this game to be a waste of $50.  I mean, the game looks and feels like a game i played back in 2003, and it's not even as good as that one.  Now, let me elaborate a bit on what i found to be bad about different parts of the game. First and foremost, the combat system. Absolutely awful combat; it feels like you're playing an RTS game(They attack, you block, you attack, they block or don't).  Not to mention the fact that it's nearly impossible to kill more than one enemy if you don't have a follower.  To sum this one up, the combat is, like i said earlier, an annoying RTS game.  Next let's talk about the voice acting.  It's horrendous.  I mean, the way people talk makes it impossible for you to be immersed.  To sum this one up, you'd be better off using JUST the subtitles. And last, let's talk about the graphics.  Well, there isn't much to say about the graphics, seeing as they are pretty non-existent(that's an exaggeration, of course). But really, they are pretty awful-even on max to near max settings.To sum this one up, the graphics are similar to that of a game made back in around 2010(Just an estimate)Now, to sum everything up, i would avoid this game unless you are a hardcore Risen fan that doesn't mind poor game development, or you just don't mind poor game development and think this game is fun.

Posted: September 16, 2015
												Having actually enjoyed Gothic 3, and then Risen 1 and 2, I was quite surprised by how tedious I found this game, to the point where I stopped playing and unistalled it after about 10 hours. I thought for sure it would be an improvement over the previous two Risen games, or at least as good.  How long should you play a game that is boring and frustrating before throwing in the towel?Since I played a 30 hour game for about 10 hours, take that into consideration when reading this. I was not able to finish, nor would I ever want to. But I paid for it and did not really get my money worth. The first Risen game was pretty straight forward, with a simple plot and simple combat with a small yet interesting island to explore. Risen 2 gave you a pirate ship and a crew and added some more complexity. I guess Risen 3 had to get more complicated, giving you too much to do, too many ways to do it, and too many places to go. The combat was sloppy in the first two games, but you were able to endure it and it didn't really get in the way of progress. In this game, the combat should have been cleaned up, but instead it is still clunky and it now gets in the way of progress. The low level enemies surround you and overwhelm you with interupting attacks. After 10 hours, I still felt like a weakling. The game starts off by taking all of your abilities away from you and leaving you with a crappy raft. You have to really work to get it back and it felt like a chore. I never did get my ship back, and I didn't want to grind my life away to get it. I never felt any sense of improvement from gaining experience and abilities. I basically felt like a helpless idiot wandering around an island getting killed by every single enemy I would encounter, doing fetch quests for the locals with little payoff. The game really is a chore. It should pay you to play it.

Posted: February 11, 2015
												Here's the thing about Risen 3Even though I've pressed the "I recommend this game" button, I don't think it fits for all situations.The graphics are decent, the writing and voice over have their moments but are overall mediocre, the story is... meh and  the game play is tough.This should not be confused with Dark Soul's tough but fair, as in if you die, YOU screwed this up, nope, it's more like, if you died , yeah you may have done something to prevent this, but probably your character isn't really good enough at this moment, so run away and level up.In fact the game play is a classic zero-to-hero deal, like in the gothic series and the other risen games, if you enjoy being beaten mercilessly at the beginning only to come back 10 hours later to BEAT THE CRAP OUT OF THOSE STUPID DODO BIRDS THAT STUNLOCK THE CRAP OUT OF YOU....... yes you will enjoy this.While exploring, you get stat points or skill points or whatever they're called, and you can spend them to raise your stats. If your stats are high enough you can buy skills, this is what in effect counts as leveling, and many of the skills make a huge difference in your character's fighting ability, and if you will be able to kill a monster or not.You will at some point get to pick one of three factions, which will give you magic, doing it sooner rather than later will make the game easier.The only problem (yes I know there are a number of problems, this is the only one that I cared about)  I've had with this game is that , even though I like the zero-to-hero model, towards the end it becomes very easy, in fact boringly so, I powered through it just to say that I have finished it. I guess they could have done a better job at keeping the difficulty a bit higher towards the end.Overall I liked it, maybe my opinion is a bit biased for personal reasons, or because I played this right after the shipwreck that was sacred 3, which made me appreciate things a bit more.Bottom Line:If you liked the gothic games or the previous risen games, or if you like games that start out frustrating (no , not hard, there's a difference) , then this game is probably for you

Posted: December 26, 2014
												Good:- Return of three factions increases replayability.- Diverse and effective spells/skills, many of which are unique to each faction.- Characters and dialogue still have the old PB charm.- Islands are large and interesting to explore.- Expanded combat mechanics.- You can turn into a parrot.- You can talk to a parrot.- Your parrot has his own questline.- You can still deploy monkeys.- Treasure hunting is still fun.- DLC is way more substantial and compelling than Risen 2's.Bad:- Enemies only attack one at a time, making groups of enemies far less threatening than they used to be.- Morality system encourages metagaming rather than making choices you genuinely believe in.- Patty looks like a stripper.- Chani is more white.- You play as a new protagonist with a silly voice.- Combat still has the old PB jank.- Skill checks rarely offer alternative quest solutions.- Naval boss battles are annoying.- Lots of recycled content from Risen 2.- Lockpicking minigames are still tedious (though this is true of minigames in general).Conclusion: If you enjoyed the previous Risen games, you will very likely enjoy Risen 3. If you didn't enjoy them, Risen 3 won't change your mind.

												Overall the game is ok, fairly long playing time with good RPG elements.Positive:+  Graphically it is pretty good, with latest patch they've improved texture resolutions. FPS does drop when everything is maxed out.+ Story is fine. At least I didn't forget what I was supposed to do, when playing this game only 1-2 times a week+ Minigames. Although simple, some of them are pretty fun to play.+ Exploration. The game always encourages you to look for something special that is hidden near by. It is a very rewarding experience+ Map design, overall pretty good and with a nice variety.Negative:- Combat. The most frustrating combat experience ever. I couldn't find any other game where combat experience was that bad. Controls have a lot of delay, some keys don't register so you have to mash the buttons multiple times to make sure it will. The overall dodge mechanic is just annoying and doesn't make the combat fun in any way. In fact, while you are dodging you are complete invulnerable to damage ? Batman Arkham series have shown what a good fun and fluit combat should be like, take notice Piranha Bytes ! - AI. I don't even know if there is an AI in this game. Pretty much all the enemies just charge straight towards you, and go into attack/dodge cycle. Funny thing almost every single monster in the game behaves pretty much the same way, shouldn't there be a better variation of enemy AI, maybe ? Companions pretty much the same thing, while they do follow you, sometimes they just get stuck and become missing, or they go and run away from you, just to hit a monster. And why enemy AI always targets me first ? The fact that I have companions doesn't seem to matter to them.- Glitchy and buggy, for some reason the game kept crashing on me, I occasionally get stuck in the walls, enemies don't care and just go through them. Many other minor issues as well.- Difficulty spikes. In the beginning when you are going with melee, you are going to be destroyed a lot. In the end when you go with magic you are going to destroy everything so easily that game becomes extremely easy. Shouldn't there be a different difficulty curve, like easy in the beginning and harder in the end instead ?

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												The dialogue in this game is so absolutely, hilariously, cheesy. The voicing of our "Hero" was probably supposed to be along the lines of Captain Jack Sparrow, but actually sounds more like Jason Stratham (Transporter) doing an impression of Mel Gibson playing Jack Sparrow. ;o) And the general character animations during dialogues were usually restricted to swaying back and forth and a few complimentary waves of the hand. Oh, and Patty, looks like a strip-a-gram in a naughty pirate costume, which MAY be very distracting for some players.But, you know what? None of that's, by any means, a deal-breaker. I did groan a few times during the first hour or two, but once I got used to it, I actually started to accept it as "just the style of the game" and began to find it quite funny.As for questing, well it takes a little while to get yourself up and running to a level where you can at least deal with stuff. Spending a good few hours on the same island at the start (your chosen faction) will serve you well. After that, it's off to explore the map, and do all the usual "Questy" stuff...which was really quite fun, and only minimally "back & forth, back & forth".The graphics/environment were pretty good, and the free-to-roam aspect was fun. Especially once you've figure out how to get to the seemingly impossible to reach places.If you like this type of game, it's pretty good fun, and does not take itself seriously AT ALL! 												Ive been a fan of both risen games, risen is, in my opinion, one of the best old-school-rpgs out there. Instead of fixing the problems the previous games had, it puts them on steroids.The combat in risen always had a few problems, the players windup has always been a little to long but in this game it takes AGES to throw a punch, that on its own wouldnt be to bad if the enemys had any windup at all (which they dont) they throw a barrage of attacks at you (each of them stunning you and canceling any attack youre trying to do) which leaves you two options:1. Be totally at the mercy of the enmeies AI, hoping that you get enough hits out before the lock you in place.2. Go ranged and run and jump around like a cat hoping they dont get to youThe voiceacting is beyond terrible, which is a shame considering that they got a lot of the voiceactors from the previous games back, who are even playing the same characters. They didnt do so bad back then (gruanted the dialouge was pretty cheesy at times but always beliveable) which leads me to belive they just werent given any directions or at least pretty terrible ones.The world itself is designed pretty well, they took old maps from risen 2 and modified them so it would fit the needs of this game but never to a point were you couldnt recognize them anymore, you can always remeber back how it looked "back then", they even have characters from the previous games who you dealt with on your journey in risen 2, thats cool, right? Not really, since youre not the same character as from the previous games, you cant really talk with them about anything from the past, which makes having them there kinda pointless.I never would hav e thought that this would be the closing statement of my review to a risen game but:DONT BUY IT!

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												For all Gothic or Risen fans, I can highly recommend this game, especially for the German speaking gamers, 8.5/10. You get the RPG which are you are expecting from Risen 3, I actually really liked the story, the setting with the 3 main islands (and smaller islands) which had a distinct setting, the huge open World to explore, fight monsters, gain XP, increase your talents with trainers, hunt for treasure chests, win in Mini games, recruit companions... a lot to do.  What really makes this a typical Risen/Gothic game is the athmosphere, and the "dirty rough" dialogs, which work really well in German (likely not as good in English). The voice actors are excellent, and together with some really crazy and funny quests, they made me smile several times, and thats what I wanted to get.So why not an even higher grade? Well first, the story is almost completely dissociated from the Risen 1+2, which is particularly wierd as you start with the "Girlfriend" from Risen2 as companion, but in Risen 3 she is your sister... the 2nd reason is the difficulty... its a bit too easy... and the monsters are not so different in strength anymore... in previous games, stronger monsters like Snappers can kill you in 2 attacks, and you have no chance to kill them... here, you can kill them from the start... which does not make you feel so much that you get stronger with time... and from ca. half-2/3 of the game, you kill everything without much fear of death...In conclusion, Risen 3 is well suited for both veterans who want more of the same formula, but is also good for newcomers, as you dont need knowledge of previous games to enjoy this one.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Titan Lords is my first game of the series, a game that took a little bit of play through before I really started to enjoy it.  At first glance the game swallowed me with its active environment.  You have the moving oceans, moving trees and grass, animals/vermin/creatures and colorful settings.  While the graphics of the environment was very good in my opinion, the character models did not feel on the same level. Titan Lords gave me a chance to play as a pirate.  With this comes the accent, sea monsters, ship battles and a lot of booty.  (The loot because as far as I know no other booty was obtainable.)The games main characters voice annoyed me in every dialog.  Titan Lords is an easy game to play.  The combat felt over simplified.  Most of the beginning combat consists of parry/dodge and clicking one button to swing the weapon.  You do have a secondary weapon which is a ranged weapon.  From early on one of your goals is to join a faction.  This basically outlines what type of weapons and magic you will be learning.  Titan Lords have several quests for you to check out.  By end game with all of my skills even though the game is easy, I felt like my character went from some lame pirate to the ultimate badass.  I had a lot of fun gathering alliances to overcome the shadow.  Get this game on sale if you love rpgs.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												This game is a wonderfully retro rpg that I truly appreciate still having baldur's gate 1 & 2 and other simarly retro games.  I purchased this game recently and I am really enjoying it.  I am not the type to disregard the possible fun and exciting game play simply because the graphics aren't up to snuff by todays or even the standards of 5 years ago.  To be honest I think the games today are focused way too much on graphical appearance and feel and not enough on story and plot development, or character development.  A good backstory can`t be overlooked simply because a game requires a quad-core i7 processor.  The UI is well done in my opinion and has just about everything one could hope for, and the companions or crew don`t require any micro managing.  I think the idea of massing a crew for a big ship is a splendid plot device though i`m slightly disappointed in only having one companion at a time.  I thoroughly recommend this game to anyone looking for a change from current rpg game types, and most definitely for old time gamers such as myself who appreciate games like this and still play the oldies but goodies.

LONG AWAITED-Risen 3 people!!!-Did I mention Risen?-Improvement over the other series (although haven't played 2)-Gold and leveling is harsh but enjoyable-Hilarious dialogues-Decent graphics, even my 1.7 GHz i5 HD Graphics 4000 can run it in 20+ fps almost all to low-The fires were amazing, makes me feel warm just staring at them-Open-world, damn where do I start?Cons:-Combat, needs target-locking, I don't want to switch targets when my original target is one slash to death-Voice acting, decent, but it could be better-Not really immersive-----Minor spoilers-----They say first impression lasts and that is what happened; the game didn't catch me at first, but after I left the first island, I was surprised with the potential of the game. I was also surprised I had a lot of quests already at my logbook haha. Damn, those fires were beautiful, and the combat was really unpredictable; you just can't rage and spam left clicking or just parry your battles, but rather wait for an advantage.Although, I'm really put off by simply chugging down a bottle of rum and regaining health in an instant, which really breaks the immersion. I also hated the slow movesets in combat, it goes out at random, and even the combat is about who strikes first, so you're in a disadvantage if your first move is that piroutte against a sand devil or a scavenger.Overall, the game is decent, it has both it's positives and negatives. Don't expect a Witcher game or something dark and macabre, but expect something more of a simple, magical and piratey theme.

												One of the best RPGs in recent years. Honestly I'm not sure to which game should I compare it, each Piranha Bytes game is its own experience, and I love them for that.I loved all games in Gothic series and I love all games in Risen series. From the Risen series, I would say that Risen 3 is probably the best one of them, even comparable to the golden Gothic 2.The story of this game is solid, it is not the best, not the worst. I've been quite used to bad stereotype-like stories in RPGs (especially open world ones), like TES series, Two Worlds series, or Dragon Age series (in case of more linear ones). Each of these games suffer from black-and-white storyline (from the named ones I consider the plot one of the better ones).The gameplay is typical for Piranha Bytes games. The combat system is something different, and very good (unless you just left-click all day long, which is a bad way to play this game and it can ruin your experience). It is better than in TES games, way better compared to Dragon Age series, but a lot worse compared to Dark Messiah of Might and Magic.In this game you can actually dodge hits (which is very common in medeival fencing schools), but well, don't expect realistic fight simulator. But it is action enough, you won't get bored. Plus, guns are very good addition into the game.Dialogue lines are well done, audio for them is also quite good. As for the quests, there is a whole lot of them, but I'd like more impact on game in general, and longer side quest lines. Music is one of the best, it perfectly suits the game.Visuals are also very good, very nice fire particles, water splashes and particle effects in general. The authors did quite a job on light and shadows, each single island is in a bit different stylized art set and it works perfectly. The graphics quality can compete with any other AAA game.Of course there are few things that look bad. One of them is, that after performing major actions to close gates to underworld, the islands look unchanged. For me, if green grass would return to that areas it would be perfect. I would see that I did some major impact on game world and it would made me even more happy.Second thing is, I don't really see further lore connection with Risen series, yes it is in the same world, there are some of the characters that were in previous games, but the lore connection is weak. I'm comparing mainly to Gothic 1 - Gothic 2 games here, where the lore connection between those game was really strong and good.Anyways, this game is worth it. I know it seems average, it isn't. Don't believe metacritic, as some fans of older Piranha Bytes games are downvoting, without even playing it, sadly...

Great game. Sure I'm only 30 hours in but I think it's lovely. I'm currently a fire wizard dressed up all cool like, runnin around like prince Zuco, burning like 3-4 enemies at once, raining fire down upon my enemies! >:D and when fire doesn't work, LIGHTNING!! Anyway, if you're up for a fun single player RPG, this is a good pick. My only Con: I wish games like these could be Co-op. 												Having just finished Risen 3, thought this would be a good moment to put down my thoughts..I have been a longtime fan of Piranha Bytes.  From their earliest releases such as Gothic & Gothic 2, to their jump over to the Risen series, I have always found their games to be enjoyable, but always needing more polish.  Risen 3 is no exception to this.  I stopped and started the game several times before I really sat down and played through it.  And, in the end, I'm glad I did.  It felt very much like putting back on a good pair of shoes again, just comfortable to be able to play the game, and in the end I pushed through it quickly because I wanted to get to the end.  Much like the last 2 games in the series, the ending was a little disappointing, but I did enjoy the experience of getting there.There are bugs, there are wonky issues with inventory and resolution and other items.  But, look up a few FAQs and whatnot and you can get past most of it.  From a programming side of things, the game was.. competent.  It always feels like they need just a few more months, or just some extra money, and they could pull off what would be considered to be a AAA game.I would recommend this to others, and while it is nice to have the previous experience of Risen 1 and 2, it isn't entirely necessary to have played those to enjoy this one.

												Ive been a fan of both risen games, risen is, in my opinion, one of the best old-school-rpgs out there. And risen 2 is one of the few good pirate themed rpgs in existence.This game however.. kinda sucks. Instead of fixing the problems the previous games had, it puts them on steroids.The combat in risen always had a few problems, the players windup has always been a little to long but in this game it takes AGES to throw a punch, that on its own wouldnt be to bad if the enemys had any windup at all (which they dont) they throw a barrage of attacks at you (each of them stunning you and canceling any attack youre trying to do) which leaves you two options:1. Be totally at the mercy of the enmeies AI, hoping that you get enough hits out before the lock you in place.2. Go ranged and run and jump around like a cat hoping they dont get to youThe voiceacting is beyond terrible, which is a shame considering that they got a lot of the voiceactors from the previous games back, who are even playing the same characters. They didnt do so bad back then (gruanted the dialouge was pretty cheesy at times but always beliveable) which leads me to belive they just werent given any directions or at least pretty terrible ones.The world itself is designed pretty well, they took old maps from risen 2 and modified them so it would fit the needs of this game but never to a point were you couldnt recognize them anymore, you can always remeber back how it looked "back then", they even have characters from the previous games who you dealt with on your journey in risen 2, thats cool, right? Not really, since youre not the same character as from the previous games, you cant really talk with them about anything from the past, which makes having them there kinda pointless.I never would hav e thought that this would be the closing statement of my review to a risen game but:DONT BUY IT!
